title: BAAM Celebrates new Soccer Field and 20 Years
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
BAAM Celebrates new Soccer Field and 20 Years

 May 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 663
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Not only did Building African American Minds mark 20 years of service Saturday, but the organization also celebrated the creation of a great space where children can play.BAAM has refurbished a soccer field for children with new Bermuda grass. They had a ribbon cutting to open the new field near Moton Park on May 11.
Located in Easton, the nonprofit provides scholarships, afterschool programing, summer camp, and more to empower at-risk youth in the community.
A white tent full of local government officials listened to different speakers at a podium set up right in front of the field.
Frank Gunsallus, president of the Easton Town Council, said, "I want to extend special thanks to everyone involved in making this project a reality. From our dedicated town staff to our numerous community volunteers and generous sponsors."
The small crowd of officials clapped as the colors were raised on either side of the podium.
"Let's continue to support and invest in our parks and recreational facilities to ensure that Easton remains a vibrant and engaging community for everyone," Gunsallus said.
Del. Tom Hutchison (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) came up to the microphone.
Hutchison said, "You have done such great things for the community. This is a great addition for the children and youths that are here."
He presented citations to BAAM for U.S. Sens. Chris Van Hollen and Ben Cardin honoring BAAM's 20 years of service.
Mautz said, "If you had been standing here 20 or 30 years ago, you wouldn't recognize where we are standing. I am looking forward to everybody kicking soccer balls out here."
The sound of DJ Hector could be heard in the distance as Amy Kreiner, president of the Talbot County Chamber of Commerce, came to the microphone to give a glass award to BAAM.
"It is my honor to present Derek and Dina Daily with this 20th Anniversary plaque on behalf of the Talbot County Chamber of Commerce and blessings for the next 20 years," Kreiner said.
Then they stepped onto the pitch for a large red ribbon cutting to open the field up.
William Ryan is president of the board of directors for BAAM. He was smiling as he wore a BAAM sweatshirt.
"We want to get our kids out playing as much as possible. It is part of the town park. It is open to all. If you want to have an event, you have to check with the town. We started out small and we have just been steadily growing," Ryan said.
There were members of the construction crew that actually built the field. It was a lot more than siting a rectangle. Lucas Lees, coastal and land designer of Unity Landscapes, had a three man crew that got the drainage on the field just right.
"We ran into water lines we weren't expecting, but since we were putting in irrigation it was convenient that the town already owned them. It really transformed this space and completed the park," Lees said.
Unity Landscape built it in 45 days.
Derick Daly, founder of BAAM, said that key is being long-term. The relationship with the town, the donors and the staff were all long-term.
"We wanted a place where kids could come and call it their own. We are opening up the soccer field with the partnership of the town of Easton developing with this field for youth soccer. Come out here and just have fun. Play and enjoy yourself, get out and exercise. This could be an incubator for kids to get exposure and take it to another level," Daly said.
Looking past the new soccer field, there was BAAM Fest going on closer to the community pool. There were 31 community partners, whose colorful tents lined a winding sidewalk.
"We started BAAM Fest to give out information about what we are doing. It turned into offering a meal to everyone. We have free lunch for everyone. We have a band as you can hear, face painting — the kids love it. We have community partners," Daly said.

title: Tench Tilghman: A Talbot County-born revolutionary hero
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Tench Tilghman: A Talbot County-born revolutionary hero

 October 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 795
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — One of George Washington's most trusted men has roots in Talbot County, and this week he was celebrated by a local chapter of the Maryland Society of the Sons of the American Revolution.The SAR's Colonel Tench Tilghman Chapter honored its namesake after receiving proclamations from Easton and Talbot County for the inaugural Tench Tilghman Week from Oct. 19 to 24.
Tilghman, born in Talbot County in 1744 and educated there during his youth, was a primary aide-de-camp for Washington during the Revolutionary War. Wes Hagood, chapter president, has deeply researched Tilghman and his critical role as one of Washington's right-hand men.
In 1776, Tilghman joined Washington's staff. Washington often referred to him as "family" in written letters, Hagood said.
"He became, in a lot of ways, like a son to Washington," Hagood said. "… They carried on a relationship until Tilghman died."
Tilghman's calling card was his duty of delivering the notice of British surrender following the Battle of Yorktown. Surrender came on Oct. 19, 1781, and Tilghman arrived in Philadelphia on Oct. 24 to confirm the news to the Continental Congress.
"It's probably one of his most recognizable accomplishments," Hagood said.
Hagood described Tilghman as "hard working" and smart, adding that he "probably would have had a role in the future government had he lived." He provided leadership to patriot soldiers and often was responsible for finding food to sustain the troops, Hagood said.
In a letter to Continental Army General John Sullivan in 1781, Washington spoke highly of Tilghman.
"This gentleman came out a captain of one of the light infantry companies of Philadelphia, and served in the flying camp in 1776," Washington wrote. "In August of the same year he joined my family, and has been in every action in which the main army was concerned. He has been a zealous servant and slave to the public, and a faithful assistant to me for nearly five years, a great part of which time he refused pay."
Following the victory, a portrait of Washington was commissioned in 1781, depicting Tilghman and Marquis de Lafayette. Maryland-born Charles Willson Peale painted the portrait, which is displayed today in the Maryland State House.
Tilghman died in 1786, leaving behind his spouse, who spent many decades thereafter in Oxford on Tilghman's father's plantation. Today, Tilghman is buried at the Oxford Cemetery after being reinterred in 1971 from his original burial site in Baltimore.
MARYLAND 400
Hagood, who has read all of the letters Tench Tilghman wrote to his father during the war, pointed out the Talbot County native's critical role in the Battle of Brooklyn in 1776. At that battle, a larger and more experienced British army posed a significant threat to patriot troops.
Owen Lourie, "Finding the Maryland 400" project director at the Maryland State Archives, calls that the "first major battle." Lourie says the troops known as the Maryland 400, along with some from Pennsylvania and Delaware, reformed to attack the enemy after a damaging British charge.
While there were massive casualties, Lourie says the Maryland 400 "bottled up" the British and prevented them from delivering a "final death blow" to the other continental soldiers that were escaping.
"It is probably not too much of an exaggeration to say that they saved the Continental Army," Lourie said.
Witness to the heroic efforts, Tilghman applauded the Col. William Smallwood's 1st Maryland Regiment, Lourie notes. "No Regular Troops ever made a more gallant Resistance than Smallwood's Regiment," Tilghman wrote in a memoir.
Lourie and the Maryland State Archives are working to identify and write biographies on as many of those soldiers as possible. There were more than 1,000 Maryland troops, and his historian work has helped identify over 800. He says he's focused on "telling the small stories" of those Marylanders that may not have been thought of in hundreds of years.
Lourie is presenting a history of the Maryland 400 at the Talbot County Free Library on Saturday at 11 a.m., an event sponsored by the Tench Tilghman Chapter which wraps up Tench Tilghman Week.
Dana Newman, library director, says registration is open online at tcfl.org, with limited spots remaining. It will also be livestreamed on Talbot Library's YouTube channel.
Hagood is excited for Tench Tilghman Week to return next October and for years to come.
"What better way would there be for us as a chapter to fulfill our mission of educating current and future generations about all of this than to have a week dedicated to Colonel Tench Tilghman," Hagood said. "And this year, just start with one event. But the idea is, we'll do this every year."
Following the Maryland 400 presentation on Saturday, a free program on how to join the Sons of the American Revolution and Daughters of the American Revolution will be held at the Talbot County Free Library from 2 to 4 p.m. in the Frederick Douglass Room.

title: Groove City Festival - Cambridge community enjoys dancing, good eats, street fair
author: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com
content:
Groove City Festival - Cambridge community enjoys dancing, good eats, street fair

 August 31, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com | Page: A5 | Section: News 
 
 625
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Yock soup and African dancers whirling to live drums were all part of the community rich scene at the fifth annual Groove City Culture Fest on Pine Street in Cambridge on Aug. 19.It was a great, family friendly, street fair where grandmothers were dancing with their grandbabies and fathers were buying lemonades for their daughters.With not one, but two music venues at each end, a DJ and a live stage, the event was joyously loud.Four city blocks were packed with vendors. There was BBQ chicken being prepared by the hunky stepping dance troupe from Omega Psi Phi. With every flip of the chicken, these fraternity brothers came up with more highly aerobic, synchronized dance moves. It was like going into a '90s soul video with the smoky sweet smell of chicken."Stepping is something we all do to get together to unify us. It is mainly an uplift for events. This is our fourth year doing this. It puts us out there in the community.We do a scholarship.We all believe in education.All these guys are from the Eastern Shore and went to UMES or Salisbury," said Albert C. Jones Jr., or "Queban." He said they were not done and will all get together to hop.One festivalgoer tried to sum it all up and thank some sponsors.Veronica Taylor, president of Groove City Black Heritage and Cultural Group Inc., said, "It will be a rockin' party. If you weren't here, you should have seen the phenomenal performance by the Universal African Dance and Ensemble. A great performance.We started preparing for this in April. We get funding from grants, the city of Cambridge, the Elks Lodge and the Maryland Heritage Way. We get support from throughout the community like Dorchester Center for the Arts." "My favorite part is seeing all the vendors on the street.We started in 2018. Five years. I want to thank the community for trusting in us to provide a good cultural experience for them," said Taylor as she looked over at a broken generator that was supposed to power the live stage. The large trailer mounted generator was not turning over, but they got it going after trying to jump it with a yellow van.On a more serious note, getting a solid education is the key to prosperity and the ability to give back to the community. It makes leaders in a community.Victoria Jackson-Stanley, former mayor of Cambridge, is a member of Delta Sigma Theta sorority, which is a service based group. She was wearing the red and black colors of her sorority."We are a public service organization. We are here to pass out information about the mission of Delta Sigma Theta. We are part of the Cambridge alumni chapter.Scholarship, service and sisterhood those are our motto," said Jackson-Stanley.Lois McCord president of Delta Sigma Theta said, "We do get out the vote. We work with young girls in our community.We offer scholarships for college." Not only could the community shake it and have a good time, they could also find vital resources to help make life a little better.This festival had it all including the smell of funnel cakes frying. 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/TMCCA LL@CHESPUB.COM
 
Food was a huge factor in the fun of Groove City Culture Fest. These folks were running a lemonade trailer.
 
PHOTO BY TOM MCCALL/TMCCA LL@CHESPUB.COM
 
Universal African Dance and Drum Ensemble stole the show with rousing examples of this ancient art form.
 
PHOTO BY TOM MCCALL/
 
A member of the Universal African Dance and Drum Ensemble goes deep to pull out the rhythm.
 
PHOTO BY TOM MCCALL/TMCCA LL@CHESPUB.COM
 
Yock soup was offered up. This tomato based dish has tangy and spicy covered while noodle and hard boiled eggs and either chicken or pork. Some added hot sauce to this soul food fusion.

title: Garfield Center announces cast and production staff for 'A Rock Sails By'
author: Staff Writer
content:
Garfield Center announces cast and production staff for 'A Rock Sails By'

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 231
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Garfield Center in Chestertown will open its second production of the 2025 season on April 25 with Sean Grennan's play, "A Rock Sails By."The play centers on Dr. Lynn Cummings, a facts-only astrophysicist facing personal challenges. When an unidentified object heads toward Earth and she's misquoted by a journalist, she invites him to witness the object with her as it approaches Earth.
Grennan's plays and musicals have seen hundreds of productions worldwide. He has served as playwright in residence at several theaters and as an adjudicator for the Midwest Dramatists Conference.
Nic Carter, the GCA's theatre manager, directs the production. The cast includes Suzanne Thuecks as Dr. Cummings, Macy Morris as Olive Cummings, Dominic Delcoco as Jason Harper, Adrienne Wrona as the Messenger, Brianna Johnson as Haley/Taylor, Hester Sachse as the Doctor/Chancellor and Michael Tucker as Tom.
The production staff includes Stage Manager Jordan Dixon, Sound Designer Benji Price, Technical Director Butch Clark, Costume Designer Heather Robuck, Props Designer Jennifer Kafka Smith and Light Board Operator Shannon Carter. Carter is also the scenic designer.
The production runs weekends through May 11, with 8 p.m. performances on Fridays and Saturdays and 2 p.m. performances on Sundays. The lobby opens one hour before showtime, with house doors opening 30 minutes before performances.
For tickets, visit garfieldcenter.org, call 410-810-2060, or visit 210 High St. during box office hours (Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.).

title: Robbins YMCA opening reading hub to tackle childhood illiteracy
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Robbins YMCA opening reading hub to tackle childhood illiteracy

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 500
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Robbins YMCA is stepping up after Dorchester County Public Schools faced significant budget cuts this year.The school district started this budget season with a $10 million deficit. Addressing that deficit meant Dorchester County schools lost after-school and summer programming.
The cuts to education come at a time when the county ranks 21st out of 24 school districts (including Baltimore City) in third grade literacy and 22nd out of 24 in overall English Language Arts proficiency in the state.
The Y is partnering with the John and Janice Wyatt Foundation to create a space for the Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading, a campaign that aims to target childhood illiteracy.
{span}The campaign was inspired by the movie "Sentenced," which was produced and narrated by NBA champion Stephen Curry. The film explores the epidemic of childhood illiteracy and its lifelong impacts.{/span}
"Dorchester County has, for a long time, been ranked very low in the state of Maryland," said Matthew Peterson, executive director of the John and Janice Wyatt Foundation. "And so interestingly, now concurrent to all the work that the Y is doing, that we're all doing together, Dorchester County Public Schools is undergoing a strategic plan to go from 21st, to 15."
The Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading plans to approach this goal from multiple angles and with multiple partnerships.
Because third grade is a pivotal marker for childhood learning development, the campaign's target population are children from birth to age 5, so they are better prepared to enter kindergarten, and are less likely to fall behind.
"So we're trying to grab moms as prenatal because we're gonna do infant groups, we're gonna do, you know, toddler groups, mommy and me groups, so we want to bring awareness at early childhood," said Tynice DeShields, director of mental health at the YMCA of Chesapeake.
The campaign's partners include county schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson, the Dorchester County Public Library, United Way of the Lower Eastern Shore, Operation Pathways and volunteers from the community.
"There's a number of agencies we've been working with over the years. You know, as any organization, some were more engaged than others, and so bringing everybody on board, finding out where that alignment fits best, and then trying to leverage that, to do the best we can, is what we've always tried to have," Peterson said.
The reading hub will be a space that is open to the public and YMCA members alike.
"We're building this reading hub as a meeting place where we can have a resource center, we can have meetings with the community, we can have sessions with the parents to teach their kids how to read, how to look at letters and numbers, and not just throw a book in front of them," said Bryant Wittington, director of the Dorchester County Campaign for Grade Level Reading.
Peterson, DeShields and Wittington are excited to engage with the community and hope to build a strong foundation of volunteers at the reading hub.
"We want to build that unity in the community," Wittington said.

title: Nearly 300 Chesapeake College students celebrate graduation
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Nearly 300 Chesapeake College students celebrate graduation

 May 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 691
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Nearly 300 Chesapeake College students were cheered by friends and family as they received their diplomas on Wednesday during the spring graduation.Clifford Coppersmith, president of Chesapeake College, congratulated the graduates for their achievements in furthering their education. Coopersmith recounted his journey as a community college graduate over 40 years ago.
In his speech, he referenced two themes he wanted to share with the graduates: the first acknowledges the extraordinary times they are living through, and the second theme is the hope that the graduates embody.
"I wish to focus on all of you, our first cohort of students graduating with degrees and certificates that were impacted the most by the immediate and following effects of the COVID-19 pandemic," Coppersmith said. "You have persevered in the most difficult times we have seen as a nation in decades, and your decision to pursue your education, to quote a colleague of mine, Dr. David Harper, is a sign of hope, in and of itself."
An array of individuals were honored, including Rob Thompson, current director of arts for Chesapeake College, who received the 2024-2026 Bounds Distinguished Teaching Chair Award.
In Thompson's speech, he spoke of Victoria Woodhull, the first woman to run for president in 1872, and her dedication to her dream for a more equal society. He described her as a pioneer for women's rights.
"Woodhull never asked for permission to try and change the world or to embark on any of the careers she took up," Thompson said. "She felt an injustice, she found a purpose, and she took action in as many ways as she could think of. For as long as she could stand, it would all be a national figure. But as her story shows, she was just as focused on changing conditions in her home as she was on the nation."
Thompson described the importance of shaping homes and communities and the power that adapting after failure has on people.
"That's not so much persisting as it is adapting and seeking an alternative," Thompson said. "Chasing dreams requires that you travel down some dark and twisting trails. But you've got to keep searching. My student's dreams and their remarkable capacity to show up with creative minds and passionate hearts have carried me through this career. I'm talking about you guys."
After Thompson's speech, Milton Nagel, vice chair of the Chesapeake College Board of Trustees, presented the John T. Harrison Award to Zulema Delacruz Martinez. The John T. Harrison Award is given each year to a student who has demonstrated the highest academic performance, leadership and overall contributions to the college and the community.
Delacruz Martinez was praised for her commitment to Hispanic and Latino students within the region who are interested in college but may be intimidated by the academic process. She has organized several events to welcome the students and their families to complete college applications and sign up for resource services.
During her speech, Delacruz Martinez recounted her childhood growing up in a nontraditional home and witnessing the extraordinary hard work that her mother had to do to provide for her and her brother.
"My mother overcame so many obstacles while making so many sacrifices. It was then, at the age of 8, that I vowed to do the same. I decided I would learn from her experience of having a front-row seat to my mother's hardships as she overcame her adversities. All of those experiences have pushed me to persevere."
She recounted the resources her advisers gave her and the many people who helped guide and support her to finish. During her time at Chesapeake College, she founded the Hispanic Latino Student Union, learned to be a leader and found her home there.
Toward the end of her speech, Delacruz Martinez praised her classmates and offered words of encouragement.
"Take advantage of every opportunity that comes your way. Build upon meaningful relationships with those around you and keep persevering as you keep persevering. Whether that be in your future college endeavors or in your day-to-day lives," Delacruz Martinez said. "I leave you with this quote: 'To make a great dream a reality. The first requirement is a great capacity to dream. The second is persistence.'"

title: 'Love In Action' displayed by Black Excellence fund
content:
'Love In Action' displayed by Black Excellence fund

 August 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A9 | Section: News 
 
 326
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Salisbury, Md. - The Black Excellence Community Fund, which is a Community Foundation of the Eastern Shore Giving Circle, celebrated Black Philanthropy Month by awarding grants to three Lower Shore Nonprofits at an evening dinner event on Aug. 5.The grants benefit local nonprofits, which impact the quality of life for the local Black community.Each organization received a $500 grant for their work. Grantees were: ▪ Young Elites of the Eastern Shore West to East Coast Aviation Network (Y.E.E.S. W.E. C.A.N.) produces emerging young leaders interested in the career fields of aviation, aeronautics, and aerospace technology.▪ SchooLARS 4 STEM is a local grassroots mentoring program that seeks to create a cohort of K-12 aged students with strong STEM aptitude.▪ Faith Over Fear Economic Empowerment Inc. builds stronger communities by providing resources and professional development for newly established black-owned businesses or expanding businesses."The theme for the evening's event was 'Love in Action" and each of the nonprofits selected embrace this theme daily through their work," said Sonya Whited, founding member of BECF. "Each grant recipient's story of local impact reminds us of the importance of giving back to our community."The event highlighted recent proclamations from Wicomico County designating August as Black Philanthropy Month, along with a citation from the Maryland General Assembly which honored BECF for philanthropic community support during Black Philanthropy Month.BECF was created in 2022 at the Community Foundation to preserve cultural awareness and pride by expanding the benefits of education, health, and welfare in the Black Community, while teaching the values of philanthropy. Members work together through the power of collective philanthropy to create a positive impact in the community.To get involved or learn more visit CFES.org/becf.

title: Police charge woman with being accessory in killing
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Police charge woman with being accessory in killing

 October 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 341
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - An Easton woman is charged with acting as an accessory after the fact to second-degree murder and related charges in connection to the shooting death of a 55-year-old man in August.Detectives from the Easton Police Department arrested Dana L. Wilson, 59, on Thursday, police announced.The charges, which include acting as an accessory, altering physical evidence and obstructing and hindering a police officer, stem from Wilson's alleged involvement after the shooting death of Easton resident Ty A. Brooks in early August.Police responded to the area of 104 Blake Street around 7 p.m. Aug. 7 for a report of a person who had been shot and was laying in the grass.Officers arriving on scene rendered aid to the man, later identified as Brooks, until paramedics arrived. Brooks died from his injuries at the scene, police said. He was transported to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore for an autopsy.Police said earlier in the day, Brooks argued with individuals that were near and operating a 2018 Land Rover Range Rover, which was parked in the 100 block of Blake Street.Brooks left the area and returned later, operating an ATV. Brooks confronted the same individuals with a shotgun, police said.Police said after the group exchanged words, a man seated in the driver's seat of the Range Rover fired shots through the front passenger seat window and struck Brooks' side.The man in the driver's seat was identified by police as Daseir Cornish, 22, of Denton. Cornish is charged with second-degree murder, assault, manslaughter and related charges in connection to Brooks' death.After Brooks was shot, he fell off of the ATV, police said. The Range Rover fled the scene accompanied by a gray Hyundai sedan.Police said Thursday that when officers were attempting to secure the crime scene and render aid, Wilson walked to the area where Cornish allegedly shot Brooks and retrieved his cell phone, which was dropped by Cornish. Wilson left the area with the phone, police said.Wilson was released on a $25,000 unsecured bond, according to online court records.

title: It's about community - Chesapeake Bay Walk to Defeat ALS set for Oct. 22 in Centreville
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
It's about community - Chesapeake Bay Walk to Defeat ALS set for Oct. 22 in Centreville

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 892
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE - The Chesapeake Bay Walk to Defeat ALS is on track to reach its $35,000 goal on Sunday, Oct. 22, and organizers are hoping last minute walkers and supporters will join the fight.Walkers will sign in at 9 a.m. at Route 18 Park in Centreville. Even those who wake up and decide to participate that day can get in on the action and register at the walk.When Pam Clark Edwards of Centreville, was diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), in February 2021, her family and friends not only rallied around her, they lost no time launching the effort to raise funds for the ALS Association.Edwards' daughters, Meredith Kulbacki of Centreville and Morgan Edwards of Winter Garden, Florida, spearheaded the Oct. 2022 Walk that rallied some 140 people who walked, ran and wheeled to raise over $30,000.Their team, Pam's Praying Pineapples, will be joined by 10 additional teams this year.As of the beginning of October, the local walk had raised over 80% of its goal."That's pretty amazing," Kulbacki said. "I think we can definitely get close to that, if not reach it by the walk." The community has reached out to help. Other fundraising in the form of raffles and a 50/50 drawing will be held, and about 40 items were donated by local businesses.For example, "we have a foursome golf outing at Queenstown Harbor, an official NFLfootball signed by Justin Tucker of the Baltimore Ravens, a gift basket from Draper Brothers liquor store, cosmetic gift bags, jewelry and various services," Meredith said.Fun activities include pumpkin decorating for kids.The ALS chapter from D.C., Maryland and Virginia will be sending helpers to be stationed at tables, so people can find out more information about ALS itself, and maybe about how they can help, Kulbacki said."If they have become a caretaker to someone with ALS," she said. "There will be workers there to help them through that." Information will be available for people who have been diagnosed with ALS.In fact, some members of Edwards' care team at Johns Hopkins will be attending the walk Ebb Tide Tent & Party Rentals in Queenstown donated a large tent, while Queen Anne's County Parks and Recreation donated the use of the park.Community support has been "just amazing," Edwards said."Having the support of the community helps us as a family deal with all of this," she said.The Clark family has deep roots in the county. Pam and her husband, Fred, and Kulbacki and her family live on the family farm just down the road from the park where the walk will be held.Pam is a retired teacher in Queen Anne's County Public Schools.Pam's mother, June, and her brother Jeff have canvassed local business owners, who are supporting their longtime neighbors.Edwards' longtime friends and colleagues are part of the small committee helping her daughters. Connie Dean, Barb Thompson and Bobbie King have rallied around the Edwards family to help out where they can to help organize the walk.Kulbacki, who was raised in Centreville, spent eight years in York, Pennsylvania, and recently moved back. "It means everything to me. It means family," she said.During the COVID pandemic, she and her family, which includes her husband and two children, decided to move back home "on a whim." "We felt so alone with just no family and (few) friends there," she said. "We had no idea that this would happen.We say it was almost like God told us. He helped us through this, and it was almost a blessing in disguise that we moved home, so that we could help my mom and my dad and my family through this." "So not only to be here with them, and then also to have so much support from everybody in the community and all of our friends and family - it's just amazing and we're so thankful for that," Mer said.Kulbacki knew about the ALS Association's Walk to Defeat ALS through a sad coincidence. The mother of a close friend in Pennsylvania died from ALS about a year before the Kulbackis moved to Maryland, and Kulbacki had participated in a Pennsylvania Walk in memory of Becky Miller's mom."I didn't know that it would affect me so deeply a year later, so it's been amazing to still be friends with her and have support from her because she knows what I'm going through," Mer said."You never know when ALS may affect a friend or family member," Edwards said. "It is becoming, I think, more prevalent. I know five people who have passed away from it, not because I have been in this situation - these are people who have been in my life." "It's a disease that they really do not have a treatment or cure for yet, and we just need to put money into the resources for help for these families, as well as to provide money for research," she said.To register online for the Oct. 22 Walk, visit Walkto-DefeatALS.org.For more information about the ALS Association, donating your time or resources and supporting the Walk to Defeat ALS Chesapeake Bay, visit als.org or contact coordinator Tara Huang at tara.huang@als.org. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Team Chesapeake Bay is ready to lead the Walk to Defeat ALS Oct. 22. From left are, Fred Edwards, Pam Clark Edwards, Meredith Kulbacki, June Clark and Tara Huang from the ALS Association's headquarters in Rockville.

title: EDITORIAL: 10-cent paper bag fee should be optional
author: Staff Writer
content:
EDITORIAL: 10-cent paper bag fee should be optional

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 923
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Earlier this week, the Easton Town Council debated a proposal to remove a 10-cent fee on paper bags used to bag groceries and other purchased merchandise.We think that fee should be optional — if retailers need to charge the fee to cover the cost of the bags, they should be able to do so. But it is also important that store owners be able to provide the bags at no charge as part of the service they offer customers.
The April 2023 Easton ordinance banning the use of plastic bags required retailers to charge customers a fee of at least 10 cents for each paper bag used, encouraging shoppers to bring reusable bags. It came as the Town Council banned the use of plastic bags for packaging purchases in stores such as groceries and retail shops. Restaurants and food establishments are exempt from the ban.
This is a hot topic in Eastern Shore communities.
Late last month, the Commissioners of Oxford debated a similar ban for Oxford before tabling the proposed ordinance.
Like it does in Easton, Oxford Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan said the Oxford ban would apply to retail establishments including grocery stores, convenience stores, shops, department stores and service stations. The ordinance would not apply to restaurants and food service establishments.
During the Oxford public hearing, some business owners and employees expressed concerns with the proposed ordinance. Graham Norbury, the general manager at Safe Harbor Oxford, said that while this may be a national issue, he doesn't observe plastic bags being littered often in Oxford.
"Why is restricting a retailer's right to choose the best delivery mechanism for their products, why is that something that the commissioners feel necessary?" he asked.
Oxford Vintage and Trade owner Barbara Ranson said in her six years of being in business in Oxford, she has always used paper bags. She said she doesn't understand why the commissioners are looking at this legislation when "it may or may not target three very small businesses."
We think Oxford should follow in Easton's footsteps and ban plastic bags and even expand the ban to include restaurants and food service establishments.
Plastic bags have severe and dire affects on the environment.
Non-biodegradable: Plastic bags can take hundreds of years to break down in the environment. Instead of decomposing, they break into smaller pieces called microplastics, which can persist in the ecosystem for even longer.
Pollution: Plastic bags often end up in waterways and oceans, where they can cause severe pollution. Marine animals can ingest or become entangled in plastic bags, leading to injury or death.
Harmful chemicals: As plastic bags break down, they can release harmful chemicals into the soil and water, which can contaminate ecosystems and pose risks to wildlife and human health.
Energy and resources: The production of plastic bags involves the use of fossil fuels and energy, contributing to greenhouse gas emissions and resource depletion.
Waste management: Plastic bags can be challenging to recycle due to their lightweight and flimsy nature. They can clog machinery at recycling facilities, leading to higher costs and lower recycling rates.
Just this week a Star Democrat editor watched a plastic grocery bag go airborne from the bed of a pickup truck crossing the Bay Bridge. The bag floated into the air where a breeze caught it and sent it flying over the Bay, eventually landing in the water. That bag became a death trap for a fish or a bird. This is not an isolated incident, we are sure readers can recount similar experiences seeing wayward plastic bags.
So we stand firmly behind banning plastic bags and think more towns should follow the lead of Easton and Oxford.
Our complaint comes with the imposition of a 10-cent fee that Easton requires retailers to charge a fee if a customer requests or needs a plastic bag.
There is a good reason for that fee: It provides an incentive for customers to begin using reusable bags, which are far better than even the paper bags.
"The reason for the proposal to remove this fee comes directly from the voices of many Easton residents who are feeling its impact," said council President Frank Gunsallus in explaining the proposal to make the fee optional, "especially those in lower-income brackets who are already stretching every dollar to make ends meet."
Gunsallus and Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery both said they've talked to residents who do not support the current 10-cent fee. The rest of the council, though, stated otherwise.
"I have heard from many people the exact opposite, that the ban is working and that the 10 cents is not onerous in any way, shape or form," Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry said.
Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello and Ward 4 Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis stated the fee has incentivized people to bring their own reusable bags. Abbatiello said, "the reason for that (fee) is because paper bags pollute just as much as plastic bags do."
All valid arguments on both sides of the issue. Our thought is that this is an issue that should be left to individual retailers to decide what is best for their businesses.
Nearly everybody from the audience who spoke at Tuesday's council meeting supported leaving the mandatory fee in place.
Easton resident Shari Wilcoxon held a different stance, questioning why the businesses are forced to charge the 10-cent fee.
"I don't know why people are afraid of freedom of choice," Wilcoxon said. "Why don't you let the merchants decide if they want to charge or not, what's wrong with that?"
We agree with Wilcoxon and hope town council members look to making the fee optional when the issue is discussed again on Sept. 16.

title: classic corner - "The French Connection" drives William Friedkin's talent home
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
classic corner - "The French Connection" drives William Friedkin's talent home

 September 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 169
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Of the films that the late director William Friedkin was known for, "The French Connection" particularly endures for a number of reasons not the least of which is one of the screen's greatest car pursuits, which Friedkin admitted he shot in a renegade style that only enhances its impact and legend. Turner Classic Movies shows the picture Thursday, Sept. 14, to lead a memorial salute to Friedkin, who died in August.He won an Oscar for the fact-inspired 1971 police thriller (named its year's best picture at the awards), as did Gene Hackman as "Popeye" Doyle, a tough New York detective determined to get the goods on a seemingly untouchable international drug smuggler (Fernando Rey). Roy Scheider also attained stardom as Doyle's partner, and while there's much else to recommend about the movie, the chase that puts a wild-driving Doyle on the trail of an overload train is a highlight that's hard to beat. (TCM has scheduled a second Friedkin tribute night, including "The Exorcist," for Nov. 26.)

title: Letter opposing Resolution 338 discussed during council meeting
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Letter opposing Resolution 338 discussed during council meeting

 June 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 300
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON – A letter by the town of Trappe and Trappe East Holdings Business Trust was sent to the Maryland Department of the Environment opposing Resolution 338, a resolution amending the Talbot County Comprehensive Water and Sewer Plan and requiring any future expansion of the new Lakeside wastewater treatment plant to be approved as an amendment to the comprehensive plan.Pete Lesher, vice president of the Talbot County Council, brought the 37-page letter to the council's attention and requested that it be discussed further on a future agenda.
Patrick Thomas, Talbot County attorney, said the letter asks that MDE disapprove of 338 or, at a minimum, delete the 100,000-gallons-per-day capacity limit and the requirement for a comprehensive water and sewer plan amendment for each expansion of the Lakeside facility.
This joint letter, undersigned by Lyndsey Ryan, representing the Town of Trappe, and Ryan Showalter, representing Trappe East Holdings Business Trappe, the owner and developer of the Lakeside community, describes Resolution 338's purpose as "intended by Talbot County to establish a County growth control mechanism specific to a single development project located entirely within the Town."
The Talbot County Council approved Resolution 338 and its amendment in April of this year.
Thomas said prior to the resolution's approval in April that if it is approved, it will go to the Maryland Department of the Environment, and the MDE will have the ability to either approve it, modify it or revise it.
During the June 5 meeting, Lesher stressed the importance of the council members' input. He proposed that the council should hold off on any action on this letter to allow time for a thorough review of the draft language.
He suggested waiting until council member Haythe could weigh in who was not in attendance at the meeting.
A date was not set for discussion of the letter.

title: Lions rally for first Bayside title; Caroline boys defend throne
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Lions rally for first Bayside title; Caroline boys defend throne

 May 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 838
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Queen Anne's County High's No. 3 girls doubles team of Sydney Pinder and Kara Ringold were down 4-1 when head coach Dee Fisher approached."I asked them, 'Hey, are you guys having fun?'" Fisher said. "And they were like, 'No. We're not.' I was like, 'You guys need to go out there and have fun and relax.' Just the things you can say to kids, and nothing tennis related, and it just made them relax."
Pinder and Ringold rallied to win, then watched Hayden Legg rally for a clinching victory at No. 3 singles Tuesday, May 7, helping Queen Anne's defeat Stephen Decatur, 4-3, at Washington College for its first Bayside Conference championship in girls tennis.
While the Lions were winning their first title, North Caroline's boys were winning a second straight conference crown, topping James M. Bennett, 4-3, to cap a perfect 15-0 season.
"We lost one match last season," Bulldogs second-year boys head coach James Donelan said. "It was their goal to go undefeated this year. And we were able to do that, which was huge.
We had a couple of close matches at the end of the season that just took some real grit to pull out and some real mental toughness from our boys," Donelan said of a 4-3 win at St. Michaels on April 24 and a 4-3 victory over Easton in the regular-season finale May 1. "It was really impressive to watch. Their growth and their ability to face adversity, face everybody coming at you, giving you their best every single night and just finding a way to win."
The Bulldogs did that again against the South champion Clippers.
North Caroline's No. 1 singles team of Josh Huster and Jesse Link defeated Cypress Schnatterly and Joe Chen, 9-7, while Ryan Canter and Hayden Kent beat Bennett's Daniel Ryu and Mason Layne, 8-4, in second doubles. But the Clippers avoided a double sweep, when Shafay Qaiser and Rishi Kandagatla earned an 8-5 win over Gavin O'Brien and Yossin Roblero-Velasquez at No. 3.
It remained close, as Bennett's Chen defeated Link, 8-5, at second singles, and Ryu outlasted Canter, 9-7 at No. 3. But Roblero-Velasquez rolled to an 8-1 victory over Landon Blumenthal at No. 4. Huster, who last year teamed with Rebecca White to win the Class 2A state mixed doubles title — North Caroline's first-ever state tennis title of any kind — clinched the victory against Bennett and the perfect record with an 8-3 victory over Schnatterly at No. 1.
"Going into this season, after the success that we had last year, we were definitely very confident," Donelan said. "We knew it wasn't going to be handed to us. We knew that everybody was going to be putting a target on our back, and that they knew we only graduated one senior and then all these boys were returning."
Unlike Donelan, Fisher entered the season thinking rebuild after graduating nine seniors from a year ago. Instead, the Lions went unbeaten in the North and 13-1 overall, with the lone loss coming against Decatur.
And while Queen Anne's drew a rematch with the Seahawks for the Bayside championship, Fisher didn't want his team deviating from its usual approach.
"Just treat it like a regular match and have fun," Fisher said to his team.
The Lions' No. 1 doubles team of Lucy Taylor and younger sister Meg Taylor lost 8-6 to Decatur's Ana Pena and Emily Ferguson. But Queen Anne's Hayden Legg and Marylee Kline beat Brooke Berquist and Kalli Nordstrom, 8-2, at No. 2, while Pinder and Ringold erased their 4-1 deficit en route to an 8-6 victory over Anika Karl and Emmie Weber at No. 3.
The Seahawks moved to a 3-2 lead, when Pena defeated Lucy Taylor, 8-2 at first singles, and Ferguson earned an 8-2 win over Meg Taylor at No. 2. Kline tied the match at 3-3 with her 8-6 win over Nordstrom at No. 4.
That left No. 3 singles, where Karl built a 4-1 lead on Legg. Again Fisher spoke with his player.
"I was like, 'Come on Hayden. You can play better,'" Fisher said. "'Focus. Take your time.' And basically she just started turning it around."
Legg did turn it around, rallying for an 8-6 title-clinching victory.
"I was like, 'It's going to be tough,'" Fisher said. "She's like the most chill person. She just kept coming back and coming back."
Yet after Legg had completed her comeback to seal the title, nobody from Queen Anne's stormed the court or hoisted their teammate onto their shoulders for a victory lap.
"Nobody got excited," Fisher said. "We just all like took it all in, like, 'Good job Hayden.'" Fisher said. "I think that's just the mentality of our team. We treat it like a regular match. We just do what we do.
"It felt even better because we lost to Decatur during the regular season," Fisher said. "Hey we fixed our wrongs, made some corrections and won it."
What Fisher wasn't expecting came next.
"They were like, 'Come here coach Fisher and take a picture,'" Fisher said. "And then they started spraying me with silly string. It was fun."

title: Tides of Grace raises a toast to a new community resource center
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Tides of Grace raises a toast to a new community resource center

 February 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 434
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — As a beacon of hope and a testament to the resilience of the community, Tides of Grace unveiled a ribbon cutting of its grand opening of its Community Resource center Feb. 6.Welcoming a center to celebrate special moments with the community, the new larger building is located at 207 C N. Liberty Street, and at 2,200 square feet, it has plenty of space to take in monthly donations and host community outreach events throughout the year.
More than serving just the low-income, when unexpected needs arise for anyone Tides of Grace volunteers and community support mobilize to make a difference and ensure no one faces hardship alone, Founder Leann Rhodes-Ickes said.
"The truth is we all experience these storms," she said, and tides of kindness, compassion and support can make a difference.
The 100% volunteer nonprofit serves nearly 400 community members in need every month.
Knowing firsthand the experience of hardship, Rhodes-Ickes shared heartfelt testimonies and her own personal journey growing up in a turbulent environment, and uncertainty, including family struggling with addiction.
"Hardships don't break us, they shape us," she said.
Rhodes-Ickes said she eventually grew faith through her struggles and overcame adversity, breaking generational curses to graduate college, get married, publish books and raise children.
The idea for Tides of Grace developed during Covid when clearing her son's unused toys free to those in need ended up sparking an entire community campaign.
Rhodes-Ickes realized there must be many more families in need throughout the area, and set to work connecting others with resources and building a repertoire of support and Tides of Grace was eventually born as a non-profit.
Understanding every family deserves hope and every child deserves warm home filled with love and protection, Tides of Grace seeks to be the no-questions-asked organization "that offers a helping hand to every single person who needs grace during their hard storms," she said.
"Everyone has a story," Rhodes-Ickes said, including the shared passion of the Tides of Grace volunteers and Board of Directors and encouraged everyone to utilize their own life experiences to support others.
More than a building, the new community resource center will allow Tides of Grace to unite the community, respond to crisis faster, serve more people and unite the community, Rhodes-Ickes said.
Tides of Grace is currently accepting formal attire donations for its Pop-up Prom Boutique in April.
Providing a wide selection of new and gently used dresses and suits as well as accessories and shoes, anyone in need of formal attire is welcome for a whole boutique experience.
More information about Tides of Grace, including upcoming events and to schedule the space for use can be found at: tidesofgraceinc.org.

title: Number of Cambridge homicides down in 2023
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Number of Cambridge homicides down in 2023

 January 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 743
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — There were less than half as many homicides in Cambridge in 2023 compared to the year before.In 2022, Cambridge saw seven homicides. In 2023, it saw three.
Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd, who was sworn in as chief in January of 2023, called the difference progress. He credits the decrease in homicides to a few different things — namely, how the department polices and its partnerships with other agencies.
One of the police department's top priorities last year was community-oriented policing. For Todd, that meant being a part of the community that the department services.
He said getting out into neighborhoods and creating programs like neighborhood watches can help build relationships and trust in communities and, hopefully, reduce crime.
Along with prioritizing community policing, Todd said that the department has tried to be proactive in addressing gun violence and aggressive assaults. He said CPD is now taking an average of one gun off the street each week, "well more than double" the average in 2022.
Todd also stressed the importance of working with other agencies and working with the community. He said that being a part of the Dorchester County Task Force, getting support from Cambridge City Council and focusing on community-oriented policing has all made a difference.
"I think a lot of people have come to the table in the last year," he said.
Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout said this decrease in the number of homicides in Cambridge is a significant one.
"Every shooting that we can stop is a step in the right direction," he said.
Rideout said he thinks CPD's community policing efforts are part of the reason for that success.
"It's just started, but I think they're building a trust within the community that just did not exist before now," he said.
Lieutenant Kyle Clark with Maryland State Police's Homicide Unit said that although he can't say for certain why the number of homicides has gone down in Cambridge, he can say that there has been a focus on collaboration between agencies.
"We do concentrate on a lot of collaborative efforts with other units within the State Police and also allied agencies," he said, specifying the use of task forces, gang units and gun units. "And those are all tools that we use to combat the crime in any city."
Clark said that he would estimate about 50% of the homicides in the last two years in Cambridge have been gang-related. He said that in addressing gang violence, MSP, along with other agencies at all levels, do "everything and anything" to combat the gang violence.
Todd said CPD is working to identify gang members and groups that are "constantly harassing" residents in different Cambridge neighborhoods. He said they have worked with the different agencies within the Dorchester County Task Force as well as federal agencies to identify who is bringing in handguns and where they are coming from.
"The partnership's been great with the Task Force and Maryland State Police," he said. "The Homicide Unit with Maryland State Police — they handle all of our homicides. So we work hand in hand together. And that's what it's going to take."
Todd said he has noticed gun violence and homicide rates begin to fall throughout the country.
Specific data on other crime rates in Cambridge should be released to the public in the next couple of weeks, Todd said.
Rideout said early intervention is important when it comes to crime prevention. Rideout was recently at a meeting about a flag football initiative by CPD and the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services.
"It was really an exciting possibility of where we can really start focusing, not only on the crime itself, but on the prevention and early intervention," he said.
Rideout added that engaging children in education and outside activities, such as programming at the YMCA or Boys and Girls Club, can have a positive effect.
Going into 2024, CPD's goals include continuing to build its manpower, focusing on data-driven technology and "patrolling with a purpose."
Todd said "patrolling with a purpose" means putting officers in the areas where crimes are occurring on the specific days and at the specific times they have been occurring.
He said that residents can also expect to see more data from CPD in the new year, including heat maps of where crimes are occurring.
Regarding homicides, Rideout said the downward trend is good, but added that the work doesn't stop here.
"What we have to do is continue working on it and engage the community in working on it to hopefully keep these numbers down," he said.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/July 1
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/July 1

 July 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 260
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On July 1, 1867, Canada became a self-governing dominion of Great Britain as the British North America Act took effect. Called Dominion Day until 1982, the national holiday is now known as Canada Day.Also on this date:
In 1863, the pivotal, three-day Civil War Battle of Gettysburg, resulting in a Union victory, began in Pennsylvania.
In 1903, the first Tour de France began. (It ended on July 19; the winner was Maurice Garin.)
In 1944, delegates from 44 countries began meeting at Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, where they agreed to establish the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
In 1963, the U.S. Post Office inaugurated its five-digit ZIP codes.
In 1973, the Drug Enforcement Administration was established.
In 1984, the first movie rated PG-13 ("Red Dawn," starring Patrick Swayze) debuted.
In 1991, President George H.W. Bush nominated federal appeals court judge Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court, beginning an ultimately successful confirmation process marked by allegations of sexual harassment.
In 1997, Hong Kong reverted to Chinese rule after 156 years as a British colony.
In 2004, actor Marlon Brando died in Los Angeles at age 80.
In 2015, after more than a half-century of hostility, the United States and Cuba declared they would reopen embassies in each other's capitals, marking a historic full restoration of diplomatic relations between the Cold War foes.
In 2018, LeBron James announced that he would be signing with the Los Angeles Lakers, leaving Cleveland for the second time in his career.
In 2019, 15-year-old Coco Gauff, the youngest player to qualify at Wimbledon in the professional era, defeated 39-year-old Venus Williams in the first round.

title: Rabid cat reported in Legion Road, Denton area
author: CAROLINE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT
content:
Rabid cat reported in Legion Road, Denton area

 December 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CAROLINE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT | Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 362
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Department of Health laboratory has confirmed a positive rabid cat in the Legion Road area of Denton. The cat was turned into the Humane Society, which then contacted the Caroline County Health Department's Environmental Health Division to facilitate rabies testing.Any person in the vicinity of Legion Road should avoid contact with wildlife, feral cats, unknown animals and any animal (including cats or dogs) that appears sick or to exhibit signs of rabies. Additionally, all residents in the area are urged to make sure their pets and mammal livestock are up to date on rabies vaccinations.
To report a potentially rabid animal, contact Animal Control at (410) 820-1600 or the non-emergency line of the 911 Center at (410) 479-2222.
Please contact the Caroline County Health Department immediately if you have had, or may know of anyone who might have had, any possible human or animal exposure to a rabid animal at (410) 479-8045.
If you have an emergency regarding a potential rabid animal or exposure and are calling after normal business hours or on the weekend, call (410) 829-5910.
An exposure can mean contamination of open wounds, abrasions, mucous membranes or scratches by potentially contaminated with infectious material from a rabid animal.
Additionally, any penetration of the skin by teeth constitutes a bite exposure. All bites, regardless of body site, represent a potential risk of rabies transmission, but that risk varies with the species of biting animal, the site of the bite and the severity of the wound.
Rabies is a serious, but preventable viral disease that attacks the nervous system. It is predominantly seen in raccoons, bats and skunks, as well as dogs and cats.
All wild or unknown animals must be avoided whenever possible since the possibility of exposure to rabies can occur anywhere and anytime.
Pet owners should remember that the best way to protect themselves, their families and their pets is to keep their animals up to date on rabies vaccination.
The Health Department regularly offers low-cost rabies clinics to help residents protect their pets. The next clinic will be held in the spring. Please monitor the Health Department's Events Calendar for more information.
For more information about rabies, visit CDC's Rabies Prevention webpage at cdc.gov/rabies/prevention/index.html.

 On Aug. 30, 1916, on his fourth attempt, explorer Ernest Shackelton successfully returned to Elephant Island in Antarctica to rescue 22 of his stranded crew members, who had survived on the barren island for four and a half months after the sinking of their ship, the Endurance.Also on this date:
In 1941, during World War II, German forces approaching Leningrad cut off the remaining rail line out of the city.
In 1945, U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur arrived in Japan to set up Allied occupation headquarters.
In 1963, the "Hot Line" communications link between Washington and Moscow went into operation.
In 1967, the Senate confirmed the appointment of Thurgood Marshall as the first Black justice on the U.S. Supreme Court.
In 2005, a day after Hurricane Katrina hit, floods covered 80 percent of New Orleans, looting continued to spread and rescuers in helicopters and boats picked up hundreds of stranded people.
In 2021, the United States completed its withdrawal from Afghanistan, ending America's longest war with the Taliban back in power, as Air Force transport planes carried a remaining contingent of troops from Kabul airport. After watching the last U.S. planes disappear into the sky over Afghanistan, Taliban fighters fired their guns into the air, celebrating victory after a 20-year insurgency.
In 2022, Mikhail Gorbachev, who was the last leader of the Soviet Union, and waged a losing battle to salvage a crumbling empire but produced extraordinary reforms that led to the end of the Cold War, died at age 91.

title: Bridge - Let's hear it for MMCCIV
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Let's hear it for MMCCIV

 January 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Robert Burns, in his poem "New Year's Day," wrote, "This day, Time winds th' exhausted chain;/To run the twelvemonth's length again." Since most people - but not bridge columnists!-get today off work, here is a difficult declarer-play problem. How should South plan the play in four spades?
West leads the club six, evidently a singleton.
South sensibly plunged into game. He did not know who could make what, so he tried for the big bonus.
Declarer won the first trick with dummy's club ace, unblocked the spade ace, ruffed a diamond in his hand and continued with the spade seven. However, West went in with the king and led a heart to his partner's ace.
East cashed the club king and then gave his partner a club ruff to defeat the contract.
"Boy, I should have stayed in bed this morning," grumbled South.
"You were a trifle unlucky," agreed North.
"A trifle!" exclaimed South.
"And West defended well," continued North. "But there is a technique worth trying when a ruff is threatened.
At trick two, lead a diamond honor from the dummy.
Let's assume East covers with the ace. You ruff, play a spade to dummy's ace and lead the second diamond honor from the dummy.
When East cannot cover, discard your heart king. The communication between the defenders has been cut, and West never gets his club ruff." "And if East plays low at trick two, I discard my heart king," said South. "Yes, of course. I should have thought of that." I wish all of my readers a healthy and successful 2024. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Mixed-use residential development planned in Easton
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Mixed-use residential development planned in Easton

 June 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 492
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Two mixed-use developments will be built on the former Perdue grain facility on Brookletts Avenue. These developments will provide affordable housing opportunities and commercial use for the town of Easton, developers said.The project's developers are Chesapeake Community Development, a subsidiary of The Arc focused on creating equitable, accessible and inclusive committees.
Jonathon Rondeau, president and CEO of The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, said the project will be a thriving neighborhood that will support the various housing needs of the community by offering quality affordable and market-rate rentals.
"When you look at a six-and-a-half-acre site, there's a real opportunity to think more broadly, but also to say, 'how do you really affect the community rather than just building something that's part of the community?'" Rondeau said. "But how can it be a foundation of the community?"
The Arc is a nonprofit organization with a mission to support people with intellectual and developmental disabilities.
About 15 years ago, The Arc decided to create housing opportunities for people with disabilities, which is how Chesapeake Community Development and Chesapeake Neighbors were created.
Though the focus was to establish affordable housing for people with disabilities, the need for affordable housing became so essential that the organization changed its mission to create affordable housing opportunities for all.
Rondeau said they manage about 70 units in Anne Arundel County and the Eastern Shore, including the Primrose and Port Streets Commons. The Arc's subsidiaries seek to create opportunities for people from disadvantaged backgrounds to access services.
Rondeau said mixing affordable and market-rate housing makes development financially viable by allowing subsidies for affordable units through market-rate rents.
He said though Talbot County has a high median income, there are a lot of families that live significantly below the average income. Rondeau said that there is a range of people who have a full time job but make less than $30,000 a year.
workers like baristas and education professionals are people who do important work in the community and should be given the access to live in the area as well, Rondeau said.
Ross Benincasa, a consulting partner and vice president of community development, said the need for affordable housing was great in the area.
"Our vision is to bring a vibrant multi-purpose space to the community that incorporates a wide range of amenities and resources, including much-needed housing," Benincasa said in a press release earlier this month.
Rondeau said they will be hosting a community meeting at the Brookletts Place Senior Center on July 10 at 5 p.m. to hear the concerns and ideas from the local community. He emphasized that community involvement is crucial to addressing any concerns and helping design a development that can meet the people's needs.
"We, The Arc and Chesapeake Neighbors and Chesapeake Community Development want to be part of the community and be part of making Easton an inclusive and equitable community," Rondeau said. "And projects like this allow us to do that, and we hope that the community can help be part of that."

title: Fall is for digging up sweet potatoes
author: Mabel Savage
content:
Fall is for digging up sweet potatoes

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mabel Savage | Page: A4 | Section: News 
 
 1514
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sweet potatoes are a classic fall favorite that requires a lot of work if you grow your own.We did back in the day on the farm. Each year there would be certain foods that were harvested for the coming winter months - white potatoes, turnips, corn and sweet potatoes.It took most of the family to help harvest these crops.A couple of days in advance, the baskets were prepared for digging day.The older brothers set aside the day to help my dad and the younger brothers.We cleaned and made space in the storage shed to place the sweet potatoes.They were sorted in baskets according to size. Usually digging day was on Saturday, when everyone was off work and out of school.A few days later, mom would wash some of the larger ones and cook them in large pots of boiling water until tender, then drain off water and cool enough to remove the skins and snip off ends.They were then placed in freezer bags and frozen for later use.Not only do sweet potatoes taste great they provide many health benefits.When eating sweet potatoes do not remove the skins, as they contain antioxidants including vitamin A and beta-carotene. They also have sporamin.Eating sweet potatoes is great to help manage your blood sugar levels, improve your immune system strength, improve your vision and help eliminate bacteria in the intestines.Let's get exploring some great sweet potato recipes.SWEET POTATO BISCUITS1 cup sweet potato cooked, mashed, and cooled,¼ cup granulated sugar, 1 large egg beaten, 1 tbsp butter melted, 1 cup milk, 3 cups self-rising flour, 1 tsp. baking powder, 1 tsp. ground cinnamon nutmeg,½ cup shortening.Start by combining sweet potato, sugar, egg and melted butter. Beat with a fork until smooth then stir in milk. Set mixture aside.Stir together self-rising flour, baking powder, cinnamon, and nutmeg in a large mixing bowl. Cut in shortening until it resembles coarse crumbs.Make a well in the center of the dry mixture. Add spiced sweet-potato mixture and stir just until combined. Turn out the biscuit mixture onto a well-floured surface. Knead gently for 10 to 12 strokes.Don't overdo it. Pat dough to about 1/2-inch thickness.Cut with a floured 2-1/2-inch biscuit cutter. Place biscuits 1 inch apart on a large baking sheet. Bake in a 400 degree F oven for 15 to 20 minutes or until the biscuits are lightly browned.SWEET POTATO FLUFF3 cups sweet potatoes cooked and mashed, 2 tablespoons butter, 1/4 cup orange juice, or milk, 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt, 1/3 cup marshmallow creme, or fluff, 1 large well beaten egg, 1 cup miniature marshmallows. Gather the ingredients. Preheat the oven to 400 F. Combine sweet potatoes, butter, orange juice or milk, salt, and 1/3 cup of marshmallow creme. Beat in egg. Pile sweet potatoes in a lightly buttered baking dish.Bake for 25 minutes. Top with miniature marshmallows and brown under broiler for about 4 minutes.CANDIED SWEET POTATOES4 to 5 large sweet potatoes, about 8 to 10 cups peeled and cubed, 2 tablespoons orange zest, from 1 orange, 1/4 cup orange juice, from 1 orange, 1 cup light brown sugar, packed, 1/4 cup honey, 4 tablespoons unsalted butter, 1/2 teaspoon vanilla, 1 1/2 teaspoons cinnamon, nutmeg. Gather the ingredients. Peel the sweet potatoes and cut them into 1-inch cubes. Lightly grease the slow cooker crock.Arrange the sweet potato cubes in the slow cooker.Use a zester or grater to get the zest from 1 orange, then squeeze the orange to get its juice. In a small bowl, combine the orange zest, orange juice, brown sugar, honey, butter, vanilla, cinnamon, and nutmeg. Heat the mixture in the microwave or on the stovetop in a saucepan.Stir to blend and pour the mixture over the sweet potato cubes. Cover and cook on LOW for 6 to 8 hours, until the sweet potatoes are tender.OLD FASHIONED BAKED SWEET POTATOES4 medium sweet potatoes, 1 tablespoon olive oil, 2 tablespoons butter, Kosher salt, Freshly ground black pepper, cinnamon sugar. Preheat the oven to 425 F. Line a baking pan with foil. Scrub sweet potatoes thoroughly, dry, and prick each one in several places with a fork to aerate. Rub oil all over each potato. Arrange potatoes on foil and bake for 35 to 45 minutes, or until they are fork tender. Cut a 1 1/2-inch "X" in the center of each baked sweet potato. Using a clean dish rag or potholder to protect your hands, hold a potato on each side and press upward until filling "bursts" up through cuts.Top with butter and sprinkle with salt and pepper. Season with paprika or a mixture of cinnamon and sugar. Wash and dry your sweet potatoes thoroughly. This will help the skin to crisp up well during baking.CROCK POT CARAMEL GLAZED SWEET POTATOES2 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more for buttering slow cooker4 to 6 medium sweet potatoes, about 2 1/2 to 3 pounds, peeled and sliced, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1 cup brown sugar, packed, 3 tablespoons cornstarch, 1 teaspoon cinnamon.Lightly butter the inner sides and bottom of the slow cooker. Add sliced sweet potatoes and sprinkle with salt. Combine sugar, cornstarch, and cinnamon in a small bowl; sprinkle over the sweet potatoes. Cut butter into small ¼ cubes and drop into the crock pot. Cover and cook on low for 7 to 9 hours.Here is a non-traditional recipe that my son John makes with sweet potatoes.ITALIAN SWEET POTATOES4 medium sweet potatoes, 1 tablespoon olive oil, 3/4 pound hot Italian sausage, 1 cup chopped red bell pepper, 1/2 cup chopped onion, 2 clove garlic minced, 1 1/2 teaspoons Italian seasoning, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1 cup Italian cheese blend, Italian parsley, chopped. Preheat the oven to 425 F. Line a rimmed baking sheet with aluminum foil. Scrub the sweet potatoes thoroughly, dry, and prick each one in several places with a fork to allow the steam to escape. Rub olive oil all over each potato. Arrange the potatoes on the foillined baking sheet and bake for 35 to 45 minutes, or until they are fork-tender. Meanwhile, heat a large skillet over medium heat. Crumble the sausage into the skillet and cook until the sausage begins to brown. Add the red pepper, onion, garlic, Italian seasoning, and salt to the skillet.Stir and cook until the vegetables are soft. Place the Italian sausage and vegetable mixture in a large bowl.Cut each baked sweet potato in half and scoop out most of the inside, leaving the potato skin shell fully intact. Add the scooped sweet potato to the bowl with the Italian sausage and vegetables. Stir to combine. Spoon the sweet potato and sausage mixture back into baked potato skins.Top with cheese and return to the oven for 5 minutes or until the cheese is browned on top and potato skins start to crisp. Top with parsley and serve.SWEET POTATO PIE2 cups Cooked Mashed Sweet Potatoes, 1.25 cups Granulated Sugar, 1/4 cup Butter, melted, 2 Eggs, 1 tsp Pure Vanilla Extract, 1/4 tsp Salt, 1/4 tsp Ground Cinnamon, 1/4 tsp Ground Ginger, 1 cup Evaporated Milk, 9" Frozen Pie Shell.Preheat the oven to 350°F.In a mixing bowl combine the sweet potatoes, sugar, melted butter, eggs, vanilla, salt, cinnamon and ginger.Mix together with a hand mixer until well combined.Add the evaporated milk and mix to combine. Add the pie filling mixture to the pie crust and place into the oven.Bake for 45 minutes or until done. Center of the pie should be set when done. Allow to cool before serving. Top with whipped cream, if desired.OVEN BAKED SWEET POTATO FRIES2 pounds orange fleshed sweet potatoes (about 3 large) 3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil, 1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt, 1 to 2 tablespoons spice or spice combination of your choice: chipotle powder, pumpkin pie spice. For more crispiness, preheat your oven to 500°F.Place a roasting pan or heavy duty baking sheet (one that can take high heat) in the oven to preheat.Peel the sweet potatoes and cut off the ends. Cut the potatoes in half lengthwise and then, if they are very long, in half crosswise. Cut each piece into 1/4 to 1/2-inch thick wedges. Alternatively, you can slice the peeled sweet potato into disks either with a mandoline or a sharp knife. Put the sweet potatoes into a large bowl and add the oil. Mix well to combine.Sprinkle them with salt and spices of your choice.Use your hands to mix well, so all pieces are coated with oil and spices. Remove the preheated baking sheet from the oven. Carefully spread the sweet potatoes out in a single layer on the baking sheet. Bake for 15 to 25 minutes. After the first 10 minutes, remove the baking sheet from the oven and use tongs to turn over all of the sweet potato pieces. Return to the oven and bake for another 5 to 15 minutes, or until they are well browned.Cooking time depends on the temperature of the oven (500°F will need less cooking time than 450°F) and the size and thinness of the sweet potato wedges. The browner they are, the crispier they will be, but there is a fine line between browned and burnt beyond edibility.Even if they get really dark, they should still be good because of the natural sugars of the sweet potatoes caramelizing. 
 
 Caption: METR O CREAT IVE SERVICES
 
Mabel Savage's oven baked sweet potato fries can be spiced a variety of different ways. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
