title: Museum creates immersive Harriet Tubman experience
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Museum creates immersive Harriet Tubman experience

 October 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 476
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Harriet Tubman Museum and Educational Center closed in May due to water damage. Since then, the museum has secured a grant that has allowed them to renovate the facility.Tuesday there was an open house for residents to see the progress and vision for the museum's reopening. Director of Programming and Events Linda Harris said the museum will be an immersive and interactive experience that follows Tubman's journey from slavery in Maryland to freedom in Pennsylvania.
The museum walls will depict different scenes of Tubman's life, integrated with lighting, sound, music and narrated walkthroughs to attract a young audience and evoke spirituality and community.
"I think it's something divine. Being connected to this story, marvelous things happen," Harris said. "We had a flood in May. Lots of water damage, and it took us until about three weeks ago to get the insurance company to pony up."
Though they received a check from the insurance company, it wasn't enough to cover the renovations. But as Harris said they received a large anonymous donation that made this dream come true.
Harris' daughter-in-law Erica Carson-Harris is an interior architect and is leading the museum's renovations. Artist Michael Rosato, who painted the "Walk With Me" mural — which can be found on the wall outside of the museum — is doing the paintings on the walls and floors.
"We're painting a path on the floor and certain areas lead to a certain part of the wall, that's gonna tell her story. So there will be a story of her standing out in the marsh, looking at the shooting stars having revelations, to a story about where she was enslaved, the cabin and the fields outside of that, to meeting Frederick Douglass, to leading the troops at the Combahee River, and then through the end in Philadelphia," Rosato said.
For Carson-Harris, she hopes the museum will create an emotional connection that provides knowledge about Tubman. Both Carson-Harris and Rosato want to encourage the public to come and visit during the renovations to see the work they're doing and if they feel called, to leave a donation.
"With Linda opening it up for people to see this, I encourage people to come and visit, as we're in the midst of this transition. You know, definitely just come out and look at the transition. Be a part of the journey as well," Carson-Harris said.
Harris plans to create the exhibit as a virtual reality experience where those who don't have the opportunity to see it in person, can experience it firsthand online.
There is still no projected date for the re-opening, but Carson-Harris is hopeful it could happen within six months. She encourages residents to donate to the museum that runs solely on donations.
"My mantra is find the Harriet in you," Harris said. "To all of us love, community, passion, resilience, courage. Embrace those things, and we got this." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Commissioner Roche brings up CWDI lawsuit, hopes city will withdraw it
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Commissioner Roche brings up CWDI lawsuit, hopes city will withdraw it

 May 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 700
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — As the open session of the Cambridge City Council meeting on May 13 came near a close, tensions rose.Minutes before entering closed session, Commissioner Brian Roche brought up the City Council's pending lawsuit against Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. The lawsuit, filed May 1 against CWDI, CWDI Holdings and Yacht Maintenance Company, alleges CWDI is in violation of a transfer agreement it entered into with the city in June 2021.
It seeks $75,000 in damages and requests temporary, preliminary and permanent injunctions stopping defendants from transferring any portion of the property in violation of the covenants of the 2021 transfer agreement with the city.
In the meeting, Roche said he hoped the city could withdraw the lawsuit because it could be jeopardizing a critical aspect of CWDI's Cambridge Harbor project, which is a project to develop the space along the Cambridge waterfront that includes a promenade, parks and a boutique hotel with a restaurant and bar.
Roche talked about the project plans for public spaces — including an expanded public promenade and tree park — and a working waterfront. He said that these parts of the project are things that the community has said it wants and that a lot of it can't or won't happen while the litigation is pending.
He said the $2.4 million grant from the U.S. Economic Development Administration to expand the promenade cannot be pursued because of the city's lawsuit.
"I understand the issues the city has with this development, and I'm not discounting them," Roche said, adding that his understanding is that the project should be looked at in two phases: one being the public parts of the project and two being the developable parts of the project.
According to a community update event CWDI hosted in April, the first phase of the project would include the creation of a boutique hotel, the expansion of Yacht Maintenance and a partnership with Richardson Maritime Museum. The second phase of the project would include the creation of residential units and retail spaces, seven acres of open public spaces and parking.
As Roche talked about the phases of the project, Atkiss interrupted to ask, "Do you want to have CWDI come and do a presentation on the calendar for this?"
Roche said he was sorry and his point is that there are two phases.
"If the city wanted to actually encumber and really come to the table, we could have waited until they —"
"We did ask them to come to the table," Atkiss said, cutting Roche off. "I was in that meeting. I know you have a different outcome from what happened at that meeting, but I was there. And we did come to the table and we did ask them to work with us."
Atkiss said CWDI did not work with them, and that is why the city is now in this position.
"Just to be perfectly clear," she said. "Because a lot of what you're staying is not really factual."
The lawsuit is one piece in a series of actions the city has taken regarding its concerns with the Cambridge Harbor project. In October, the city wrote a letter to CWDI expressing concerns with the project. On March 18, former City Manager Tom Carroll submitted his resignation and said he was resigning over concerns with the project. April 16, Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout held a meeting where he proposed amendments to CWDI's Articles of Incorporation.
Roche said that withdrawing the lawsuit could allow the city to "come back to the table" to see if the CWDI Board of Directors is willing to dive into "the real concerns" including tax increment financing, requests for proposals, the YMCA and other issues.
As Roche listed these concerns, Atkiss added a few to the list: "property transfer, covenants," she said.
Roche said another concern is whether the lawsuit could affect the search for the city's next city manager.
"Are we actually risking our possibility of attracting a good candidate with being subject to what could be a very prolonged and intractable legal situation?" he asked.
At the end of his comments, Roche said this was something he had to bring up and apologized to Atkiss for upsetting her. When Rideout gave Atkiss an opportunity to respond to Roche's comments, Atkiss said she would pass. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Black watermen’s monument proposed for Wells Cove
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Black watermen’s monument proposed for Wells Cove

 September 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 653
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Commissioners approved Wells Cove as the site for a proposed Black watermen's monument Aug. 26, further representing the history and legacy of the county's iconic industry.Tilghman Hemsley, a Queenstown artist and director of American Patriotic Monuments Inc., who created the original Kent Narrows watermen's monument 20 years ago, said he had been approached about the lack of Black representation in that project.
Seeking commissioner approval to establish the new monument on county property at Wells Cove, Hemsley presented mock-ups of the detailed sculptures.
Symbolizing the rich heritage of Black watermen, the monument will depict life-size bronze sculptures featuring a conversation between a head boat captain and an oyster boat worker, according to Hemsley. The piece will also feature other important aspects of the industry, including a man working with clams, a woman picking crabs, another cleaning fish, as well as a young boy with a fishing pole along for the experience.
"It's a sculpture that leans into the whole industry," Hemsley said.
"The piece is designed for the public to be able to come through and be part of the sculpture," he said.
With the history of the Black watermen engraved into the side of the pieces, "it's all about education," he said.
The monument is slated for a location between Bridges Restaurant and the Jetty restaurant. Hemsley emphasized the interactive nature of the work, allowing visitors the opportunity to pass between the pieces and engage with the sculptures as they visit the local area.
The watermen will be life-size bronze sculptures while the boat pieces will be stainless steel and powder-coated, he said.
Hemsley said the design of the pieces should make the monument low maintenance.
The project has already received approval from the Queen Anne's County Parks and Recreation Department and a letter of recommendation from the Kent Narrows Foundation, he said.
The commissioners unanimously approved Wells Cove as the site for the proposed monument. Commissioner Jim Moran noted he would have preferred a competition among artists to design a tribute to Black watermen but supported the plan.
Hemsley noted time is of the essence if the statue is to be ready by July 4, 2026, in celebration of the country's 250th anniversary.
Serving as director of the project, Hemsley said various other artists will be involved in the sculpture work. The proposed monument has an advisory committee that includes watermen, he said.
With commissioner approval, the next steps include seeking funding grants, according to Hemsley.
Although highly appreciated, just like the original watermen's monument, the project would not be solely dependent on county support, he said.
The total cost for the project is estimated at about $475,000. The previous watermen's monument cost about $300,000, he said.
Statues typically take about three years to complete, but Hemsley was confident as long as funding came through.
"It's aggressive, but we can do it," he said.
A fundraising event with auctions, games and music will be held at the Kent Island American Legion Nov. 8 starting at 7 p.m., he said.
Hemsley is also working with the Centreville Veterans Information Committee to create a life-size statue honoring the more than 400 Black soldiers of Queen Anne's County who fought for the Union during the Civil War.
Working with Chesapeake Charities, the veteran statue committee has been hard at work establishing itself as a nonprofit, according to John Wright, statue committee chair.
Wright credited the enthusiasm of the committee in working to establish a historic monument.
"I'm glad I am in a position to help," he said.
With the sculpture to be completed in stages, the committee foresees about a year and a half before a statue stands in front of the Kennard African American Cultural Heritage Center.
Donations can be sent to United States Colored Troops Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 42, Centreville, MD 21617.
As a Maryland nonprofit, American Patriotic Monuments Inc. seeks to lead public arts projects and monuments that celebrate American legacies.
More information, including sponsorship opportunities, can be found at apmiart.org.
Information about Hemsley's work can be found at tilghmanhemsleyfinearts.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland’s Hogan makes surprise entry into GOP race for US Senate
author: BRENNAN STEWART, YESENIA MONTENEGRO, TORRENCE BANKS, LISA WOELFL and ANGEL GINGRAS Capital News Service
content:
Maryland’s Hogan makes surprise entry into GOP race for US Senate

 February 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BRENNAN STEWART, YESENIA MONTENEGRO, TORRENCE BANKS, LISA WOELFL and ANGEL GINGRAS Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 788
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Former Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan will run for a seat in the U.S. Senate.Hogan, a Republican, announced his campaign on Friday via social media, releasing a video just nine hours before Maryland's candidacy deadline and surprising a lot of political observers.
"Fifty years ago, my father, Maryland congressman Larry Hogan Sr., made a very tough decision. He became the first Republican to come out for the impeachment of President Nixon," Hogan said. "He put aside party politics and his own personal considerations, and he stepped up to do the right thing for Maryland and the nation."
"Today, Washington is completely broken, because that kind of leadership, that kind of willingness to put country over party, has become far too rare," Hogan added.
Hogan joins the list of 20 candidates fighting for outgoing Sen. Ben Cardin's seat. Cardin, a Democrat, announced in May his plan to retire at the end of his current term.
Notable Senate candidates include Democrats Angela Alsobrooks, Prince George's County executive, and Rep. David Trone, as well as Republicans Robin Ficker, a former member of the Maryland House of Delegates and a perennial candidate for various offices, and John Teichert, a retired Air Force brigadier general.
"The beauty of living in this great republic that I fought to defend for over three decades is that we give Americans a choice about who represents us in elected public office," Teichert said in a statement released Friday. "Marylanders deserve to have a choice and I welcome anyone to the race who wants to offer them one."
If elected, Hogan would become Maryland's first Republican senator since Charles Mathias, who served in the Senate from 1969 to 1987.
"He's the only Republican in the state who stands a chance," Todd Eberly, associate professor of political science and public policy at St. Mary's College of Maryland, told Capital News Service.
"His chances depend on a couple of factors," said John Dedie, political science professor at the Community College of Baltimore County. "First, if the Trone, Alsobrooks primary gets contested with nastiness and they can't make peace after the primary… that could help Hogan because maybe one side stays home and doesn't vote."
According to Dedie, Hogan will have to focus on his accomplishments during his two terms as governor and his work with the Democrats. He may have to criticize Republicans, but then some of those voters may stay home, Dedie said.
Trone said in a statement that Hogan's bid is an attempt to boost the agenda of Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Kentucky) and former President Donald Trump.
"Larry Hogan's candidacy is nothing but a desperate attempt to return Mitch McConnell and Donald Trump to power and give them the deciding vote to ban abortion nationwide, suppress votes across the country, and give massive tax cuts to the wealthiest Americans," Trone said in a statement.
Hogan has always said that he is pro-life, according to Dedie. On this year's ballot, Maryland voters will see a "measure of basically codified abortion rights into the state constitution," which will affect Hogan's campaign, Dedie said.
Cardin believes that the Republican nominee for Senate will be in a tough battle against Democratic candidates Alsobrooks and Trone for the seat.
"Regardless of who is the Republican nominee, I am confident that Marylanders will keep our state in the blue column this November, holding the Senate as a bulwark against a dysfunctional and chaotic House of Representatives," Cardin said in a statement.
According to Bloomberg, McConnell recruited Hogan.
"This is the best one in the sense that we are now competitive in a state nobody thought we could win. He's a proven winner," McConnell told Bloomberg.
Maryland's primary election is May 14, giving Hogan just three months to campaign.
Sabato's Crystal Ball at the University of Virginia's Center for Politics slightly changed its rating for the Maryland Senate race after Hogan's announcement from "Safe Democratic" to "Likely Democratic," a reflection of the former governor's immediate impact on the contest.
In Annapolis, one Republican lawmaker said he wouldn't count Hogan out.
"I certainly believe that Governor Hogan feels that he has a path to victory, or else he would not get into the race," said State Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey (R-Caroline, Cecil, Kent and Queen Anne's ). "He certainly has a chance. He's proven that he can win in Maryland, on a statewide basis … He has found a way to map that out and believes that he can be successful."
But another fellow Republican asserted that running on the ticket with Trump would be no easy task for Hogan.
House Minority Leader Jason Buckel, R-Allegany, told CNS that Hogan's announcement took him by surprise.
"It's going to be an uphill climb," Buckel said. "He'll have to navigate being on the ticket with Donald Trump … and it will be a challenge for him."

title: Cambridge shares progress on Douglas Street houses
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge shares progress on Douglas Street houses

 March 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 592
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Those walking down Douglas Street this summer might see new homeowners sitting on spacious porches, looking out onto Cornish Park as kids run around and play.A city project to build four homes on Douglas Street in Cambridge's historic Pine Street neighborhood has been underway since September. Cambridge Housing Program Manager Ed Crosby said the city expects construction on all four houses to be complete by June 30.
These custom houses will be energy efficient and have features that make them feel like home, from oak staircases to crown molding.
"We wanted folks to take a sense of pride," Crosby said.
This project is one way the city is improving its housing stock, uplifting the community and fostering a culture where residents want to stay in Cambridge.
The houses on Douglas Street will be sold at 80% of area median income to people who qualify based on income and standards by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. Crosby said prospective buyers will have to complete homebuyer education training.
Three of the four homes getting built on Douglas Street will have three bedrooms. The fourth home will have four bedrooms and follow accessibility guidelines from the Americans with Disabilities Act, including having a ramp.
In all of the houses, features include electric fireplaces and washer and dryer units. Each house will have backyard space with a shed.
Crosby said the homes will be listed in the low $200,000s, with the most expensive home possibly reaching $250,000 in price. In February, the median selling price for homes in Cambridge was $276,000, according to Realtor.com.
On March 4, those working on the houses were putting up drywall. Gregory Beard, the general contractor for the project, said the next steps will be painting, putting in flooring, installing trim and bringing in subcontractors to install fixtures, hardware and plumbing.
"Things are coming together great," Beard said. "Fantastic build. It's a fun project."
Crosby hopes the city will have the property listed online this month.
"There's an excitement brewing that we're just ready to move forward with this," he said.
Although the properties could be purchased by people who don't live in Cambridge, Crosby said the city has made an "intentional effort" to market the homes to city residents before listing them. He said there are at least 30 Cambridge residents who have shown interest in the homes and have applied to buy one.
In late February, the city gave tours to show the construction progress to the Cambridge City Council and the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development. Crosby said the tours gave attendees an opportunity to learn more about the project from the developer, architect, engineers and contractors.
During the tours, some commissioners gave the city ideas on how to ensure the homes are not flipped or purchased by landlords to turn into rentals, Crosby said.
"You can actually write that into the deed where there's a requirement that the city could get what is called the right of first sale," he said. "So if it comes to a point and the homeowner's interested in selling, the city would have the opportunity to actually purchase the property back and then keep it under that 80% of AMI program so that we can continue to have it available as affordable housing."
After the city finishes building the Douglas Street houses, it plans to build at least 10 more homes on Chesapeake Court and School House Lane. Crosby said this project will help inform the city on how to go about building more houses.
"And from this blueprint, we'll learn how the next set of homes will be," he said.

title: Easton man receives 18 years for sex assault of daughter, other crimes
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton man receives 18 years for sex assault of daughter, other crimes

 July 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 660
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — An Easton man received an 18-year sentence on Thursday for third-degree sex offense against his then-3-year-old daughter, among other offenses.Kevin Manning, 34, appeared in court to hear his fate after entering a guilty plea for the felony sex offense and nine other counts, including witness intimidation, electronic communication harassment and violation of a protective order. Those nine counts were levied for actions he took against his daughter's mother after the Sept. 2024 assault of the daughter.
Talbot County Circuit Court Judge Phil Cronan handed down the 18-year sentence — a term exceeding the recommended five- to 13-year range — for what he called a "vicious and heinous" crime.
Before Cronan delivered the sentence, Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel asked the court for a 30-year sentence.
Endzel cited Manning's past sex assault convictions: a fourth-degree sex offense in Anne Arundel County in 2016 and second-degree rape in Talbot County in 2022 stemming from a 2009 incident involving Manning and an underage female living with him at the time.
The rape conviction was dismissed in 2023 after it was determined that the judge who postponed Manning's trial date was not designated to do so.
Endzel argued for the extended sentence, in part, due to Manning's "repeated harassment" of the child's mother, Emily Hiester, beginning last September. Endzel wrote in a memo to the court that Manning contacted Hiester nearly 200 times through emails and phone calls, violating a protective order.
Endzel read a written impact statement from Hiester, in which the mother said she couldn't bear to be in a courtroom with Manning. Hiester wrote that she has secluded herself from others and that she "can see the pain" in her daughter's eyes.
"I can't see others the same when someone I thought I knew I could trust did something so horrible," a portion of the statement read.
Hiester asked for Manning's sentence to be "as much time as the court will allow."
Endzel also argued that an open District Court case in which Manning is accused of assaulting an inmate at the Talbot County Detention Center factors into the danger he poses to society. The alleged assault occurred May 24.
"The question is not whether he will reoffend, but when," Endzel said.
Manning's defense attorney, Holly Brownley of the public defender's office, asked Cronan to deliver a sentence within the pre-sentence recommendations.
Manning "had some serious traumas in his young life," such as the murder of his mother and being exposed to drug and substance abuse, Brownley said.
The 34-year-old defendant, in an orange suit, handcuffs and wide black glasses, spoke for a few minutes at the hearing Thursday. He said he wants to go to a maximum-security prison, Patuxent Institution in Jessup, to receive treatment.
Manning acknowledged his daughter was the victim and said what occurred was an accident. He disagreed with Endzel's claims that he has shown no remorse.
"To ostracize me from society, I don't believe's appropriate," Manning said, noting that since 2019, he doesn't feel he's been a "trouble or menace" to society.
Cronan disagreed with that assessment.
The judge said Manning's behavior has escalated the last 15 years. The dismissed rape conviction is "certainly something ... in this court's mind," Cronan said. He added that the sex offense conviction and a related burglary crime from 2016 as well as the pending assault case from two months ago played a role.
"That doesn't sound to me that you haven't been any trouble," Cronan told Manning. "Quite the opposite."
The judge said the facts of the case were clear: Manning assaulted his daughter and "manipulated the mother of your child" to try to get her to lie in court for him.
Cronan said the daughter "should have the comfort" to be with her father without such a thing happening.
In addition to the 18 years, Manning is ordered to be on probation for five years after his release, make no contact with Hiester or the daughter and not visit their residences, schools, places of employment or daycares. He will register as a Tier III sex offender.

title: Adkins Arboretum hosts plein air painters
author: Tom McCall
content:
Adkins Arboretum hosts plein air painters

 November 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Arts 
 
 417
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — The smell of linseed oil wafted into the forest as over 50 artists competed in Plein Air Adkins at the Adkins Arboretum on Saturday. There was food and drink, nature and art all combining to create a perfect fall day."We had almost 250 attendees and 55 artists," said Ginna Tiernan, executive director of Adkins Arboretum.
There was lots of food and drink.
"Ten Eyck provided mimosas and bloody Marys, and Craft Bakery and Night Kitchen provided great food and drinks including pastries and lunch items," Tiernan said. "Diane Mullaly got us started and is our advisor on this event, and she won first prize," she said.
Mullaly learned a lot about running a Plein Air quick contest from her time at the Plein Air Easton.
"I brought Ginna the idea about four years ago about creating an event like this. I created sort of a slower version of the quick draw. The painters started at 10 and ended at 12:30. A half hour longer than Plein Air Easton. Quite a few sold," Mullaly said.
For Mullaly the passion goes deeper than her creativity.
"I am deeply involved with the arboretum. I am a Maryland master naturalist and a trained docent there. I am there a lot and I just adore that place. I always feel so good when I am there. It is very healing and relaxing. Being able to paint there in that beautiful environment is such a treat," Mullaly said.
Beth Bathe was the judge and was generous with her time with all artists.
Bathe said, "Judging the works of over 50 artists this past Saturday at Adkins Aboretum was a true honor as each painting vividly showcased the rich colors and textures of the autumn season. Live music, wonderful food and drink and beautiful artwork all for sale made a great day for the artists and the community."
There were collectors who have also attended the Plein Air Easton event. They came to see and purchase more great art.
The winners were Mullaly, second place winner Abby Ober and third place winner Maryellyn Lynott.
There were honorable mentions too. These included Lori Yates, Lynn Lewis, Ronaldo Dorado, Stephen Walker and Sheryl Southwick.
There was a tie for Artist's Choice — Nancy Fine and Toni Wolf.
Event Sponsors included Caroline County Council for the Arts, Maryland State Arts Council, Enel and Unity Landscape Design/Build. Live music was provided by Fine Times.
Although the Arboretum got a 20% commission of any art that sold, the main benefit was attracting lots of people to spend time in nature.

title: MDOT talks investments in Talbot County
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
MDOT talks investments in Talbot County

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 784
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - State, county and local officials packed the meeting room at the Talbot County Free Library Tuesday afternoon to hear the latest updates on the Maryland Department of Transportation's investments in county projects.The visit to Talbot County capped off another leg of the department's statewide tour discussing its sixyear Draft FY 2024-2029 Consolidated Transportation Program - a $21.2 billion investment into creating a safer, more accessible transportation system.The meeting, hosted by the Talbot County Council, featured Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul J. Wiedefeld and representatives from various state agencies.State Highway Administrator William Pines spoke about his agency's efforts to improve infrastructure and safety at several high-traffic locations within Talbot County.The agency initiated a $1.5 million study of Route 328 to assess safety and capacity improvements along a 1.6-mile stretch between U.S. Route 50 and Black Dog Alley. Delays are seen in this area from turning vehicles and queueing at signalized intersections, and there are limited pedestrian and bicycle facilities, Pines said.A public meeting on the Route 328 project is tentatively scheduled for this winter.Other transportation improvements within Easton include a $600,000 project for new lighting at the intersection of Route 50 and Route 322 (Easton Bypass) to improve visibility and safety, signal improvements and pedestrian upgrades - including a Rails to Trails link - at Route 322 and Glenwood Avenue, and a new signal at Route 50 and Chapel Road that will be activated by the end of November.In 2024, SHA will begin construction on two additional projects: reconstructing the signal at Route 50 and Route 309 and upgrading the flashing signal at Route 331 and Black Dog Alley to a full signal.Two local trail projects are also receiving federal and state grant funding, Pines said.$48,000 will go toward the final design of a 1.25-mile extension of the St. Michaels Nature and Bike Trail, and $30,000 will go toward the study and preliminary design of a rail trail connecting parks in Oxford.Turning to public transit, nearly $1.1 million in operating and capital grants are being allocated to support Delmarva Community Transit.$225,000 of this will fund preventative maintenance and two new small buses, said Travis Johnston, the Maryland Transit Administration's local transit support director.Delmarva Community Services will also receive $123,000 to install a propane filling station for future propane-powered vehicles, enabling DCS to transition to a low-emission fleet.Additionally, $24,000 in highway safety grants were awarded to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and the Easton Police Department.Turning to the skies, the Easton Airport's runway improvement program is receiving $525,000 from the Maryland Aviation Administration to support the initial phase of construction.THINKING DOWN THE ROADLocal officials also weighed in on a number of priorities and problem areas they hope the transportation agency will address in the future.Discussions on traffic surrounding the proposed new regional medical center site off of Route 50 were top priorities for state legislators, the county and the Town of Easton. Rick Van Emburgh, Easton's town engineer, said he wanted to work with the county and the state on a regional traffic plan to handle the impact on local roads and infrastructure.Cheryl Lewis, Oxford's town manager, raised questions on the agency's response to flooding on the causeway and pedestrian safety in a town with few sidewalks.Queen Anne Mayor Philip Starkey asked if the agency would reevaluate fixing the bridge between the towns of Queen Anne and Hillsboro, which floods every time it rains, he said.Accessibility was raised as an issue in St. Michaels. According to Town Administrator Rob Straebel, all but one of the town's ADA ramps are not in compliance due to poor work from a contractor."I'm not sure what the way forward is, and I'm not here to point fingers or to blame anyone or to place culpability on anyone," he said. "But there really needs to be a sense of urgency to get this project rectified as soon as possible before our tourist season starts in the summer of 2024." Pines said the state was working to develop an "aggressive schedule" to get the project over the finish line.Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-37) further emphasized the need to fix the ramps, noting that Route 33, as the main road running through St. Michaels, doesn't just serve town residents, but residents of Claiborne, McDaniel, Sherwood and Tilghman.Several Royal Oak residents in attendance also raised concerns about the width and safety of Route 329 (Royal Oak Road), asking the transportation officials to lower the speed limit."I wish I could do everything that everyone asked immediately, but we will keep chipping away," Wiedefeld said, closing out the meeting. 
 
 Caption: NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
State transportation officials take turns sharing updates from their respective agencies on Talbot County projects during a meeting Tuesday, Nov. 7.

title: Four World War II chaplains honored at American Legion
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Four World War II chaplains honored at American Legion

 February 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 349
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — There was reverence and patriotism ringing across a room full of veterans at American Legion Post 70 Sunday as the group gathered to honor four chaplains who gave the ultimate sacrifice.The program, held annually by the American Legion, marks the anniversary of the Feb. 3, 1943, sinking of the U.S.A.T. Dorchester. The ship was torpedoed by a German U-boat shortly after midnight, just 90 miles short of its destination.
Aboard were four chaplains, George L. Fox, Alexander D. Goode, Clark V. Poling and John P. Washington, who gave up their life jackets to save the lives of four servicemen.
"They didn't have life jackets when they went down with the ship," American Legion Post Cmdr. Wayne Hall said to those gathered Sunday. "The story goes that they were all holding hands and singing hymns when the ship went down."
During the service, the four chaplains were represented by local religious leaders — Rabbi Peter Hyman of Temple B'nai Israel, the Rev. Jonathon Moyers of Grace Lutheran, the Rev. Gary L. Moore of the Trappe Faith Chapel United Methodist Church and the Rev. Michael Angeloni of Sts. Peter and Paul Catholic Church.
The JROTC from Easton High School presented the colors.
After the color guard cleared, the four religious leaders took turns coming to a lectern up in front of the room. They told narratives that fleshed out the four men who gave their lives on that ship.
After they were finished, a citation from U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Maryland) was presented to Post 77 and Post 70 for honoring the four chaplains.
"It is an important way for the community and society to make sure that the veterans know that their sacrifice and their effort has been appreciated," said local veteran and community liaison for Rep. Andy Haris Mike Detmer, who served in Falluhah during the Iraq War.
"I do a lot of invocations and benedictions at services," said Paula Grimes, Department of Maryland chaplain for the American Legion. "It is from the heart. It is important to spread the word of the sacrifice about these four gentlemen. Everyone should know the story."

title: Sending Shelly home
author: Staff Writer
content:
Sending Shelly home

 May 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 657
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chestertown to Tilghman Island can be a long drive, especially if you're riding the whole way in a plastic box with air holes punched in the top.But for a special diamondback terrapin, the school bus trip was a one-way ride home.
For the past year, Shelly has lived in an aquarium at Kent County Middle School in Chestertown as part of a research program.
Recently, middle school teachers Samantha Cawthorne and Roberto-Luis Copeland; Shelly, who rode in the aforementioned plastic box; and a group of sixth-graders traveled to Tilghman Island in Talbot County.
From there, they caught a boat to Poplar Island, where Shelly originally came from. Shelly was part of the Terrapin Program through Maryland Environmental Service, the agency heading up the Paul S. Sarbanes Ecosystem Restoration Project at Poplar Island.
As part of the research program, Shelly spent her first year growing from a tiny hatchling to a young terrapin at Kent County Middle School before being release back on Poplar Island.
For Copeland, this was his first time raising a terrapin, an experience he described as "amazing."
"Not only was it truly great for the students to learn more about terrapin ecology and physiology, it was also a good opportunity for students to learn about the environmental impacts we as humans impose on literally our backyard, the Chesapeake Bay," Copeland said.
Cawthorne said she loved every minute helping raise Shelly and was very thankful for the experience.
"Seeing the look of awe and excitement in the students' faces whenever Shelly made her way to my classroom was nothing short of wonderful. The students learned so much about terrapins and we were very sad to see her go," Cawthorne said.
For more than a decade, the State of Maryland has been rebuilding Poplar Island.
In its day, there were families that called Polar Island home. It also hosted a getaway used by the most powerful people in Washington, D.C., including U.S. presidents like Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Harry Truman.
The waters of the Chesapeake eroded Poplar Island so much so that by 2000, it was predicted the entire island would soon be washed away.
The Poplar Island restoration site is still under construction. While no people live on the island, many species of wildlife now call it home — or at least a stop on their migratory route.
Scientists led by biologist Willem Roosenburg at Ohio University are conducting a study of terrapins on Poplar Island. They locate nests and count and measure eggs.
"A lack of land predators, undisturbed sandy shorelines, and a variety of habitat types make Poplar an ideal terrapin nesting site," the Terrapin Program website states.
With around 800 diamondback terrapins — the state reptile of Maryland — hatching annually on Poplar Island, the researchers collect about 150 eggs each year and give the juveniles to schools raise.
This "head start" program aims to determine if this level of human involvement in terrapins' early stages of life gives them a better chance in the long run of surviving in the nature world, according to the Terrapin Program site.
It also gives students the opportunity to more personally engage with the Bay's ecosystem.
"Through this program, students are playing an important role in relevant, cutting-edge research focused on the conservation of the species," the Terrapin Program site states. "The combination of scientific applications, hands-on involvement and the emotional attachment to the terrapins provides a unique opportunity to inspire a meaningful connection with the Chesapeake Bay."
Through releasing Shelly back into the wild, Cawthorne and Copeland both said they hope the middle school students learned that any action they take, no matter how large or small, can have a huge impact on the health of the Bay.
The field trip was funded in part by the Kent County Public Schools Education Foundation Fund.
Part of Mid-Shore Community Foundation, the education foundation fund helps cover the costs of extended field trips, provides mini-grants to teachers and more.
For details about the Kent County Public Schools Education Foundation Fund, or to make a donation, visit www.kent.k12.md.us/Foundation.aspx.

title: Hope is a powerful force in our communities
author: STEPHEN RIDEOUT
content:
Hope is a powerful force in our communities

 February 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPHEN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 657
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gov. Wes Moore came to Cambridge on Monday, Feb. 12, to speak about the ENOUGH Act that he has proposed. I had the opportunity to speak briefly prior to his comments and thought that I would share them with you here. Please see the relevant portion of them below.When I was asked to say something at this event, I decided to focus on the words "enough" and "hope." Enough is the acronym for this important and needed legislation that the governor has proposed. It has somewhat different meanings that, I think, are relevant to this legislation.
It can mean "as much or many of something as required" as in "you need to get enough of the right things to eat," and it can also mean that you are "unwilling to tolerate anything more of something that is undesirable" such as poverty or bad behavior. Both definitions are applicable to this legislation. We have not done the job that we could do to address systemically the challenges that the ENOUGH Act seeks to address.
While I understand that the legislation primarily focuses on the funding of the initiative and how the government must implement it, I know that the Moore-Miller Administration is also thinking about the communities the legislation is intended to serve and the need for people within the community to do much of the hard work. So local training, local collaboration in implementing this legislation, more effective local utilization of resources and the opportunity to lift up all of Maryland and its people are areas of focus.
This past summer I was able to attend the installation ceremony for Judge Gayle Carr as president of the National Council of Juvenile and Family Court Judges. I know Judge Carr from my time on the juvenile court bench in Virginia. The main focus of her speech was about "hope" and how it impacts children and families as well as all of the judges, child welfare workers, teachers, juvenile justice staff and others working with them.
I see these goals in the governor's proposed legislation. I see this legislation as the cornerstone of the kind of change that I have hoped to see since moving to Maryland almost 14 years ago. What I hope to see in supplementary laws or administrative requirements implemented by the Governor's Office for Children are the things that I think will give children, their families and communities the "Hope" that Judge Carr talked about in her speech.
She said:
"What are we without hope? Who here among us has not achieved without having hope? Why should it be any different for the children, youth, adults, and families we serve?
"The hope I speak of propels us to keep striving; to get up again when we fall. Hope is not wishful thinking but confident expectations.
"Research and science have proven Hope changes outcomes. Hope produces positive results. It changes the trajectory particularly for our children, our most vulnerable children — the ones we are responsible for in our work."
She concluded with these words. "You are optimistic if you think the future will be better than the past. You are hopeful if you believe the future will be better than the past, and you believe you have a role in making it so."
The hope that Judge Carr talked about is also needed by all of those people she mentioned who work with children and families. Just as the children and families need hope so do those who are working locally to help them. I have seen in my past work as a judge and consultant on child welfare what hope can do for a community, and it is a powerful force. I see Judge Carr's reference to hope as meaning "Help Out People Everywhere."
Gov. Moore, thank you for your leadership and your vision and for placing this first cornerstone for what will change Maryland for a better future for everyone. I look forward to helping however I can.
Stephen Rideout is mayor of Cambridge. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Americans must speak out
author: Staff Writer
content:
Americans must speak out

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last Saturday night, the Trump regime used ICE to illegally detain Mahmoud Khalil (a green card holder) without warrant or charge, to try to arrest his pregnant wife and to kidnap Khalil to an undisclosed location it refused to share with his family. This illegal, terrorizing behavior would be expected from a dictatorship but not from our government.Any doubt as to the in terrorem role ICE would serve for the Trump regime is quickly vanishing. ICE is for Trump what the Gestapo was for Hitler, a force to stifle opposition with threats, force and torture.
Khalil has no criminal record. All he did was to exercise his Constitutional rights by organizing peaceful protests at Columbia that opposed continued funding for Netanyahu as Netanyahu committed well-documented war crimes against Palestinians.
When confronted, ICE first claimed Khalil's visa was being revoked but, when informed that he has a green card, changed its story to state his green card was being revoked. However, the decision to revoke a green card can only be made by an immigration judge after the government procures a warrant, makes a legal arrest, files charges, tries the person, convicts the person and allows that person to exhaust all appeals.
Instead of allowing the due process our Constitution affords every person – citizen or not – the Trump regime executed an autocratic move to stifle dissent and disappear a dissenter that resembles the manner in which Putin deals with dissenters in Russia. This amounts to government terrorism and follows the Trump regime's open repression of student activism and political speech, in this instance criticism of Israel and Netanyahu. Thus, the Trump regime has shown it will use immigration to suppress free speech.
If Columbia secretly colluded with the Trump regime in the arrest, it may be a result of the regime's recent cancellation of $400 million in grants and contracts. Trump proved that he is willing to use extortion to achieve personal goals when threatened to withhold funding to force Ukraine to announce an investigation of Biden, so it is not surprising that Trump would use extortion to force colleges to kowtow to his wishes to silence dissent by wrongfully withholding the funds they are entitled to receive, but it is chilling.
Americans must speak out against this brutal and illegal conduct.
JACK L. WUERKER
Tilghman

title: Adkins Arboretum plans to add Woodhenge
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Adkins Arboretum plans to add Woodhenge

 July 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 493
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGLEY — Vicco Von Voss is working with Adkins Arboretum to erect "Woodhedge."A local woodworker and artist, Voss said the idea of a Woodhenge, an art installation modeled after Scotland's famous Stonehenge, came from the emotions of his work.
"I'm a woodworker, and part of what we do is we salvage local trees that have been diseased or fallen," Voss said. "We have a mill here, and we cut these trees open. I've noticed that when my sawyer, he's cutting a tree, and the tree is really beautiful, everybody feels really good. Then when we get to a tree where the tree is kind of diseased and rotten, the mood kind of changes.
"I said to my sawyer, I said, 'Isn't that interesting when you have a tree that is all good and healthy and beautiful, your energy is good and positive. When you get a tree that's all diseased and rotten inside, you might be blaming it on something.' Isn't it interesting that you're exposing the energy of the tree and you're really receiving what is happening within the tree."
Voss hopes Woodhenge will make visitors think and feel emotions and energy from the tree.
According to Abby Lorenz, director of public engagement for Adkins Arboretum, conversations with Voss went on a for long time, but the energy shifted on the project after receiving a grant in July.
"More recently the energy and movement around this project is through a Public Arts Planning Grant with Maryland State Arts Council," Lorenz said. "He received a grant funding to focus on the planning of the installation, so right now we have created a survey for people to give feedback on what they think on the project. So I think that's a big part of what we're looking for because this is not just art for artists, it's public art."
The next step for Woodhenge is applying for a second grant for $30,000 in the fall to begin construction, but according to Voss, they will need to do some fundraising to complete the $75,000 project.
Lorenz said the focus right now is informing the community about the project and getting their thoughts and ideas.
"We just recently had a community meeting where we invited people that had knowledge of Stonehenge and cultural landscapes to come together and give their feedback and ideas, and Vico shared his plan and intention of really opening one tree so that you feel like you're inside of one tree," Lorenz said.
At the feedback meeting, residents shared on how they felt visiting Stonehenge and how that same feeling and cultural significance can be conveyed in a tree landscape.
"I think there's excitement, there's intrigue and in a way that people are interested in really what does it mean," Lorenz said.
While there is no set timeline for the project, Lorenz and Voss believe Woodhenge will be built and open to the public in 2026 or 2027.
Woodhenge would sit on Nancy's Meadow on the north side of the Adkins Arboretum property. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Warriors rally to edge Bucs
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Warriors rally to edge Bucs

 September 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Jordan Horsey had a question for his teammates at halftime."I just told the guys, 'How bad do you not want to lose this game,'" Easton High's junior football standout inquired.
A little over an hour later, Horsey had his answer.
Horsey scored all three Easton touchdowns, including a game-tying 1-yard dive into the end zone with 1 minute, 28 seconds remaining, then watched Luke Stanco drill the point-after kick Friday night, lifting the Warriors' to a 21-20 come-from-behind victory over Kent Island.
"The boys played hard," Easton head coach Matt Griffith said after his team improved to 3-0. "They didn't quit. That's the biggest thing I'm proud of. They're dogs."
After a scoreless first quarter, Kent Island (1-2) took a 3-0 lead on Spencer Chappell's 44-yard field goal with 7:06 left in the first half. The Buccaneers stretched that lead to 10-0, when running back Jaxson Hess caught a short pass from quarterback Trace Klapaska and broke a handful of tackles en route to a 52-yard touchdown 32 seconds before intermission. Chappell added the extra point.
"The speed of the game was really fast, especially for our quarterback and our offensive line," said Griffith, who watched quarterback Brady Walls battle pressure for most of the first half. "They've got a great defense. They play fast, they play hard.
"Tim had a great game plan," Griffith added of Kent Island head coach Tim Goodrich. "We've played each other so many times. He's got a lot of defenses you practice for. So even what they were doing we practice. But you can't simulate how hard and how fast they play. They gave us a helluva time in the first half."
Kent Island put the Warriors in a deeper hole with just under 8 minutes left in the third quarter, when fullback Alex Brestensky busted loose for an 87-yard touchdown jaunt that — together with another Chappell PAT — made it 17-0.
Easton answered.
Three Jamier Copper carries netted 26 yards. Horsey ran for 8 and 5 yards. Walls then connected with Kyree Acree for a 37-yard gain, setting up the first of Horsey's three TD runs, a 3-yard run up the middle. Stanco's first PAT made it 17-7 with 5:33 left in the third quarter.
The Bucs widened their lead to 20-7 with 1:26 to go in the third on Chappell's 42-yard field goal.
Kent Island maintained that 13-point cushion, when Easton took over from its own 20 with 7:13 left in the game. Walls hit Zach Barnhart for a 42-yard pickup, completed a 12-yard gain to Carter Mooney, then found Barnhart for a 21-yard to the 1. Horsey capped the drive, slamming in from the 1. Stanco's second PAT made it 20-14 with 6:03 to go.
Easton forced a three-and-out and took possession at its 30 with 4:23 remaining. A 9-yard completion from Walls to Barnhart coupled with a roughing-the-passer penalty on Kent Island, moved the Warriors to Kent Island's 40.
On third-and-10, Walls dumped a short pass to Horsey for a 22-yard pickup. A Walls-to-Mooney connection pushed Easton to the Bucs' 6. Horsey carried for gains of 2 and 3 yards, before launching himself over the goal line from 1 to tie the game at 20-20 with 1:28 left.
"I felt like (NFL Hall of Fame running back) Emmitt Smith jumping over the pile," Horsey said of his tying touchdown.
On came Stanco to convert his third PAT of the game for a 21-20 lead.
"After I made the first (point-after) kick, got the nervousness out," Stanco said. "Then I made the second and we got close. And then the game was on me; game was on the line. I had to put it through the uprights and I did."
"I was nervous for him," Griffith said of Stanco. "We've struggled on our special teams this year. It was an emphasis this week that specials had to be perfect and we were pretty good tonight. That was big. He (Stanco) has a great leg. He's very talented. And so does Kai Ferraris. Both of them, very talented. They just need more reps and it's hard when they're soccer players."
Kent Island's Andy Bennett returned the ensuing kickoff 10 yards before slipping at the 25. Four incompletions later, Easton took over, with Walls taking a knee twice to complete one of the bigger come-from-behind wins over Griffith's career as head coach.
"Second half I think we wore them down a little bit and we hit some big plays," Griffith said. "And that was the difference."

title: Color run brightens rainy day in Kent County
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Color run brightens rainy day in Kent County

 September 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 345
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Painted sneakers and damp, smiling faces could be spotted on Sunday morning down South Cross Street. The rain did nothing to stop walkers and runners of all ages from participating in the 2025 5K Color Fun Run/Walk, benefiting Kent Goes Purple.Kent Goes Purple is a substance abuse awareness and prevention initiative of the Kent County Sheriff's Office and Chestertown Rotary Club, engaging the community and youth to stand up against substance abuse.
Now into its seventh year, the race began bright and early at Wilmer Park, extended down South Cross Street, turned at John Brown Road then returned to the park for a finish.
It kicked off with purple foam bubbles shooting courtesy of Willy Woo Woo Productions and a burst of blue paint at the finish line coating everybody. People scattered playfully away, ducking under the police tape heading for the road.
Along the route, participants, if they asked for it, were doused in more paint by over-eager students. Roadside, the Chestertown Elks Club provided water and encouragement. Police did a great job ensuring participants were safe from traffic as mothers walked their children in strollers, friends ran beside each other and dads jogged with their daughters.
After the race, the Purple Jamboree was held at the park. Kids danced and played in the foam machine of Willy Woo Woo, who provided some sports games, popcorn, cotton candy and snow cones.
Paul Gunther's Catering offered cheeseburgers and grilled chicken sandwiches.
Along the walkway toward the water, Shore Community Outreach Team were on-hand to administer health advice and blood pressure checks, the Elks informed people of their kids Drug Awareness Program handing out Frisbees, coloring books and other items. Recovery in Motion and the The AF Whitsitt Center offered assistance and information about their programs.
Andy Meehan Chestertown Rotary Club member said, "We had a very enthusiastic turnout. Over 130 people signed up and with volunteers and vendors that's another 30. People had a great time."
They all enjoyed themselves but are hoping for a sunny day next year come race time.
For information about Kent Goes Purple check out kentgoespurple.org.

title: Taylor-made - Vast repertoire ' across multiple musical genres: 'An Evening with Livingston Taylor' at the Avalon
content:
Taylor-made - Vast repertoire ' across multiple musical genres: 'An Evening with Livingston Taylor' at the Avalon

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3A | Section: News 
 
 262
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Livingston Taylor will bring his eclectic and formidable musical talents to the Avalon Theatre for a show on Saturday, Nov. 18, at 8 p.m.Taylor "vast repertoire" includes 22 albums and popular songs, according to a concert announcement from the Avalon. He is from the musical Taylor family and is the brother of James Taylor.Tickets to "An Evening with Livingston Taylor" at the Avalon are between $42 and $47 as well as $35 for ADA seats.Livingston Taylor has appeared and toured with the likes of Linda Ronstadt, Fleetwood Mac, Jethro Tull, Joni Mitchell and Jimmy Buffet."He's a natural performer, peppering his shows with personal stories, anecdotes and ineffable warmth that connect him to his fans.His relaxed on-stage presence belies the depth of his musical knowledge, and fans might just as often be treated to a classic Gershwin or a favorite from a Broadway musical," the Avalon's show announcement continued.Taylor's music delves into multiple genres including folk, pop, gospel and jazz.He taught for three decades at the Berklee College of Music in Boston and created a course on stage performance.Former students include John Mayer, Liz Longely, Gavin McGraw, Molly Tuttle, Charlie Puth and Susan Tedesci. Taylor continues to teach at other schools and college including the Frost School of Music at the University of Miami.He also has upcoming shows in New York, Virginia, Minnesota, Wisconsin and his home base of New England.For more information check out https://livingstontaylor.com/or https://www.avalonfoundation.org/event/livingston-taylor.

title: Rabbi Hyman delivers multicultural understanding
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Rabbi Hyman delivers multicultural understanding

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: News 
 
 705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Easton has been and is blessed with an extraordinarily number of exceptionally talented individuals engaged in a wide range of community service endeavors.One of them is Rabbi Peter Hyman DD (Doctor of Divinity) who is retiring in October after serving 18 years as the first full-time rabbi at Easton's Temple B'nai Israel.
Rabbi Hyman has a long history in walking his talk on promoting greater understanding of and respect for individuals with different religious beliefs and different faith journeys.
There is no more enduring symbol of Rabbi Hyman's commitment to respect for other religious beliefs than a Persian rug he bought in Israel 40 years ago. It is now on display in his office. That rug includes 99 names of God in Arabic. Rabbi Hyman views it as a metaphorical bridge connecting people of different faiths.
He once asked the leaders of a mosque if they could help him translate some of the Arabic words on his rug. They did so, amazed that such an inclusive rug was owned and displayed by a rabbi.
For Rabbi Hyman, it was simply his belief that "building relationships not only creates friendships, but they also cement ties."
A partial list of his local efforts to improve the quality of life in our community and beyond, includes serving as a member, program vice president and president of the Talbot Association of Clergy and Laity. He received an Award of Appreciation for Outstanding and Inspiring Interfaith Work in Talbot County for a Temple B'nai Israel February Lecture Series: "Introduction to Islam."
He was a recipient of the NAACP Dorothy Webb Black Community Service Legacy Award and a recipient of a Governor William Donald Schaefer Helping People Award. He was a member of The Frederick Douglass Celebration Committee and delivered the sermon at the Community Interfaith Worship Celebration, which was a part of the "Douglass Returns" statue dedication.
An author and teacher, he served as a presenter and instructor at Chesapeake College's Institute for Adult Learning and collaborated with Bishop Joel Marcus Johnson to launch a "Downtown Lunch and Learn" program. He was elected to the board of directors at the YMCA of the Chesapeake and appointed chair of the board at the Easton YMCA.
Support for Scouting has been a huge part of Rabbi Hyman's life since he earned his Eagle Scout award, as did his two sons. That is an achievement that has been earned by only 6% of all Scouts since 1912.
He has served as a scoutmaster and a chaplain at Scout World Jamborees in Thailand, England, Sweden and Japan and a National Jamboree in the United States. He was the first national chair for the Messengers of Peace Program, BSA, after having served as a national chair of the Jewish Committee on Scouting and as national Jewish chaplain — Boy Scouts of America. He was the keynote speaker at a national annual meeting of the BSA "Duty to God Breakfast" in Washington, D.C.
He is a recipient of the Silver Buffalo Award for distinguished service to youth awarded by the National Council of Boy Scouts of America. He is also a recipient of the Bronze Wolf Award, which is the Scouts' highest honor. It is presented by the World Scout Committee to recognize the service, commitment and contributions of volunteers to the Scout movement. Not surprisingly Hyman received the award for his interfaith activities and his lifelong commitment to "building bridges between people and nations."
Rabbi Hyman represented the BSA in Saudi Arabia at Saudi Nation Day when they received an award for the work of the BSA with the Messengers of Peace Program. This program promotes service projects through social media in effort to achieve world peace.
Hyman recalls that trip as the most amazing experience of his life because he was welcome in a Muslim country.
While the news of Rabbi Hyman's impending retirement is bittersweet, there is some good news.
He is not planning to leave the Eastern Shore.
Whether he stays here for the short term or long term, one thing is certain. He has made countless selfless contributions to help make Easton, Talbot County, and our world a better place.
Each one of them has earned Rabbi Hyman a well-deserved thank you and Godspeed.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant based in Easton.

title: Bridge - 'Always' may mean most of the time
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - 'Always' may mean most of the time

 October 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 286
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A guideline is something to be followed all of the time - except when it is wrong!Also, as you are aware, bridge is full of guidelines. One of the most reliable is that if one side is playing on a suit, it is wrong for the other side to play on it too.Today's deal is a straightforward example.West leads his fourthhighest heart against three no-trump. This gives declarer seven top tricks: two spades, one heart, three diamonds and one club. Assuming no 4-0 diamond split, two more tricks are readily available in diamonds. Or are they? Look at the spots. If the diamonds break 3-1, declarer will have to win the fourth round in his hand. With no dummy entry, the fifth diamond trick shrivels and dies like an earthworm on a hot pavement.However, South spotted a possibility. After winning the first trick with dummy's heart nine, he cashed the diamond queen and ace.West's club discard was a blow, but now declarer led the heart king.You see the idea behind this play. South knew West had started with at most five hearts, because West had led the five and declarer could see the three and four. South hoped that West would cash at least one more heart trick, on which the declarer would discard the blocking diamond seven or nine.However, West knew that if South thought it was right for North-South to play on hearts, it had to be wrong for East-West to do so too. West won with the heart ace and immediately switched to a spade.This condemned the contract. When declarer lost a trick in another suit, the defenders cashed their hearts. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Lions can't find way past Glenelg
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Lions can't find way past Glenelg

 May 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 746
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OWINGS MILLS — It had faced tough defenses before this season.But usually Queen Anne's County High's girls lacrosse team solved the opposition's defensive scheme, finding enough openings and seams to carve a path to victory.
The Lions couldn't find a solution though late Tuesday afternoon, as Glenelg dominated possession and yielded Queen Anne's few offensive opportunities en route to a 13-3 victory in the Class 2A state championship at Stevenson University's Mustang Stadium.
"They were able to come out defensively and put on the pressure and hold it," Lions head coach Kesley Fitzgerald said of Glenelg.
The Gladiators (18-1) were also able to hold the ball. Glenelg consistently won draw controls, reached ground balls before the Lions, and seemed to have someone on the ball every time Queen Anne's (15-3) lost possession or had a pass miss connection.
"Lots of speed and explosiveness," Fitzgerald said of the Gladiators. "And when you don't have lots of possessions you have to make every single one count.
"In the beginning of the first quarter we were," said Fitzgerald, whose team fell behind 2-0 in the opening 61 seconds, then cut that deficit in half with 8:46 left in the first quarter. "We were working through some kinks on defense, and every time offense had it in the first quarter we were converting. And then it came down to the draw possessions, and just making sure we got the ball out safely. And we didn't do that as well as we have all season."
Glenelg took a lead in never surrendered 34 seconds into the game when Kayleigh White (two goals) swept in the from the left and put a shot past Lions goalie Maddie George. Just 27 seconds later, Kamryn Henson (three goals) gained possession at the top of the box, dodged two defenders and stuck a shot into the right side of the net for a 2-0 lead.
Queen Anne's, which entered the game on a 10-game winning streak in which it averaged 13 goals a game, didn't appear rattled, as it pulled within 2-1, when RJ Ensor set up Riley Klepper's goal. The Gladiators regained their two-goal cushion a little over a minute later, when Regan Kelleher (two goals, two assists) found Reilly Kelleher alone in front of the net for a goal. Maggie Metz (three goals) scored in transition, extending Glenelg's lead to 4-1 with 3:36 left in the opening quarter.
The Lions answered, as Baillie Pinder dished to Ensor to make it 4-2 with 52.4 seconds remaining in the first quarter.
But Queen Anne's wouldn't score again until Madison Brown's goal with 3:40 left on a running clock in the fourth period made it 13-3.
"Offensively, they were all moving," Fitzgerald said of Glenelg. "Great off-ball movement. That's a strong team."
A team that scored nine consecutive goals after Ensor's strike to build a 13-2 lead with 9:41 left in the contest.
Glenelg had six different goal scorers before Henson netted her second off an assist from Emmy Dello Russo with 58.8 seconds left in the first half, pushing the Gladiators' lead to 8-2 at halftime. Chloe Key, Dello Russo and Regan Kelleher also scored in the first half.
Fitzgerald rotated George in goal with Emma Dulin throughout the game, both making big saves to keep the score respectable.
"Both those girls did an amazing job," Fitzgerald said.
Glenelg tacked on three third-quarter goals, with Henson scoring once and Metz twice. Regan Kelleher and White scored one apiece in the fourth before Brown ended Queen Anne's scoring drought.
"I do know we have the makings of being right there with them," said Fitzgerald, whose team was bidding for its second state title in four years. "Wasn't our day today. Super proud of the team. They have nothing to hang their heads about. We got here. We deserved to be here. And we'll be back.
"Every year we start out and try to figure out what the roles are going to be," Fitzgerald continued. "This year we made those roles very apparent, very early; earlier than I ever have before. And that's what worked for us this year. Everybody fell into their role. I'm fortunate every year at Queen Anne's as their coach to just have amazing student-athletes."
BASEBALLBRUNSWICK 26, COL. RICHARDSON 6FREDERICK — Derrick Mitchell had a pair of hits for Colonel Richardson, which had its hopes of a third straight Class 1A state final appearance end in Tuesday's semifinal round at McCurdy Field.
Brayden Dadds, Caleb Rouser and Gavin Whitby each had one hit for the Colonels, who finished the season 20-3.

title: FY2025 budget introduced at Dorchester County Council meeting
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
FY2025 budget introduced at Dorchester County Council meeting

 May 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County's proposed $86,523,125 fiscal year 2025 draft budget is a balanced budget, County Finance Director Karen Tolley said at a council meeting May 7."We're excited about that," said Tolley, who is also the mayor of Church Creek.
The proposed budget — an $81,938,414 operating and $4,584,711 capital budget — includes the council's efforts to implement "across the board" raises for county employees.
Tolley said that compared to the fiscal year 2024 budget, the fiscal year 2025 operating draft budget increased by about $2.5 million, or roughly 3%. She said the capital budget decreased by about $6.3 million, which is roughly 58%.
Within the operating budget, Tolley said the operating government funds budget increased about $2.9 million, or 4%. She said most of that increase is attributable to a 5% "across the board" raise to county employees.
"That was one of the council's missions," she said. "So therefore, that was one of the top priorities in this budget."
Tolley said that to balance this, other cuts needed to be made. She said those cuts were made in collaboration with department directors, and departments will still be maintaining full operations.
The county's proposed tax rates are the same as the fiscal year 2024 budget. The proposed real property tax is $1 per assessed $100 of value. The proposed personal property tax is $2.44 per assessed $100 of value.
According to the draft budget document, within Cambridge, the real property tax rate is $0.9267 per assessed $100 of value. Within Hurlock, the real property tax rate is $0.9179 per assessed $100 of value. This is due to tax differentials for these two towns.
Tolley also talked about the grants budget during her presentation. According to the draft budget document, the county is leveraging $903,919 for $3.9 million in grant funds.
At the council meeting, the Dorchester County Council introduced the budget. Public hearings for the proposed budget will be held May 14 and May 21. A final hearing and adoption of the budget is set for May 28 during the regular council meeting.
Along with introducing the draft budget, the council passed a resolution that gives the county the authority to invest in the Maryland Local Government Investment Pool.
"I think it will give us some great returns," Tolley said.

title: Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: News 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After a threatening social media post on Friday was determined to not be a threat to Easton schools, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office is investigating another threat that has been circulating on social media.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday morning that the threat, which originated on Instagram, is not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code. He said the threat is a photo of a "clearly" photoshopped Instagram message that includes the 410 area code.
"We're taking it very seriously, as we do every threat," Gamble said, adding that, through investigation, the Sheriff's Office doesn't think there is "any viable threat to the safety" of TCPS students.
According to a letter from the district addressed to TCPS families, the district is "closely monitoring the situation" and working with local authorities. The letter says that school operations will continue as normal.
Gamble said a criminal investigation by the Sheriff's Office is underway. He said all school resource officers in the district are aware of the threat, and extra deputies are patrolling.
On Friday, TCPS students were put in a modified lockdown following a threatening social media post made that morning. According to the Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.
Gamble said the Sheriff's officer is aware of jurisdictions in other states that "have had 40 or 50 of these types of threats."
"It's happening all over our country where, for whatever reason, somebody is trying to disrupt school operations and put our kids in fear," he said.
Gamble said that a few years back, the district experienced something similar where about half a dozen non-specific threats were made during the course of the school year. He said he would expect to see more of these threats this year.
"This just seems like the thing to do these days for some reason," he said.
