title: Queenstown Bank hosts Farmer's Luncheon
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Queenstown Bank hosts Farmer's Luncheon

 March 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 552
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EAST NEW MARKET — A group of Eastern Shore farmers gathered Friday afternoon at the East New Market Fire House to hear Dick Willey, former president of Perdue AgriBusiness, give his insights into the upcoming season.The event was hosted by Queenstown Bank and lunch was catered by Old Salty's Restaurant.
Queenstown Bank's Tracy Whitby-Fairall said that the event was not a sales event.
"This is an event for the farming industry and the community," she said.
After the presentation, Whitby-Fairall let the attendees know that, if wanted, Queenstown employees were present and able to talk about loan needs or answer any questions.
Willey's presentation delved into the corn and soybean markets.
He estimated the trading range for corn this year will be between $4 and $5.65 per bushel.
"That's not what you want to hear," he said. "But when I look at the technicals, and when I look at what I've seen from a historical standpoint, that's where I would venture to estimate."
For soybeans, Willey estimated the trading range this year will be $11.50 to $15.50 per bushel.
He estimated the cost of production per bushel will be $4.78 for corn and $11.80 for soybeans this year. In other words, margins could be small if the prices stay at the low end of the estimate.
Willey's presentation touched on wheat and weather. He said he didn't have any positive insights on wheat supply and use.
"So many Mid-Atlantic mills have closed," he said. "What's been going on across the country is it's just not a pleasant deal."
Willey said that in 2001, the United States had a total of 63 million acres of wheat. The estimate for 2024 and 2025 is 16 million less acres.
Touching on climate change, Willey said extreme weather is becoming the norm.
"Don't be a climate denier," he said. "There are a lot of people that are still denying that we have a climate problem. It's real."
Michael Bostic Jr., a farmer in Church Hill, said he was not surprised by Willey's insights.
"It's our job to keep up on stuff like this," he said. "It's all been in the pipeline for a while."
Bostic, who grows corn, wheat and soybeans, said he is trying to stay optimistic about what's to come this year.
"But it's not going to be great," he said.
At the end of his presentation, Willey encouraged the farmers in the audience to consider their supply chain in relation to value chain, or how much money is in a product.
"When somebody buys it, how much money does that generate and what percentage of it do you get?" he said, explaining what value chain is.
Willey encouraged the audience to consider artificial intelligence's place in all this.
"You guys are really good at knowing what your costs are," he said. "With AI, I think we're going to find a way to not only know what the costs are, but we're going to find out, not only the supply chain, but what the value chain is. And remember, other people will be able to figure out what your portion of the value chain is."
Willey said he thinks that in the next four or five years, there will be a trend in people deciding they want to raise prices on the things that go into producing a crop.
"Because there's so much money in the value chain, and they want more of it," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Contractor bringing Oxford's Strand project up to specifications
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Contractor bringing Oxford's Strand project up to specifications

 April 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 318
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Efforts to complete the first phase of the Strand Beach project are underway this week after it was determined the project was not finished to the specifications originally presented to the town.During a Commissioners of Oxford meeting March 25, Oxford Town Manager Holly Wahl said work to complete the project would begin the week of March 31.
In order to finish the first phase of the project, the contractor, Underwood and Associates, will lower the islands on the beach, remove temporary access to the islands, purchase and install native plantings and install a grassy strip along the roadway to prevent sand from flowing into the roadway, Wahl said. All of these items are to be completed to match the approved permit and site plan.
Wahl said Underwood and Associates is required to complete this phase of the project by April 19.
In December, the Commissioners of Oxford announced that although the Strand Beach project was signed off on in June by previous Town Manager Cheryl Lewis, the project had not been completed to the specifications that Underwood and Associates had originally presented.
The plan for the project was to create a berm, place hooks along the east and west areas of the Strand to bring in sand, create small islands in the water to reduce waves coming onto the beach and plant low marsh grasses on those islands. During the commissioners meeting in December, Commissioner Katrina Greer said not all the grasses had been planted on the islands and the islands were two feet higher in elevation than they were supposed to be.
That month, Greer brought together the Maryland Department of the Environment, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Underwood and Associates and the organizations that funded the project to ensure Underwood and Associates would bring down the elevation of the islands and take out the sand that goes out to the headlands at no cost to the town.

title: Maryland gas prices up 4.6 cents this week
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland gas prices up 4.6 cents this week

 April 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 433
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have risen 4.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.60 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 26.3 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 9.9 cents per gallon higher than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has increased 3.1 cents in the last week and stands at $4.02 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $3.25 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $4.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.54per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 6.5 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.57 per gallon today. The national average is up 17.1 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 0.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
April 8, 2023: $3.51per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.58 per gallon)April 8, 2022: $3.74per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.12 per gallon)April 8, 2021: $2.78per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.86 per gallon)April 8, 2020: $1.98per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.88 per gallon)April 8, 2019: $2.68per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.75 per gallon)April 8, 2018: $2.67per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.65 per gallon)April 8, 2017: $2.36per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.39 per gallon)April 8, 2016: $2.05per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.04 per gallon)April 8, 2015: $2.35per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.39 per gallon)April 8, 2014: $3.59per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.58 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.60 per gallon, up 7.5 cents per gallon from last week's $3.52 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.72 per gallon, up 4.7 cents per gallon from last week's $3.68 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.58 per gallon, down 3.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.61 per gallon.
"After a brief break, gas prices have leapt back up, driven by extensive refinery maintenance on the West Coast, where prices have increased notably; only a handful of states have seen prices decline over the last week," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With oil prices rising to nearly $87 per barrel last week, their highest since October, we are not only facing the seasonal factors that push prices up — refinery maintenance, the switch to summer gasoline and rising demand — but also escalating crude oil prices as OPEC's production cuts continue to cause declining global oil inventories, with escalations between Iran and Israel adding to concerns of further destabilization."

title: Disaster relief loans available for businesses affected by Key Bridge collapse
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Disaster relief loans available for businesses affected by Key Bridge collapse

 May 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's inevitable that Kent County businesses will be impacted due to the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse, says Liliana Tschanett, public affairs specialist for the Office of Disaster Assistance for the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA).When that happens, she wants to be available and armed with the proper resources to lend a hand.
The SBA announced that Mid-Atlantic small businesses affected by the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse in Baltimore can apply for disaster loans now until Dec. 30, 2024.
On Tuesday, April 23, she went before the Kent County Commissioners, presenting some options business owners have.
She stated that small business owners can receive up to $2 million if they can prove that the collapse has affected their business.
"It's a loan, not a grant," she pointed out meaning they'd also have to prove they can pay it back at 4% interest.
Specifically, Tschanett explained, it's called a short idle loan; an economic injury disaster system loan.
Tschanett told the commissioners that after the tragic collapse, every county in Maryland and adjacent counties in neighboring states were declared a disaster area, so the loan is a certification from Governor Wes Moore...distinct from a presidential declaration.
To be eligible, businesses must prove they've been in operation for a year at least. They will also be asked to submit the proper forms such as a copy of a federal tax return and information from their insurance company.
She added that it has more success of being approved if it is $25,000 or under as well.
It's similar to the COVID-19 loan, she said. However with their new automated processing software, Tschanett hopes it will be easier for people to navigate the website.
She acknowledged their office heard complaints during the Covid-19 time period.
For anyone still overwhelmed maneuvering through the website, Tschanett invited them to talk to one of their many loan officers either via email or in-person at one of their three sites in our area.
There's plenty of help available, whether it be through their own loan officers, or their partners at SCORE (a business mentoring organization) or the Small Business Development Center.
They will answer any questions that pop up.
For instance, if a small business already has a Covid-19 loan can they still be eligible for this one?
Tschanett's answer was yes. A loan officer will work with the business owner to change the terms of the loan.
"They'll take you step by step," Tschanett assured the public.
With a December 30 deadline to get the information in, her advice is to start the application process early.
She predicted that businesses will look for grants before loans. However, towards the end of the year, when grant money's not available, like around Christmas, they'll be a peaked interest.
When that happens, she wants to have resources at the ready.
Resources like webinars with detailed instructions while partnering with Jamie Williams, director of Kent County Economic & Tourism Development and Sarah King Executive Director of the Chamber of Commerce.
Commission member Albert Nickerson, relaying a personal anecdote on how the bridge collapse was used as a reason for a delay of building supplies, saw the importance of the loan.
"Unfortunately, we'll have a lot of people enquire about this," he said.
Tschanett said when that time comes, she'll be prepared.
Business owners can contact a loan officer of the SBA at customer service at 1-800-659-2955, or through their website: https://www.sba.gov/.

title: Rep. Jamie Raskin comes to Cambridge for town hall
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Rep. Jamie Raskin comes to Cambridge for town hall

 March 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 571
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Energy was high as Eastern Shore residents packed the gymnasium at Mace's Lane Middle School Saturday for Cambridge Indivisible and Eastern Shore Indivisible's town hall event with Maryland U.S. Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-Md.)."I know I was not your first choice," Raskin said over cheers from the crowd. "I heard your congressman couldn't quite squeeze you in today."
Raskin represents most of Montgomery County and part of Prince George's County. Cambridge Indivisible Co-Founder and Co-Chair Michelle Fowle said the organization invited Maryland U.S. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) — who represents the Eastern Shore and lives in Cambridge — but Harris didn't respond.
"We made it super easy for him to be here, and he didn't even have the decency to formally decline," Fowle said. "He just completely ignores us and just tells everybody that we're paid $40 an hour and bused in."
Although Harris wasn't at the Cambridge Indivisible event Saturday, he is holding a telephone hall for residents on Tuesday, March 25. Those who would like to attend the event, which will be from 5:30 to 6:30 p.m., can listen in by calling 833-380-0671 or can stream the event at harris.house.gov/live.
During the town hall Saturday, Raskin expressed concerns with the Republican Party's priorities.
He brought up recent actions taken by President Donald Trump and the the Department of Government Efficiency. He said he is trying to "stop this savage assault on American democracy."
"They're not opponents of corruption," Raskin said. "They're agents of corruption."
When it came to the question and answer portion of the town hall, residents asked what could be done in response to the Trump administration's actions.
Many made a point to mention they were not paid to be there, referencing Harris' words following a rally Cambridge Indivisible organized in opposition to the congressman March 13. Harris told members of the media he didn't believe many of the people at the rally were his constituents, adding that he believed they were paid protesters "brought in by buses."
Commenting on the Saturday town hall, Harris said in a statement Monday that it's "ironic" that "ultra-radical leftist" Raskin is "suddenly pretending to care about our farmers, watermen and people on the Eastern Shore after four years of voting for reckless Biden administration policies and radical environmental regulations — which almost crushed our Eastern Shore economy."
"If these protests weren't being paid for and influenced by radical Democrat activists, Jaime Raskin would have stayed on the western shore — right where he and his radical policies belong," Harris said.
Throughout the event Saturday, volunteers were available with smart phones to capture residents' stories.
"Andy Harris can ignore our emails, he can dodge our phone calls and he can refuse to hold a town hall," Cambridge Indivisible Co-Founder and Co-Chair Andy Fowle said. "But he cannot erase our stories."
Retired East New Market resident Roscoe Handy, who attended the event, said he has concerns about the fate of Social Security, Medicare and the U.S. Department of Education. He said Harris needs to hear from his constituents and put a face to their name.
"I didn't necessarily vote for him. However, I'm in his district," said Handy, a Democrat.
At the end of the event, Raskin was asked if he has plans to run for president in the next U.S. presidential election.
"I will do whatever is necessary for us to save our democracy," he said in response as applause and cheers filled the room.
This report has been updated to include comment from Andy Harris.

title: Winston opens office support business in Preston
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Winston opens office support business in Preston

 May 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: News 
 
 525
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PRESTON — Savannah Winston is busy. She is a mother, she is working on a doctorate in education and she was recently appointed as president of the Preston Commissioners.And, she has just cut the ribbon on her new business support services building.
Winston has turned a 3,900-square-foot old bank into a multifaceted space to incubate other businesses.
"We do administrative support services. So part of that is to offer the business center services, you can come in and get your copies made, fax, scan, notary," Winston said. She also offers call center services and tax returns.
Her business's name is Van Tech Business Solutions. With it, she hopes to provide support to other local entrepreneurs.
The chamber of commerce has been a huge support in her efforts, Winston said, along with her friends, family and other community members.
"Tracy Snyder, director, she led the ribbon cutting ceremony. The whole community was there. People came from near and far. I had family that traveled in, and I had other businesswomen that traveled from the western shore to come over in support. My bishop was here to bless the building," she said.
Entrepreneurs see potential where others just drive by, Winston said. She is hoping to employ five people.
"That was one of the goals behind purchasing this property. As well as carrying out the vision of the mayor to bring economic development to the town. For so long this building was vacant. It has been a great six months of development," she said.
She reached out to the Maryland Capital Enterprise Women's Business Center in Salisbury to get help with her loan. She shared her business plan and didn't have any problem getting the funding, she said.
"This is all part of my leadership is to empower women in business, to really get out there. If you have a business, don't be afraid," Winston said.
Winston has a lot of space. Her own business needs only require about ¼ of the whole footprint. She plans to rent out the remaining space to long-term tenants as well as offer desks and office space for short-term business needs.
She has two renters already. One is Elegant Affairs event planning service and the other is Eternal Love Cleaning Service. There will also be a musical organ repairman, who will have his showroom in the back. She wants to open her front lot to food trucks.
"If you work from home or remotely, you can just come in and work in a different space or meet a client here. I also have more private office space you can rent by the day. Just go on my website and reserve your space for the day — you have a furnished office," she said.
She knows this will bring more businesses to town, another one of her goals, both as a businessperson and as a local elected official.
"If you want to see more businesses come to town, you have to lead the way," she said. "... I am an entrepreneur. It is all about bringing the resources to the community and allowing others to also to grow and expand their business opportunities. Why not do it together? I love partnerships and collaboration," she said.

title: Residents weigh in on potential improvements to Matthewstown Road
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Residents weigh in on potential improvements to Matthewstown Road

 December 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 445
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Easton residents voiced desires to see improved pedestrian and bicycle access, left turn lanes and traffic volume mitigation on Matthewstown Road during a transportation open house Tuesday evening.Facilitated by the Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration, the open house served as an opportunity for residents to ask questions about the agency's working study of a 1.6-mile stretch of the busy two-lane road.A SHA team first began considering environmental, community and economic goals in terms of improvements along Matthewstown Road this past spring as part of a Planning and Environmental Linkages Study.According to survey data collected by SHA, residents primarily like the road's traffic lights and convenience.However, concerns were raised about extensive traffic congestion, timing issues with the traffic light at Elliot Road, speeding, excess development and a lack of sidewalks.Those concerns were echoed at Tuesday's open house, where residents were able to view an aerial map of the portion of the road being studied and place sticky notes on areas of concern.Notes included adding left turn lanes at the intersection of Matthewstown Road and Black Dog Alley and the road's intersection with Dyott Court, changing speed limits and coordination of signals to lessen traffic.Residents also highlighted the number of dense housing developments along the road, some of which have yet to be built, like Gannon Range.To Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey, who lives near Matthewstown Road, the lack of pedestrian and bicycle access along the road could stand to be improved.Efforts have been made to improve pedestrian access on the west side of Easton, particularly west of Route 50, but dense development on both sides of the highway necessitate taking steps to handle the additional volume.Adding sidewalks - and dedicated center turn lanes to avoid cars traveling around others on the shoulders - would be great, he said.But above all, Lowrey hopes the community will be engaged with the process of improving the busy road.Hunters Mill resident John Franczak raised concerns about the significant traffic on Matthewstown Road, noting long wait times for lights to change.Franczak said he would be willing to look at the possibility of a traffic circle somewhere along the road stretch in question to slow speeding traffic down, though he also voiced a request to lower the speed limit from 50 mph to 35 mph between the Hunters Mill neighborhood and Route 50.The SHA study is set to finish by spring 2024. The agency is still accepting survey comments, which can be accessed via the SHA project page. 
 
 Caption: NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Easton Town Council Ward 2 Councilman Don Abbatiello, center, speaks to a State Highway Administration representative about potential improvements to Matthewstown Road.

title: 'Unparalleled resilience, adaptability and determination:' CSD class of 2024 graduates
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
'Unparalleled resilience, adaptability and determination:' CSD class of 2024 graduates

 June 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 470
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — It was during summer break of last year that Wil and Luke Reinbold found out they just might end up sharing a title other than twin."I was starting on college applications and they were asking for my class rank," Wil said in an interview with the Star Democrat. "So I emailed my guidance counselor, and she got back to me and told me that I was ranked first, and I was tied with my brother."
Fast forward to Thursday evening, the identical twin brothers — who have matching grade point averages down to the hundredth of a decimal — were called to the stage in the gym of Cambridge-South Dorchester High School as co-valedictorians of the school's class of 2024.
"Some of you may be wondering why there are two people that look so similar standing up here tonight giving a speech," Luke said. "Some say I'm the funny twin."
"While other's say I'm the better looking twin," Wil cut in.
During their speech, the pair talked about the importance of taking risks and working through challenges.
"If times get tough down the road, we must remember all the good times and lessons learned in high school," Luke said.
CSD Principal Jerome Stover acknowledged some of those challenges the class of 2024 faced in their high school career, particularly with the COVID-19 pandemic.
"Despite the challenges of the pandemic, the school shut downs, the world coming to a halt, you have demonstrated unparalleled resilience, adaptability and determination to succeed," he said.
The class received a total of $2.8 million in scholarships.
Stover reminded the audience that four years ago, these students didn't get to have a traditional eighth grade graduation ceremony.
"But today, as you stand on the brink of a new chapter in your lives, it is essential to acknowledge the magnitude of this milestone," he said. "You have taken chances, leapt in the face of uncertainty, embarked on roadtrips, enjoyed senior trips, witnessed and enjoyed breathtaking experiences as a CSD student."
During the commencement address, CSD teacher and basketball coach Shawn Tucker told the students that inspiration can come from unexpected sources. He talked about a student who, over the last four years, went from not attending class, to arguing with Tucker to calling Tucker the reason they come to school every day.
"There were a lot of times that I didn't want to get up and come to school, but I thought (about) what you told me," Tucker said about the student. "And it inspired me to get here. Maybe not on time, but I got here."
The graduation ceremony brought tears and laughter on Thursday evening. Along with the speeches, the CSD chorus performed "I Lived" by OneRepublic, and the students, along with some staff and administration members, performed "Don't Stop Believin'" by Journey and "The Time of My Life" by Bill Medley and Jennifer Warnes.

title: Student designs school district holiday card
content:
Student designs school district holiday card

 December 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A4 | Section: School 
 
 223
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Artwork by Colonel Richardson High School student Summer Smith has been chosen for the annual Caroline County Public Schools holiday card.Each year, art teachers provide students the opportunity to produce and submit artwork for the school system's holiday card. Submissions are narrowed down to about a dozen finalists and, in keeping with long-standing tradition, the superintendent chooses the winner.
At the Dec. 5 board of education meeting, Supervisor of Instruction Renee Hesson unveiled Smith's artwork, and presented her with a certificate. Summer's family, CRHS art teacher Melanie Bolles and CRHS Principal Jared Sherman were also in attendance.
Superintendent Dr.
Derek Simmons said that as a person who "cannot draw a stick figure well," he is continually amazed at the artistic ability of students and what they are learning in art classes.
Simmons said all the finalists' artwork was worthy of representing the district; however, Smith's card really stood out because of the intricate details, in particular noting the footsteps leading from the snowman to the cabin. Board members also commented on details such as the smoke rising from the chimney and the script in the trees.
All finalist entries may be viewed on the CCPS Flickr page, flickr.com/photos/142694579@N05/albums/. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF CCPS

title: Beloved school crossing guard retires after 54 years
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Beloved school crossing guard retires after 54 years

 June 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For 54 years, when school let out, Charles Jenkins worked his magic, directing traffic and ensuring Easton Middle School students walked home safely.Tuesday morning was unique, though, as the longtime crossing guard was honored for his last day on the job, waving to hundreds of cars, trucks and buses at the intersection of S. Washington Street and Peachblossom Road.
"I'm gonna miss every bit of it because I've been doing it all my life," Jenkins, who is best known by his nickname 'Nut,' said. "Just like starting driving your first time, you want to keep right on driving. That's what I felt about this.
"I've enjoyed every bit of it, working with the community and working with my fine officers and everything. …(I) give them respect, and they give me respect."
Jenkins, 81, has 54 years of service at schools in Easton, along with over 20 years in the St. Michaels community on the weekends. He's been manning the intersection for decades, managing the chaotic, busy scene of buses departing, students walking home and parents picking up their children.
"Wait 'til I tell them to go, don't go on your own," Jenkins said of his longtime message to the students. "Wait until I turn around to tell you to go, but they're great for that. They really do (listen)."
Josepha Price and Carla Beavers, who each have children that just wrapped up sixth grade at EMS, led an effort to honor Jenkins Tuesday morning. Price and Beavers worked with the school's Family Teacher Organization to have students and parents drop off cards.
They energized a large part of the Easton community prior to Tuesday morning with a Facebook post, which garnered hundreds of likes, and a wealth of appreciation for what Jenkins has done for pedestrian safety in Easton.
"He's tough on us parents that drive, but so soft and enthusiastic to our children," Price wrote. "You know wherever he is, the kids will be safe, and I can't think of any greater purpose than protecting children."
As Easton Middle's early dismissal on its last day commenced, Price and others held up "Honk for Mr. Jenkins" signs in front of the Idlewild Park fountain, down the street from the school. Some students walked over to embrace Jenkins and say goodbye.
Once dismissal finished, EMS administrators, teachers and staff all walked down to the intersection to greet Jenkins, who was accompanied by one of his two daughters.
"They all respect me and everything with my work, and I respect all of them by being here," Jenkins said.
In 2022, he was presented a Governor's Citation by former Gov. Larry Hogan for his dedication to keeping the community safe.
Jenkins' plans moving forward are to spend time with his daughters and "take it easy and relax."
"I just wish I was 30 years younger," Jenkins said.
When asked if he would do it all over again for another 50-plus years, the beloved crossing guard had no hesitation.
"If I could, I really would," Jenkins said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Glad to have post office back
author: Staff Writer
content:
Glad to have post office back

 November 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 134
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After over two years of being closed for renovations, the Trappe Post Office has finally reopened after a sudden closure in October 2022. Our community was never informed of construction progress (or the lack thereof) that seemed to drag on forever.The post office is a central feature of any small town, and we are very glad to have our post office back.
For all of this time, those of us with post office boxes have driven to Cambridge to pick up our mail. I extend gratitude to the postal clerks at the Cambridge post office who took on the extra workload processing our mail, always with a smile and a helping hand.
Special appreciation to our own postal clerk, Jasmine, who spent those years away working in Cambridge, and now is welcomed back home.

title: Ditching plastic water bottles
content:
Ditching plastic water bottles

 September 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A6 | Section: News 
 
 305
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The trouble with plastic bottled water, experts say, is not the water. It's the plastic bottles the water comes in that are potentially harmful to our health and environment.The folks at the Mayo Clinic say we need to be concerned about BPA.Exposure to BPA, they say, is a concern because of possible health effects on the brain, behavior and prostate gland of fetuses, infants and children. The Food and Drug Administration suggests that very low-level exposure to BPA is safe; however, the agency is engaged in ongoing research. Sounds scary to me.Health issues are one thing, but the effect on the environment is another.According to the Environmental Protection Agency, in 2018, the U.S. generated nearly 36 million tons of plastic waste. This has been a problem for so long that Concord, Massachusetts, in 2012 became the first municipality in the nation to ban the sale of single-serving water bottles. San Francisco in 2014 implemented one of the strictest bottled water bans in the country by banning the sale of bottled water on public property.Extreme reactions? Perhaps, but 36 million tons of plastic waste is no small matter.If health and environment issues aren't enough to give us pause, consider that single-serve bottled water is not that great for our wealth, either. Do the math. It all adds up.Every day I fill my water bottle at least three times (it has a 24-ounce capacity). I find that I drink a lot more water just because this particular container is convenient, BPA-free and pretty cool, too. What do I like most about it? I don't have to tip it up to drink from it.Think of an adult "sippy cup" with a built-in straw and flip top.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living." COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

title: Only bilingual law firm in Kent County celebrates 1 year
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Only bilingual law firm in Kent County celebrates 1 year

 April 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — The First Friday event of April brought friends, neighbors and visitors to downtown Chestertown. Some of those stopped by the law offices of Campbell and Furneisen to celebrate the company's one-year anniversary.Partners Bridget Campbell and Ivette Furneisen were both nominated for Eastern Shore's 2024 Women to Watch. And according to their website, Furneisen is "one of very few Spanish-speaking lawyers on the shore, and possibly the only native Spanish-speaking. It continues, "Furneisen has quickly gained a reputation as a friend to Hispanics and other immigrants in the area, helping with traffic and family court, visas and applications for citizenship."
Furneisen said this anniversary is a significant celebration due to that distinction.
Over sparkling beverages and catering courtesy of Happy Chicken, and while balancing conversation with friends and well-wishers, Furneisen shared why she feels like her work is more vital than ever.
It started, she said, 15 years ago. In her native country of Spain, she was working for a nonprofit doing immigration work. She extended that realm of her expertise by studying law at George Mason University. Ultimately, she and her husband, who worked for American Airlines, discovered Kent County.
Now a year in to running her own practice advocating for Spanish speakers, she expressed concern for her clients, some of whom had been detained by immigration police being caught in offenses such as traffic violations.
These incidences, she said, are why she decided to pursue law further.
"Everyone deserves representation. It doesn't matter if you're rich or poor," Furneisen stated.
She takes a lot of cases from the public defender's office for those who normally could not afford a lawyer.
"Now, I can be an advocate for them. And not just in the courts. I really care," she said.
The other half of the firm is Bridget Campbell. She handles family law, real estate, business formation and other practices.
Like her legal partner, Campbell is grateful to be representing Kent County. With both of them working jointly, they cast a wide net of services.
Some of the most rewarding work is representing children as a best interest attorney, Campbell said. It is her job to advocate for children, give them a voice, and from those assessments, persuade the judge to act in the children's best interest.
This involves talking to the parents, the therapists and the children, being present for them in their time of need, Campbell said. As a mother of three boys, this is very near to her heart as she reflects on her time studying law at Villanova, before attending Washington College.
Originally born in Pennsylvania, she has established roots here after studying law at Villanova and attending Washington College. She is president of the Kent County Humane Society, dedicated to promoting animal welfare, "preventing unnecessary pain and suffering for domestic companions in the community."
Both attorneys see themselves reaching beyond their law profession to help those in need.
"Ivette and I find a way to give back to the community every way we can," Campbell said.

title: Country Cooking: Cooking for The King
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Cooking for The King

 August 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1061
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Today's column is being written from the heart. The month of August is always a busy month, but not too busy for me to reflect on the past.Those of you who know me also know this is the month I usually travel to Memphis and meet with worldwide friends to gather at Graceland and pay respects to Elvis.
Aug. 16, 1977 was the day we teenagers of the late 1950s and '60s lost one of our favorite idols. Hard to believe it's been 48 years since I heard the news that morning. As goes with all our idols, Elvis is just as popular today with fans of all ages.
My answer to those who ask why I liked him so much is easy to explain: My older siblings loved the late 1940s through the mid-1950s music, and when I became a preteen, my generation needed a change of dance styles and rock 'n' roll music. And we got it — to the horror of our elders. That is true for all generations.
When I meet fans from Germany, some are my age, but some are 30 and 40 years old and remembering their grandparents and parents talking about Elvis serving in the Army in Germany.
Let's explore some of the King's favorite foods. Elvis loved his mother's meatloaf, and I occasionally make this recipe.
MEATLOAF
2 lbs ground beef, one chopped onion, one chopped green pepper, two minced cloves garlic, 4 oz crushed saltines, 8-oz can crushed tomatoes, 8-oz can tomato sauce, 1/2 cup ketchup.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Mix together ground beef with onion, green pepper, garlic, crushed saltines and crushed tomatoes. Mix well and form into a loaf and place in a baking pan. Bake covered, for 45 minutes. In the meantime, mix tomato sauce and ketchup and set aside. After 45 minutes of baking, remove the meatloaf and pour the ketchup on top and return to the oven. Bake for another 15 minutes and serve with mashed potatoes.
ROAST BEEF
2 tbsps black pepper, 1 1/2 tbsps salt, 2 tbsps garlic, 6 lb beef, 1 1/2 cups water.
Mix pepper, salt and garlic to form a paste and rub on this mixture on the beef. Place this roast in a baking pan, add water and place in a 350-degree oven. Bake for about 4 hours or until tender. You can steam some fresh vegetables to serve with the roast.
SPANISH OMELETTE
4 eggs, 1/2 cup chopped green bell pepper, 1/2 cup chopped onion, 1/2 cup shredded cheese, salt and pepper.
Beat eggs well and mix in bell pepper and onion. Fold in 1/2 cup shredded cheese of your choice with salt and pepper to taste. Cook in a greased skillet for about 4 minutes.
HAMBURGER STEAK ELVIS
2 1/2 pounds ground beef, 1/2 cup chopped onion, 1/2 cup chopped green pepper, 1 tbsp garlic, 1 tbsp salt, 1 tbsp black pepper, 2 cups mushroom soup, 2 eggs (beaten).
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a large bowl mix together ground beef, chopped onions, chopped green pepper, garlic, salt, black pepper, mushroom soup and eggs. Mix well Shape into mini steaks and fry in a skillet with 2 tablespoons Crisco. Cook for about 12 to 15 minutes, making sure steaks are cooked inside well. Drain on paper towels and proceed to make gravy with grease left in the pan.
ELVIS BANANA BREAD
2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 cup sugar, 1 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp baking soda, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp pumpkin pie spice, 4 medium ripe bananas (mashed), 2 large eggs (room temperature), 1/2 cup creamy peanut butter, 1/4 cup unsweetened applesauce, 1/4 cup canola oil, 2 tsps vanilla extract, 2/3 cup semisweet chocolate chips
Preheat oven to 350 degrees. In a large bowl, whisk the first six ingredients. In another bowl, whisk bananas, eggs, peanut butter, applesauce, oil and vanilla until blended. Add to flour mixture; stir just until moistened. Fold in chocolate chips. Transfer to three loaf pans coated with cooking spray. Bake for 45-50 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Cool in pans 10 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool. If you make multiple loaves like Mary Jenkins Langston would make for his plane rides to Las Vegas, you can freeze them and reheat. Securely wrap the cooled loaves and freeze. To use, thaw at room temperature or, if desired, microwave each loaf on high for 60-75 seconds or until heated through.
FRIED PEANUT BUTTER AND BANANA SANDWICHES
Smear peanut butter on one slice of bread, and on the other slice smear the bread with mashed banana. Put the slices together, smear each outside slice with bacon grease and fry in a hot skillet.
FRIED DILL PICKLES
1 jar (32 oz) whole dill pickles, 1 cup buttermilk, 2 tbsps Louisiana-style hot sauce, 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 cup cornmeal, 2 tbsps garlic salt, 2 tbsps paprika, 1 tbsp cayenne pepper, 1 tsp pepper, oil for deep-fat frying, ranch salad dressing.
Drain pickles, discarding liquid. Cut pickles into 1/2-inch-thick slices. Drain on paper towels; blot with additional paper towels until dry. In a shallow bowl, mix buttermilk and hot sauce. In another shallow bowl, mix flour, cornmeal, garlic salt, paprika, cayenne pepper and pepper. Dip pickles in buttermilk mixture, then in flour mixture. In a Dutch oven, heat one inch of oil to 375 degrees. Working in batches, fry pickles for 2-3 minutes on each side, or until golden brown. Drain on paper towels. Serve immediately with ranch dressing, if desired.
Before I close the column today, I need to honor my late brother, Staff Sgt. (E6) Ollie L. Hitchens Jr., who would be celebrating his 78th birthday on Aug. 15. Ollie served 20 years in the U.S. Army and pulled three tours of duty in Vietnam.
Ollie and I had a lot in common — our likes, dislikes, love for Chevy cars, love of family, patriotic responsibilities, personalities and love for Elvis.
Ollie loved our mom's old-fashioned cooking and often wrote home about how he missed it. While on his many trips home Mom would make sure to have those foods ready — fried chicken, pot roast, pork chops, mashed potatoes, fried liver with gravy, chicken and dumplings, fresh lima beans with tomatoes, corn and potatoes and of course homemade biscuits. I have shared many of these recipes with you in previous columns.
Rest in peace, brother — as I always say, "All gave some, and some gave all."

content:
The STREAM Scene

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 10A | Section: News 
 
 253
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "Hope Street" - Season 3 (Nov. 22)The mysteries continue in a new season of this BBC crime drama. Available on the BritBox Prime Video channel, the series is set in the fictional town of Port Devine on the coast of Northern Ireland. It follows the town's police department as they team up with a series of outsiders to solve mysteries in the area, getting caught up in the exploits of Port Devine's locals along the way."Spellbound" - Season 1, Part 2 (Nov. 20)When 15-year-old Cece Parker Jones (Hailey Romain) relocates from a small town in the US to France to study at the Paris Opera Ballet School, she's on top of the world. But, her world turns upside-down when she discovers a book of family spells in the back room of her aunt's apothecary."Stamped From the Beginning" (Nov. 20)Dr. Ibram X. Kendi's bestselling book comes to life in this new, hybrid documentary/scripted film. Chronicling the entire story of anti-Black racist ideas and their staggering power over the course of American history, the film uses an innovative animation process that blends live action with the art of the era to illuminate figures and moments both wellknown and obscure."Meet Spidey and his Amazing Friends (Shorts)" - Season 3 (Nov. 22)Our favourite web-slinger is great at working solo, but Spidey is about to discovery that when he's got some super-hero friends by his side, he can fight supervillains and rescue anyone in trouble even better. Meet the good guys and gals that help Spidey save the day!

title: Residual bill passed by Caroline County Commissioners
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Residual bill passed by Caroline County Commissioners

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 365
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On Tuesday morning, the Caroline County Commissioners voted to approve the long-discussed bill that would establish county regulations for storing food processing residuals, animal waste from the food processing process.These residuals, particularly dissolved air floatation, or DAF, residuals have been the topic of several heated discussions in the county since residents began raising health complaints and environmental concerns over how the material was being stored by some in the county late last year.
The county came up with a permitting system. There will be a universal permit requirement in order to store food processing residuals. It creates limitations on how residuals can be stored and permits the county to fine violators.
It would require that those storing the material use closed-top containers, going a step further than recently passed state legislation.
Attorney Stewart Barroll said commissioners and Caroline County staff had heard "voluminous" public comments that have been taken into account.
Prior to voting, two amendments were approved by commissioners involving distances from the storage containers.
Commissioner Franklin Bartz said he would prefer the storage distance and an occupied dwelling be increased to 2,000 feet measured horizontally rather than the 1,250-foot distance that was in the bill.
After discussion, the commissioners unanimously voted to approve the change.
Commissioner J. Travis Breeding requested a second amendment that would require the storage not to be within 500 feet of a well. This way, it would allow property owners to move wells somewhere else on their property to be 500 feet away from stored residuals to not contaminate water sources.
Commissioner Larry Porter brought up the discussion of postponing voting on the act until the Maryland Department of Agriculture shares their regulations. The vote had been postponed at the prior two meetings so the commissioners could review the proposed amendments to the legislation.
Breeding said there would not be a need to postpone for regulation changes because commissioners are acting well within the parameters of Maryland statue.
"There's only so much that the Department of Agriculture can do," Breeding said. "Everything that we have done inside of this legislature is not in conflict with the statue that the state has."
The bill was unanimously approved by the commissioners and has been enacted into the county law.

title: '“We are praying we can rebuild': Crash causes extensive damage to historic Jeffers Chapel
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
'“We are praying we can rebuild': Crash causes extensive damage to historic Jeffers Chapel

 September 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 393
 Words 

 Read News Document

 SUDLERSVILLE — Shortly before 5:30 p.m. Sept. 3, Maryland State Police Centreville Barrack troopers responded to Route 300 at Benton Corner Road for reports of a two-vehicle crash, according to police.A Ford F-350 with an attached trailer was traveling east on Route 300 when a Nissan NV failed to stop at a stop sign on Benton Corner Road and struck the side of the Ford, a preliminary investigation found.
The impact caused the trailer to uncouple from the Ford and come to rest in a grassy area along Route 300. The Ford spun and went rear-first into the building at Jeffers Chapel, police said.
The Nissan overturned onto its driver's side, and the driver was taken by ambulance to Christiana Hospital. No other injuries were reported, according to police.
"A truck took out the whole front side of the building," Jeffers Chapel trustee Lisa Kennedy said, calling the incident "devastating for my whole family."
"We are praying we can rebuild and fix it," Kennedy said.
The one-room historic Black church was built around 1894 by her ancestors, she said. Jeffers Chapel was established in 1894 by local families, and the church and surrounding grounds are still cared for and maintained by descendants of the original founding families, according to Kennedy.
The church was originally affiliated with the United Methodist denomination but closed for regular services due to low membership. In 1995, it was incorporated as a non-denominational house of worship, she said.
The church now opens about once a year or for special occasions, and the fellowship was preparing to celebrate the 103rd homecoming, she said.
Kennedy credited first responders, including the Sudlersville Volunteer Fire Company, for swiftly stabilizing the building to prevent collapse and moving church items — including pews and bibles — into storage.
"It has just been an outpouring of help and we really, really appreciate it," she said.
Homecoming celebrations are still planned, with neighboring churches offering space for services or with outdoor tents, according to Kennedy.
The church is awaiting insurance and structural engineering reports to determine repair costs, she said.
"We are confident that our little chapel can be restored and we welcome prayers and monetary donations to ensure we are able to reopen for our Annual Homecoming in the near future," Kennedy said.
Support can be made via GoFundMe under the title "Support Jeffers Chapel's Restoration After Accident."
For more information about Jeffers Chapel, contact Lisa Kennedy at lisak2595@gmail.com

title: Striped bass limits will protect their future
author: ALLISON COLDEN
content:
Striped bass limits will protect their future

 May 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ALLISON COLDEN | Section: Columns 
 
 702
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This season anglers and commercial fishermen are following new striped bass limits in the Chesapeake Bay and along the Atlantic Coast.There's good reason.
Persistent concerns about low striped bass numbers led Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission this May to take additional steps to address the number of striped bass that are dying after being caught and released, as well as unsustainable commercial fishing rates.
The commission's latest steps aim to get rebuilding efforts back on track. We must face the hard truth that striped bass are struggling. Concerns stem from below average numbers recorded over last five years by Maryland's juvenile striped bass survey — an annual count of the number of young striped bass in Chesapeake tributaries. The 2023 count was dismal — the second-lowest since the survey began in 1957.
The Bay's commercial striped bass catch has seen a decline of about 40 percent from 2012 to 2022. Maryland and Virginia's commercial harvest totaled 4.5 million pounds in 2012 and just 2.7 million pounds in 2022, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
These numbers make it clear: Without action now, there might not be a striped bass fishery in the future.
NEW LIMITS
To address population concerns, the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission's Striped Bass Management Board voted at its spring meeting to establish a workgroup to reduce catch and release mortality. The workgroup will explore the effectiveness of season closures, impacts of different types of fishing tackle and the reduction in fishing effort needed to reduce striped bass losses.
Earlier this year, Maryland implemented emergency regulations to prohibit fishing for striped bass during crucial spring spawning times (April 1 through May 15). The state also closed fishing for striped bass during two weeks in late July, when fish are most likely to get stressed and die after release.
To meet additional the commission's requirements, all Atlantic Coast states implemented a one-fish limit for recreational anglers. In the Chesapeake Bay, keepers must measure between 19 and 24 inches.
States also implemented a 7 percent reduction in the commercial harvest.
LEAVE THE BIG FISH
What has everyone so concerned is the lack of smaller striped bass present in the Bay. The last time we saw a strong group of young striped bass was back in 2015 — which are the big fish being caught today. We must leave these fish in the water to reproduce and rebuild the striped bass population. As a recent Maryland DNR study shows, older, larger female striped bass produce far more eggs. There's extra risk in hot months when the water is warm and holds less oxygen, making catch and release mortality rates are high. When air temperatures are above 95 degrees, about 17 percent of shallow hooked striped bass died after release, according to a Maryland DNR study.
Anglers in Maryland who care about striped bass can take the following steps to help ensure the fishery's future:
Avoid targeting striped bass during summer (June through August) when high water temperatures stress fish and make them less likely to survive being caught. Anglers can reference Maryland DNR's Striped Bass Advisory Forecast to determine if air and water temperatures are safe.Practice careful catch and release tactics, such as using barbless circle hooks, keeping fish in the water, and supporting fish with two hands if handling.Try fishing for other species, such as invasives like blue catfish or snakehead. The upper Bay and its tributaries are prime for targeting pickerel, white perch, and yellow perch. In higher salinity areas, anglers can target cobia, red drum, speckled trout, Spanish mackerel, and many other species.
1980s MORATORIUM
Forty years ago, striped bass numbers reached a crisis point. Fishery regulators implemented a moratorium that shut down Maryland's striped bass fishery from 1985 to 1989. Striped bass numbers rebounded through the 1990s, and the moratorium is considered a major success story for fisheries management.
But there are new factors challenging the current recovery of striped bass, including climate change, pollution, habitat loss, invasive species and overfishing. New fishing limits are one of the most immediate, effective actions that can be taken to rebuild striped bass numbers.
Making these sacrifices today will help us avoid another moratorium and ensure that the striped bass fishery has a future.
Allison Colden is the Maryland executive director of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Gag order in Trump trial is wrong - COMMENTARY
author: David Harsanyi
content:
Gag order in Trump trial is wrong - COMMENTARY

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: David Harsanyi | Page: 6 | Section: Opinions 
 
 704
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This week, U.S. District Court Judge Tanya Chutkan overseeing United States v. Donald Trump issued a gag order prohibiting a leading presidential candidate, Donald Trump, from engaging in speech aimed at "government staff," among others, during his trial.Listen, I understand the disdain some conservatives feel for the former president. I share the sentiment.But if you're cheering on a judge who's inhibiting political speech on rickety grounds, you're no friend of "democracy" or the Constitution."Mr. Trump may still vigorously seek public support as a presidential candidate, debate policies and people related to that candidacy, criticize the current administration and assert his belief that this prosecution is politically motivated," Chutkan explained. "But those critical First Amendment freedoms do not allow him to launch a pre-trial smear campaign against participating government staff, their families and foreseeable witnesses."Who is Chutkan to dictate the contours of a presidential candidate's political speech? What if one of the "participating government staff" or a family member is compromised by partisanship?Moreover, preemptively suggesting that without gagging, Trump will engage in a "smear campaign" is as prejudicial to the case as any of the inflammatory things Trump has thrown around. It implies that any accusation now aimed at prosecutors is untrue.Trump contends that he is being railroaded by special counsel Jack Smith, the longtime federal prosecutor who works on behalf of Democrats and President Joe Biden. You might believe the special counsel is a chaste defender of Lady Justice, but there's ample evidence that partisan considerations are in play. Fears of a politicized Justice Department are real. As we speak, the head of the Democratic Party is being mollycoddled by the state in a very similar case involving classified documents.Whatever the case, the Justice Department now plays a big part in Trump's campaign for the presidency - and probably his legal case, as well.If the state's accusations can be spread throughout the media before a trial, why can't the defendant speak openly, as well?In the name of fairness, Chutkan contends that Trump does not enjoy unfettered First Amendment rights because he might intimidate witnesses.It's already illegal to intimidate witnesses.Charge him if he does it. Laws already exist to cover all the other premises Smith has used to rationalize the gag order.The notion that a jury pool is going to be impartial in a trial involving a divisive former president, who is not only a leading contender for the presidency but one of the most famous people on Earth, is absurd. And the notion a D.C. jury pool will be impartial when it comes to Trump is fantastical. There is little that can be done about it. But further gagging the defendant only feeds, at the very minimum, the perception that this is all politically motivated.Establishment media informs us that the gag order is just "narrow" and meant to "protect the integrity of the trial and the jury pool." In her Solomonic wisdom, Chutkan cut the state's request in half. A "narrow" gag order limiting free speech is still a gag order limiting free speech. The fact that Smith was seeking even broader limitations only makes Trump's claims more plausible.Smith has argued that Trump should not be afforded "special treatment" because he's a candidate. He's right. No one's right to defend themselves or to engage in speech should be inhibited, not even during trials (though any good lawyer will tell clients, for their own good, to shut up). Still, gag orders are almost always an unconstitutional prior restraint. For years, the American Civil Liberties Union and similar groups argued the same.I'm sure many people simply believe Trump deserves it. Think, though, about the precedent: Administrations can now launch prosecutions against political rivals - calibrated to take place in favorable cities and timed to coincide with elections - and then demand gag orders be implemented on those running for office. If you think they won't do it to others, you haven't been paying attention.David Harsanyi is a senior editor at The Federalist. Harsanyi is a nationally syndicated columnist and author of five books - the most recent, "Eurotrash: Why America Must Reject the Failed Ideas of a Dying Continent." His work has appeared in National Review, the Wall Street Journal, Washington Post, Reason, New York Post and numerous other publications. Follow him on Twitter@davidharsanyi. COPYRIGHT 2023 CREAT ORS.COM

title: Festival of Trees readies for 38th year of fundraising - November event benefits Talbot Hospice
content:
Festival of Trees readies for 38th year of fundraising - November event benefits Talbot Hospice

 September 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A12 | Section: News 
 
 318
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In 1986, when the Festival of Trees was a fledgling organization, Midge (Fuller) Menzies and Leslie Ware could hardly have dreamed that it would be going strong 38 years later.Festival of Trees has been so successful that Friends of Hospice has donated over $3.7 million to the Talbot Hospice Foundation, all generated from the annual Festival of Trees event.Each year the theme changes and events may vary, but the mission stays the same: to raise monies to benefit hospice patients and their families in Talbot County by hosting an annual fundraising event and to bring awareness to community members about Hospice Care.Today, Midge and Leslie continue to support the event they started, serving on the board of directors as well as on various committees.Leslie sums it up this way, "Never did Midge and I imagine that our community would embrace and support us to the extent that they did.(Festival of Trees) would not only become a part of our community for 38 years, but also raise almost $4 million that has provided compassionate care and support for the terminally ill and their families in our community." Presented by Friends of Hospice, the 38th Festival of Trees will take place in Easton on Nov. 25-28.This year's Victorian theme is "Caroling, Caroling Through the Town." Events include Festival of Trees, which is held in the Tidewater Inn, as well as Carols by Candlelight, Santa 5K Run, a Poinsettia Sale, a Santa's Workshop and more.Festival of Trees is the largest fundraiser for the Friends of Hospice to benefit Talbot Hospice. To get involved in any capacity, big or small, contact Festival of Trees Chairman Karla Wieland-Cherry at dkcherry4@aol.com or 410-310-8421.Prefer to help by way of a sponsorship? Visit festival-of-trees.org to learn more.

title: Residents want Federalsburg to keep promises of transparency
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Residents want Federalsburg to keep promises of transparency

 July 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 599
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — After a 50-minute explanation from town officials about mounting issues in Federalsburg, the community spent over an hour and a half voicing concerns.The town addressed issues like misappropriation of town funds, employee resignations, $5 million of debt, water and wastewater treatment issues and police department cost, offering transparency that residents have said was lacking.
Federalsburg Mayor Kim Abner hopes this community forum is a step in the right direction for the town.
"I think that it went well," Abner said about the meeting. "I mean, it went as good as it can be expected. The problem is that a lot of stuff gets posted on Facebook that isn't true. We were trying to set the record straight about some other things that have happened. We're trying to be more transparent about what is going on down at Town Hall, and we want the public to be engaged."
During Monday's meeting, residents voiced multiple times that the town needed to maintain more open communication with the public.
Eric Padgett, business owner and owner of multiple properties in Federalsburg, spoke passionately about the town's issues and about the good in the town.
"I've been walking around town. I watch everything that's going on. Nobody is held accountable for nothing," Padgett said. "Count the town managers, every ... one of them have never walked around, drove around, asked anybody any questions about nothing. … The town needs to open up at 7 a.m. and close at 5 p.m. so these people who have a problem can go in there and do something about it."
A proposal to have the Caroline County Sheriff's Office take over policing duties for the town garnered a lot of back-and-forth among residents.
Former Police Chief Donald Nagel spoke on the topic by asking how important police protection was to the residents by show of hands. All residents raised their hand indicating it was important.
"I worked in this town 24 years or whatever, and it was rough, and we had to bring it back, and we brought it back," Nagel said. "I'm not here for any accolades or anything. I just know this town by word. You're not going to get the same service by having the sheriff's department in here that you have now. People know you're police officers, so please, don't do away with the police."
Multiple residents thought differently about the police department. Some indicated the Sheriff's Office could offer better coverage to the town.
Residents who spoke agreed on that property tax prices, wastewater problems and lack of transparency from the town government were pressing issues.
Resident Danielle Brodka acknowledged the town's efforts to be transparent, but without work, she doesn't believe the town residents' anger will change.
"Is it a wonder that everyone in this building is angry because there is so much that has been addressed?" Brodka said.
"I don't want you to think that I'm saying it's each one of you individuals," she said to town officials. "You all have different tenure, you all have different goals. But is it any wonder that everybody in this building is upset because there is a lot going on."
Brodka and many other residents in the room expressed their support of the town's plan to hold quarterly meetings like the one Monday.
"I am glad that you are going to have quarterly meetings because they are absolutely necessary," she said. "I am glad that you are telling me that there is going to be more follow through. But until we see it, I don't think anyone's going to believe it. I think this town is going to continue to be angry until we have results."

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/Aug. 4
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/Aug. 4

 August 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 623
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Aug. 4, 2020, nearly 3,000 tons of ammonium nitrate that had been improperly stored for years in the port of Beirut, Lebanon, exploded, killing more than 200 people, injuring more than 7,000 and devastating nearby neighborhoods; it was one of the largest non-nuclear explosions ever recorded.Also on this date:
In 1790, the U.S. Coast Guard had its beginnings as President George Washington signed a measure authorizing a group of revenue cutters to enforce tariff and trade laws and prevent smuggling.
In 1916, the United States reached agreement with Denmark to purchase the Danish Virgin Islands for $25 million in gold.
In 1936, Jesse Owens of the United States won the second of his four gold medals at the Berlin Olympics as he prevailed in the long jump over German Luz Long, who was the first to congratulate him.
In 1944, 15-year-old diarist Anne Frank was arrested with her sister, parents and four others by the Gestapo after hiding for two years inside a building in Amsterdam. (Anne and her sister, Margot, died at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp.)
In 1960, Burkina Faso (known then as Upper Volta) declared its independence from France after more than 60 years of colonial rule.
In 1964, 44 days after their murders, the bodies of missing civil rights workers James Chaney, Andrew Goodman and Michael Schwerner were found buried in an earthen dam in Mississippi.
In 1972, Arthur Bremer was convicted and sentenced in Upper Marlboro, Maryland, to 63 years in prison for his attempt on the life of Alabama Gov. George C. Wallace (the sentence was later reduced to 53 years; Bremer was released from prison in 2007).
In 1977, President Jimmy Carter signed a measure establishing the Department of Energy.
In 1984, the album "Purple Rain," by Prince and the Revolution, began its 24-week run at the top of the Billboard 200 record chart.
In 1987, the Federal Communications Commission voted 4-0 to abolish the Fairness Doctrine, which required radio and television stations to present balanced coverage of controversial issues.
In 1993, a federal judge sentenced Los Angeles police officers Stacey Koon and Laurence Powell to 2 1/2 years in prison for violating Rodney King's civil rights.
In 2009, North Korean leader Kim Jong Il pardoned American journalists Laura Ling and Euna Lee for entering the country illegally and ordered their release during a surprise visit by former U.S. President Bill Clinton.
In 2017, former pharmaceutical CEO Martin Shkreli, who became notorious for a price-gouging scandal, was convicted on federal charges that he deceived investors in a pair of failed hedge funds. (Shkreli was later sentenced to seven years in prison; he was released in 2022.)
In 2019, a masked gunman fired on revelers enjoying summer nightlife in a popular entertainment district of Dayton, Ohio, leaving nine people dead and 27 wounded; police said officers shot and killed the shooter within 30 seconds of the start of his rampage.
Today's Birthdays: Actor-singer Tina Cole is 82. Football Hall of Famer John Riggins is 76. Former Attorney General Alberto Gonzales is 70. Actor-screenwriter Billy Bob Thornton is 70. Actor Kym Karath (Film: "The Sound of Music") is 67. Hall of Fame track star Mary Decker Slaney is 67. Actor Lauren Tom is 64. Former President Barack Obama is 64. Retired MLB All-Star pitcher Roger Clemens is 63. Actor Crystal Chappell is 60. Author Dennis Lehane is 60. Actor Daniel Dae Kim is 57. Actor Michael DeLuise is 56. Former race car driver Jeff Gordon is 54. Rapper-actor Yo-Yo is 54. R&B singer-actor Marques Houston is 44. Britain's Duchess of Sussex, the former actor Meghan Markle, is 44. Actor Abigail Spencer is 44. Actor/director Greta Gerwig is 42. Country singer Crystal Bowersox (TV: "American Idol") is 40. Actors Dylan and Cole Sprouse are 33. Singer Jessica Sanchez (TV: "American Idol") is 30.

title: A battle royal at the library
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
A battle royal at the library

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Life 
 
 810
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I'm pretty sure I have William Shakespeare and Bernard Cornwell to thank for the fact the battle of Agincourt has long fascinated me, for it was after I read Cornwell's novel of the same title and saw Shakespeare's "Henry V" that I began to seriously ponder that battle's many imponderables. These are, in no particular order:In 1415, Henry V of England attacked France. His first goal, the seizure of the fortified town of Harfleur, took much longer than expected. By the time the city's garrison surrendered, Henry had lost a sizable number of his troops to disease, probably cholera.
Now, knowing that the king of France had sent a great host to drive the English from his realm, Henry's only hope—if he was to avoid the destruction of his army and his own capture and imprisonment—was to race all the way across northern France toward the safety of the English-held town of Calais.
But before he set off on this desperate march through miserable weather, he had to weaken his army even further by leaving enough men behind to defend Harfleur, the prize won at such great cost.
For a while the two armies played cat and mouse, but, eventually, near a village called Agincourt, the French managed to place their much larger force between the English and the road to Calais.
By this time the English force was on half-rations, so the soldiers that faced the French the next the morning (Oct. 25, 1415) were hungry, exhausted and riven by disease (it is believed that the dysentery was so bad among Henry's troops that some of them went into action that day sans culotte).
Looking at the odds—a well-fed, armor-clad French army of at least 15,000 men against an English force of, at best, 7,000, all of them half-starved and some half-naked—it's easy to see why everyone expected a great slaughter of Englishmen.
Yet the English not only carried the day, they killed so many Frenchmen that it took that country's nobility nearly a century to recover its numbers and sort out the property transfers necessitated by so great a mortality.
Authorities disagree on the precise numbers, but there is no doubt that thousands of Frenchmen died that day, while contemporaneous accounts claim only 30 English dead.
Thousands vs. 30. You would have thought Henry V had machine guns at his disposal, not bows and arrows.
And if such a lopsided English victory isn't enough to make you scratch your head in wonder, there's one final conundrum that never fails to intrigue me: despite numerous attempts to do so, no archaeological evidence of the battle has ever been found—no hastily dug graves, no broken sword hilts, no dented helmets, not even so much as a thrown horseshoe.
Despite the fact that, for centuries to come, the British would celebrate the victory and the French lament it, as far as professional archaeology is concerned, it never took place.
And so it was that, when I learned Michael Livingston, a professor at The Citadel, had written a new book about the battle, I immediately did two things: (1) I used the "Suggest a Title" option on the Talbot County Free Library's website to ask our acquisitions librarian to purchase a copy for Talbot's collection, and (2) using our inter-library loan system, I ordered a copy for myself from the Anne Arundel County Public Library.
I won't give away any of his conclusions, but I can tell you Livingston's exhaustive research has led him to propose a new site for the location of the battle (which, if he's correct, should solve the missing artifacts dilemma) and an English battle plan that helps explain Henry's improbable victory without making the French look like fools.
But Livingston's book does more than just solve the many mysteries surrounding Agincourt.
It ends up being an extended lesson in not just history but the making of history: how we study the past; how, in telling and retelling it, various biases inevitably slip into the narrative and how our view of the past is just as inevitably colored by our present, the intellectual paradigm that structures our study.
Perhaps just as interesting, and far more disturbing, the book—which spares none of the senses in describing close quarters combat between men wielding axes, hammers, halberds and flails—makes us wonder, yet again, how rational human beings can so willingly engage in war (it was the older men, the veterans who had already experienced such battles, who were the most eager that day to enter the fray).
Finally, Livingston's "Agincourt: Battle of the Scarred King" is a good story, well told. I brought the thing home from the library on a Friday and finished reading it before the fire on Sunday afternoon.
By the time this column is published, the Talbot County Free Library will own its own copy of Livingston's book. You should be able to find it on the New Books shelf at 944.0254 LIVI. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: The newly renovated Oaks Waterfront Hotel
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
The newly renovated Oaks Waterfront Hotel

 February 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Life 
 
 446
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Oaks Waterfront Hotel in Talbot county recently reopened after a $10 million renovation.Two years ago, owners Tracy and Scott Wagner purchased the historic property and were ready to make a change. Together with their daughter Quin Warner and son-in-law Andy Warner, they transformed the hotel into a thriving family business venture.
"Well, we don't know how to have dinner together and not talk about work. But it's enjoyable," Quin Warner said. "We all have the same vision… we're fully ingrained. We love it. And we have ideas, and it's just how we're going to execute these ideas. We all balance each other out, too."
Quin Warner functions as business manager, and Andy Warner acts as general manager. Together, they balance all the weddings and significant events that keep the hotel booked.
The recently renovated Oaks Hotel dates back to the 17th Century. The entire plot consisted of 740 acres, and over the years, the property transformed into a premier waterfront venue for wedding receptions.
Included in the renovation were interior and exterior changes to the main building. An additional four cottages were built on the property, and over 200 mature trees were planted.
But most importantly, the hotel's owners said, they sought ways to improve accessibility. Scott Wagner explained that they wanted to provide ways for potential grandparents to enjoy the weddings and family reunions often booked on the property.
They installed an elevator, created accessible handicap rooms and renovated the dock to make it easier to use for everyone.
Tracy Wagner describes the vision for the hotel as being comfortable and a fun place to welcome guests and locals alike.
Andy Warner said the community has embraced them, and they have enjoyed hosting events for locals, including holding Easter, Thanksgiving and Christmas dinners, hosting burger nights and galas, and opening the restaurant and bar to locals on Wednesday and Thursday nights.
"We have the best burgers in town, by the way," Andy Warner said, beaming with pride.
Last December, they hosted a Christmas party of between 350 and 400 people. Scott Wagner described the experience as akin to a reunion. Contractors, families, friends and people from every walk of life joined in the fun.
Overall, the owners look forward to having guests discover the beauty of the Eastern Shore. Whether walking through St. Michaels and Oxford or biking through nature, there's something for everyone, they said.
"We've done this for you. We've done this for Talbot County," Tracy said. "We've done this for the brides, for the parents of the bride. And we are proud of this. And we are proud that we've had this opportunity to bring this to Talbot County and to keep this historical place. We've given it a whole new life."
