title: A better option for promoting Chesapeake Bay tourism
author: DAVID REEL
content:
A better option for promoting Chesapeake Bay tourism

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 827
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A consortium of five Maryland counties — Anne Arundel, Calvert, Queen Anne's, St. Mary's and Somerset, recently released results of a $250,000 feasibility study on a new Chesapeake Bay passenger ferry system.The study concludes that passenger-only ferries — not vehicle-carrying ferries — serving Annapolis, Baltimore and the Eastern Shore destinations of Easton, Cambridge, Rock Hall, Kent Narrows, St. Michaels, Oxford, Chestertown and Crisfield are feasible.
Members of the consortium and other supporters of this new ferry system are well intentioned. The ferry feasibility study looks good on paper.
Upon closer scrutiny of the Aug. 24 executive summary of the consortium's feasibility study, there are a number of unanswered questions. There is also one alternative that should be thoroughly evaluated before proceeding further. The questions and alternative include:
Why does the consortium only have two Eastern Shore counties — Queen Anne's and Somerset?
Who will pay for projected start-up costs for a base line system requiring at least $8 million in ferry boat acquisitions and up to $5 million in necessary infrastructure improvements such as docks, passenger shelters, restrooms and attraction shuttle services at system destinations before ferry operations can begin?
Who will pay for projected $5 million in annual operating costs for a baseline system that will be only partially offset by the feasibility studies "suggestion" that 50,000 ferry passenger riders will generate $2.5 million in revenue in the first season of operation?
What is this suggestion of 50,000 riders based on?
Who will cover this deficit if passenger revenue is below projections?
What assurances are there this new venture will not replicate the historical record of cost overruns during start up and post start overruns on new transportation projects?
Where do the 67% of individuals live, who responded to a consortium-sponsored survey who expressed interest in the ferry service?
Where do the 62% of community partners live and/or operate, who have expressed interest in engaging activities for visitors to and residents of proposed ferry destinations?
Were survey respondents made fully aware that a new ferry system would not carry vehicles and would thus likely have a minimal impact at best on enormous amounts of vehicular traffic going to and from Ocean City every year?
Are consortium partners and supporters planning on state or local or government funding, for start-up and post start-up operating expenses? If so, how much?
Are they acknowledging the following current and projected fiscal realities in Maryland? The state and local governments in Maryland are facing significant challenges in funding current programs including the Blueprint for Maryland's Future (Kirwan Plan). Current projections are the state deficit will be $1 billion in 2026 and 2027, $3.5 billion in 2028, and $4 billion in 2029. Maryland also has a deficit in the state six-year transportation plan deficit that does not yet reflect the loss in toll revenue after the Key Bridge collapse and the yet to be finalized amount of state funding needed to rebuild that bridge. Earlier this week, the state proposed new cuts of cutting $1.3 billion from the six-year transportation plan after previous cuts of $ 3.3 billion to the plan a year ago, cuts that were partially restored by tapping the state's "rainy day" fund and increasing vehicle registration fees. Gov. Moore recently told Maryland Association of Counties Summer Conference attendees, all new state spending will be facing "extreme scrutiny."
Is it realistic to assume state and local funding for the launch and operation of a new Bay ferry service will be a priority or even considered in Annapolis or with local governments in the near future, if ever?
Has the consortium and supporters of more ferry service on the Chesapeake Bay given serious evaluation of an alternative to meet the goal of a new ferry service to promote tourism that could also help an endangered Chesapeake Bay way of life to survive and hopefully thrive?
There are over 400 charter boats registered in Maryland.
Operators of these charter boats have been and are dealing with extraordinary hardships due to new state regulations limiting the size and number of rockfish that can be caught by recreational fishing enthusiasts who historically come from within Maryland and beyond.
Charter boats could be more heavily promoted by destination marketing organization in the Chesapeake Bay region for Bay pleasure cruises. Charter boats can take clients anywhere they want to go, whenever they want to go, and for as long or as short a time as they want to go.
Charter boat operators also can provide data on the actual demand for Bay cruises that may or may not match data from the consortium's surveys on the demand for passenger ferry boats.
The next best step for the consortium is to meet with a representative group of charter boat captains to discuss their interest in, capacity for, and feasibility of providing more pleasure cruises on the bay. Charter boats could be a cost-effective alternative to a new, costly and unproven Chesapeake Bay passenger ferry system as the way to generate more tourism and economic benefits for the Eastern Shore and the entire Chesapeake Bay region.

title: County approves budget transfers for Talbot schools
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
County approves budget transfers for Talbot schools

 June 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 350
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Public Schools brought a request to the county council Tuesday evening to make categorical transfers in its fiscal year 2024 budget.Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones explained to council members that the district is looking to balance its FY25 budget by moving some items to FY24 as the fiscal year wraps up this month. This includes prepayments and covering for anticipated overages.
Jones asked for approval to transfer $75,000 to student services, in part for prepayments on software, and $500,000 to transportation to prepay upcoming bus lease payments.
The district also asked to transfer $600,000 to fixed charges for other postemployment benefits contributions and health insurance prepayments.
"We're just trying to make headway there because we're very far behind on that liability," Jones said of the benefits payments.
To balance the budget, Jones requested that savings from three categories — instructional salaries, special education and interfund transfer to capital projects — be used to transfer the funds. Notably, there was $850,000 saved in instructional salaries.
"Whenever we're transferring out of instructional salaries, it always raises an eyebrow," Council Vice President Pete Lesher said. "Because of course that savings comes from vacant positions."
" … I'm curious what the plan is to fill those positions for the coming years so that we don't see that loss in direct student contact," Lesher said.
Jones said the district has a director of recruitment and retention. She also mentioned that having mentors for teachers has been "very helpful for retention of newly-hired staff."
"I think a little bit of the savings are a reflection of us having grant availability this year," Jones added. " … If money frees up in a grant and it's appropriate to charge a teacher or part of a teacher salary, we're going to use that money."
"It's comforting to know that you're being intentional about ensuring that those positions will get filled," Lesher said. " … The success of the schools is one of our most powerful economic development tools. When the schools succeed, it helps all the other businesses, everybody else who's looking to hire in this community."
The council approved the request unanimously.

title: Joyce Ann Tracy (Hignutt)
content:
Joyce Ann Tracy (Hignutt)

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 11 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 176
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO - Joyce Ann Tracy of Greensboro passed away on November 09, 2023. She was 80.Born on April 18,1943, in Easton, MD., she was the daughter of the late Anna Hignutt.Joyce grew up in Greensboro and left high school in the 11th grade to go to work. She worked in the Greensboro Restaurant, then at the Highway Diner in Federalsburg and the Circus Restaurant. She worked at technacontrol making circuit boards. Joyce loved to play bingo and watch horseraces. She loved WWE wrestling; Roman Reins was her favorite wrestler.Joyce is survived by her daughters, Gloria Kinnamon, April Lahman, and Joyce Tracy; brother William "Bill" Hignutt; ten grandchildren; sixteen great grandchildren, and two great-great Grandchildren.She was predeceased by her Son Harvard Tracy II; Great grandson Christopher Rogers; Great granddaughter Evelyn Lahman; and three siblings Laurence "Bunk" Hignutt, Carol "Tink" Hignutt, Cora Lee Miner.A service will be held at a later date.In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Jude's Childrens Hospital Cancer Research.Online condolences may be made at www.fleeglenandhelfenbein.com

content:
Web links

 Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 133
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Retta is undaunted by seriously ugly domiciles as she tours properties that were nominated based on gaudy designs, botched renovations and amazingly terrible taste. Four homes look for the title of "worst" in this new episode from Season 4 of "Ugliest House in America," airing Monday, August 7, on HGTV. title: Embodiment of public service
author: Staff Writer
content:
Embodiment of public service

 April 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 180
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Why is Don Abbatiello the best choice for Easton Town Council president?The answer lies in where you will and will not find Don.
Not at glitzy fundraisers with outside interest groups, nor racing around town for every photo op. You won't find him glad-handing politicians.
You will find him helping students in the classroom, jumping on a firetruck to protect lives. You will find him seated in the Easton Town Council Chambers asking thoughtful questions, listening and sharing well-reasoned opinions that benefit our community.
His modest campaign is funded by individuals who live in our town, not political parties or out- of-town businesses.
Don does not seek to be council president as a steppingstone to a larger political career. He is answering a call to fill a well-documented leadership gap and to further serve the town he loves.
Don is the embodiment of public service. He shows up and gets the job done, prioritizing the residents of our community and working with local business to keep Easton a great place to live.
On May 6, at the Easton Fire Hall, vote for Don Abbatiello.
VICKI CARUTHERS
Easton

title: Lions move closer to first North Bayside title in program history
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Lions move closer to first North Bayside title in program history

 April 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 1285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — The walls of Queen Anne's County High's gymnasium are plastered with banners celebrating past champions in just about every sport.But with the exception of the banner commemorating head coach Dee Fisher's 200th career victory last year, girls tennis is not represented on the gym walls.
"Girls tennis doesn't have anything," said Lucy Taylor, Queen Anne's No. 1 singles player. "Sometimes those posters are kind of behind (in being updated). And we joke that it's like a forgotten sport. But we're out here showing we can win stuff too."
The Lions have shown they can win quite often this year.
It started in the season-opener, when Queen Anne's ended Kent Island's impressive 102-match win streak against Bayside Conference competition. The Lions defeated the six-time defending Bayside champions again Friday by a 7-0 count, this one moving them within a victory of their first North Bayside title in school history.
"At the beginning of the season we had like an inter-squad scrimmage and that was like the best thing ever," Fisher said after his team improved to 11-1 overall, 9-0 North. "Because when I matched them up they were just pushing each other."
What has also helped is having players who have won conference or division titles in other sports this school year.
"I have volleyball players who had a great (Bayside title) team," Fisher said. "Basketball players who had a great (North Bayside title) team. Field hockey players that had a great (Bayside championship) team. Soccer (which won the North Bayside). So I have a team of winners basically. They win at every sport they play. So it kind of trickled over to tennis."
But Fisher admitted he did not see this coming after graduating nine seniors last year, most of which made up his starting lineup.
"We had a full team of juniors and sophomores," Fisher said. "So this was going to be my get-them-used-to-playing year. Next year would be the year.
"A lot of the players hadn't played doubles and singles," Fisher said of his team. "So this was a chance to get their feet wet. But our program has a lot of girls, so I always try to build that up through exhibition. I'm always encouraging exhibition matches, lot of practice, and just having fun."
In the process, Fisher's get-them-used-to-playing year has turned into the get-them-used-to-winning year."
Queen Anne's got an early start on that Friday, sweeping doubles play for a 3-0 lead. Lucy Taylor and sister Meg Taylor, who have lost only once this season, defeated Jamie Tranquill and Isabelle Gamez, 8-2 at No. 1. The No. 2 tandem of Hayden Legg and Marylee Kline put together a similar 8-2 result over Gianna Tamburo and Taylor Harding. Sydney Pinder and Kara Ringold completed the sweep with an 8-4 win over Grace Turner and Jasleen Paquer.
"Last year we lost, what, nine seniors?" Lucy Taylor asked. "Most of which were in the lineup. This year, Hayden and Marylee have both come so far, and they have been able to pick up big wins for us. The same with Sydney and Kara. I think it's just like, keep building on those skills we learned freshman year. It's just amazing how much everyone has grown."
Queen Anne's lead continued to grow through singles play.
Meg Taylor defeated Gamez, 8-4, at No. 2. Legg was an 8-4 winner over Tamburo, and Kline earned an 8-2 win over Harding.
In the marathon match of the afternoon, Lucy Taylor, who lost both her singles matches earlier in the week, fell behind 3-0 to Tranquill. This wasn't exactly anything new for the Lions' No. 1, who rallied from a 4-0 deficit to win when her and Tranquill met in the season-opener.
"I was just thinking, 'I've done this before. I can get it back,'" Lucy Taylor said. "I used the same mentality I did last time which is just like, one point at a time, one game at a time. And then I was able to build off of that."
Taylor rallied to take an 8-7 lead, but Tranquill showed she too could battle back, pulling even at 8-8 to force a tiebreaker.
"This time was a little harder because we went back and forth so many times," said Taylor, who won the tiebreaker 9-7. "This one really felt good."
A win over visiting Easton on Tuesday or against Cambridge-South Dorchester on Wednesday clinches the division title for Queen Anne's.
Do the Lions feel any pressure one victory shy of history?
"I think they don't think about it," Fisher said smiling. "I think they just go out and just play hard and have fun. No. We really don't talk about it.
"This is our throw-away year," Fisher said, referring back to this being a season of preparation for next year. "I don't know how to explain it. We just go with the flow."
Primarily an exhibition player, junior captain Sydnee Carr said it's been a joy to be on the ride toward a potential first division title.
"It's hard for me to speak on it because I'm typically an exhibition player," said Carr, who has won all her doubles matches when Fisher has inserted into the starting lineup. "But it has been fun to watch everybody improve. Definitely Hayden and Lucy and Marylee. Just seeing them come out the past two years and improve in so many ways, and then be able to be in the starting lineup and excel is really fun to watch.
"Being on the field hockey team and being on the swim team, our teams have a lot of banners," Carr continued. "So it will be fun to see my third sport be represented up on the wall."
GIRLS LACROSSE
SSPP 21, SALISBURY SCHOOL 3
SALISBURY — Sophomore Caroline Ewing scored five goals and set up another, and senior Morgan Quade distributed nine assists and scored twice Friday, as Saints Peter and Paul won its 10th straight.
Eden Zimmerman had four goals and Kendall Kroniser (assist), Avery McCall (two assists) and Eryn Callahan (assist) each recorded hat tricks for the Sabres (10-1, 6-0 Eastern Shore Independent Athletic Conference). Kate Sweeney (goal) and Emery Zimmerman had two assists apiece.
NORTH CAROLINE 18, CAMBRIDGE-SD 2
CAMBRIDGE — Calleigh Tribbett and Ashlynn Bisesi (assist) each notched hat tricks Friday to pace the Bulldogs to their second straight victory.
Riley Walstrum (two assists), Ashley Kercheval (three assists), Maddie Mcninch, Reece Bisesi and Mia Schreyer had two goals apiece for North Caroline (7-3), and Claire Blue and Gracie Faulkner had one each.
SOFTBALL
QUEEN ANNE'S 6, KENT ISLAND 1
CENTREVILLE — Hannah Martin pitched a complete-game three-hitter Thursday, striking out 12 and walking just one as the Lions remained atop the North Bayside with North Dorchester and Easton.
Autumn Huber had one hit and three RBIs for Queen Anne's (13-1, 5-1) and Morgan Gottleib, Caroline Taylor, Camaryn Jacobi, Emily Rendulic and Reese Brooks each had one hit.
Bri Kurtz, Abbie Mahaffey (RBI) and Sena Koch had one hit apiece for Kent Island
ST. MICHAELS 22, KENT COUNTY 6
ST. MICHAELS — Madi White was 3 for 3 with a double, three RBIs and three runs, and Myla Ramey was 3 for 4 with three runs Thursday as the Saints (6-9, 2-5) ended a three-game skid.
Mercy Haddaway earned the win, striking out three and walking five.
St. Michaels' Brooke Reilly was 2 for 4 with three runs scored, Lily Haddaway was 2 for 3, scoring two runs, Brianna Crow went 2 for 4 with three runs scored, Lola Browning was 3 for 5 with two RBIs, and Katie Jenkins was 2 for 5 with a triple and a run scored.
BASEBALL
QUEEN ANNE'S 4, KENT ISLAND 3
CENTREVILLE — Evan Dickey was 4 for 4 with two RBIs, and Dalton Brown went 1 for 2, knocking in two runs as the Lions outlasted their county rival in nine innings.
Brown earned the win, going 3 2/3 innings. Dickey pitched 5 1/3 innings.

title: Mary Harrison
content:
Mary Harrison

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: Obituaries 
 
 333
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - It is with great sadness that the family of Mary Harrison announces her passing at Candle Light Cove on October 7, 2023 at 99 years hold.Mary was born on Talbot Street in St.Michaels. She graduated from St. Michaels High School and Salisbury State Teachers College and then taught first grade for two years in Linthicum Heights. Even though she only taught for two years, in her heart she always considered herself to be a teacher. Mary loved reading and doing crossword puzzles, and going to the library weekly for new books to read.She married Callaway Harrison in 1946 and together they owned and operated Covington Oil Company until their retirement. Later they embraced their love of antiques, working in antique shops in St. Michaels. They then traveled the East Coast doing antique shows before opening a shop in St. Michaels. Until she became ill, she owned Antiques on Talbot with Carol Kraznowiecki and Carol Burke. There she loved meeting and talking with customers from around the world.Mary is predeceased by her parents, Norman and Ethel Marshall; son Steve Harrison; and siblings Norman Marshall and Helen Spencer.Mary is survived by her daughter and sonin-law, Marsha and Tom Waudby. She is also survived by her two cherished grandchildren and their spouses, Jenny and Jonathan Boyd and Sam and Caroline Kemp. In addition, she is survived by her great-grandchildren Charlie Callaway Kemp and Lucy Grace Boyd. She is also survived by a special niece, Susie Brady.There will be a graveside service at Olivet Cemetery in St. Michaels on Thursday, October 12 at 4:00 p.m.Mary's family would like to thank the employees of Candle Light Cove for the loving care they gave her for her last five years, as well as Talbot Hospice for making the end of her life comfortable.If you wish to donate in Mary's memory, the family suggests donations be made to Talbot Hospice, 586 Cynwood Drive, Easton, MD 21601.Share memories with the family at www.framptom.com

title: Historical Society remembers Walsh, recalls accomplishments
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Historical Society remembers Walsh, recalls accomplishments

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 508
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - It was an evening of celebrating achievements as well as remembering once again a Caroline County stalwart who contributed much and, with his recent passing, left a huge void.At its annual meeting Oct. 3, the Caroline County Historical Society remembered the achievements and generosity of James Owen Knotts "J.O.K." Walsh, who succumbed to COVID July 13.About 50 members of the society gathered for evening cocktails and hors d'oeuvres at Caroline Country Club.Acting President Charles Andrew welcomed new members and acknowledged local officials, museum docents, leaders of sister historical societies in Preston, Federalsburg and Ridgely, as well as Friends of Linchester Mill.Members renewed the tenure of two directors and elected two more. New on the board are Randolph Moore and Walter Palmer, and staying on are Carolyn Spicher and Jo Ann Staples.With deep ancestral roots in the county, Walsh was elected president of the society in 1987. His mission was to preserve the history, stories and, if possible, structures within the county. Under his leadership, 47 structures were restored, with many serving as tourist destination sites.Treasurer Carolyn Spicher credited Walsh with the solid financial footing of $1.3 million in the treasury.Two donors presented paintings to the society.Caroline native Clarence B. Mollock of Preston brought his 1988 painting of the Mill Dam at Linchester, where he used to swim and fish.Candi Minner of Denton presented a painting of the old Caroline High School by Bill Greenly, a longtime member of the society.Society member Kathy Mackel, Walsh's longtime partner, presented the annual report in a slide show depicting the society's current work projects, including the renovation of the historic Denton Fire House as a heritage center.Diana Lapsley shared memories of Walsh in a tribute that concluded with a suggestion that the center be renamed the JOK Walsh Heritage Center.Calling it "an important legacy," Lapsley said this last project Walsh worked on "is to be an information research center, a meeting place, a further opportunity to illustrate all of the county's rich heritage, and also a place to help visitors and locals to explore, learn about and enjoy all the other Caroline County historical projects." Becoming emotional as she commemorated her friend's legacy, Lapsley said, "I personally thank JOK for his friendship and enthusiasm, tenacity, bravery and generosity, as I know well that, even when busy and under pressure, he would take time to visit, entertain and look after his friends." "My hope is that we will all continue to get the work done that he started," she said. Quoting her granddaughter when she learned of Walsh's passing, Lapsley said, "Who is going to tell the story of Caroline County now?" 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Caroline County native Clarence B. Mollock, left, of Preston donated his 1988 painting of the Mill Dam at Linchester, where he used to swim and fish, to the Caroline County Historical Society. Accepting the donation is Charles Andrew, acting president of the society.
 
CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Candid photos of the late JOK Walsh were displayed Oct. 3 at the Caroline County Historical Society's annual meeting.

title: Don't compare Trump to Hitler
author: Staff Writer
content:
Don't compare Trump to Hitler

 February 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 346
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I write in response to the Feb. 1, op-ed of Jim Bruce in which Trump is compared to Hitler in what has become the most boring cliché ever.We know you do not like Trump, Mr. Bruce, but is Hitler the only baddie in history that you can conjure up? And Hitler at the Reichstag, yet. What about Napoleon on the 18 Brumaire at Saint-Cloud in 1799? Oh, wait, Trump never conquered Europe nor invaded Russia like Napoleon, leading to the deaths of 6.5 million people.
What about Stalin at the 12th Congress of the Russian Communist Party in April 1923 in Moscow? Oh, that won't work either, since Stalin has been blamed for the deaths of 10 million people, maybe more, they don't know for sure. What about Mao at Tian'anmen on October 1, 1949? Oh no, because they now think that Mao and his policies may be responsible for 80 million fatalities; no one knows the exact amount.
The only similar number of deaths that we have had in America since Trump first won the 2016 election is the number of babies aborted, which is in the millions. But they don't count, do they? Plus abortion is not Trump's fault, although if Democrats did not love abortion they would find a way to blame him for it, as they do other things.
So please stop comparing Trump to a mass murderer like Hitler. It does not insult Trump because it is so absurd, but it does diminish the real victims of the real Nazis, whose bodies are still being recovered in mass graves throughout Eastern Europe.
As for the complaint about Trump's executive orders, what about all the executive orders given by Obama and Biden? So Democrat presidents can issue executive orders but when Trump does it somehow the Constitution is being violated? I say to all Democrats, especially to Gov. Wes Moore and his lament over the "chaos" in Washington (Star Democrat, Feb. 5), please focus on fixing the chaos your policies have caused in our schools and in our cities, where too often violence reigns.
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne

title: He was better off without his aces - Bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
He was better off without his aces - Bridge

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A15 | Section: News 
 
 291
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sometimes, you must wonder how long ago some of my deals were played. Occasionally, the bidding will tell you -- as here. North's double of three clubs was for penalty, not takeout, as it would be today.This old deal features a truly incredible defense -- one of the most imaginative ever. The deal was reported by Frenchman Jacques Blaizot, who was sitting West. He was in the Palace of Da Lat, partnering Bao Dai, then the Emperor of French Indochina. (Later, the palace was in South Vietnam.)Defending against three no-trump, West led the club ace. How do you think the defense went?West opened with a cautious three clubs. North doubled for penalties, but South, with his distributional hand, wisely didn't pass. (Three clubs was unbeatable.) Then, when North bid three hearts, South thought he was facing a heart-club two-suiter. So, rather than look for a nonexistent spade fit, he settled for three no-trump.This is how Blaizot reported the play: "I led the club ace and under the eyes of the panic-stricken spectators, Bao Dai discarded the diamond ace! I continued with the club queen and he discarded the spade ace! Immediately, silence filled the room. Discreetly, the spectators, struck with fright, got up and whispered into each other's ears. Then, little by little, a disquieting rumor spread through the palace: 'The emperor has gone mad. He threw away all of his aces.' But no! Bao Dai wasn't playing to lose."If the emperor had kept either of his aces, South could have established that suit without letting West on play. Now, though, West had to win a spade or diamond trick and could cash enough club winners to defeat the contract.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Mid-Shore counties advocating against state cost shifts
author: Konner Metz
content:
Mid-Shore counties advocating against state cost shifts

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 371
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council sent a letter this week to the Maryland General Assembly expressing its concerns regarding more than $1 million in county money impacted by the state's Budget Reconciliation and Financing Act."The proposal to shift costs onto counties by sending invoices simply places the State's fiscal problem into other hands and threatens local services," reads the letter, which was unanimously approved by the council Tuesday.
Cost shifts are expected as the state aims to balance a budget with a nearly $3 billion deficit. Specific costs include contributions to teacher pensions and the state Department of Assessments and Taxation.
Council Vice President Pete Lesher said it's "simply a poor and inappropriate strategy for resolving the very real state budget crisis."
Lesher noted Tuesday that Talbot County isn't seeing the worst of the cost shifts — Dorchester County may be looking at more than $3 million affected, he said.
Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said he testified at a Senate budget committee meeting in Annapolis and talked with members of the governor's staff.
Pfeffer says Department of Legislative Services recommendations to double the costs for counties to pay toward teacher pensions is particularly alarming. For Dorchester, it would cost $1.1 million compared to the previously estimated $550,000.
Gov. Wes Moore has said solving the budget crisis is an "enormous task" only made more difficult by constraints from the federal government. At a Feb. 28 Senate budget committee hearing, he emphasized that the budget bill is nowhere near final.
"While I still remain locked in on the destination, I come in moving in partnership to be flexible on the journey," Moore said.
Caroline County Commissioners President Travis Breeding said the county may lose $1.1 million in income tax revenue if Moore's tax cut plan is approved.
Moore has maintained that giving middle-class families tax relief is a critical component to the budget and state's economic growth plan.
"Marylanders are being squeezed. They're being squeezed by rising prices," Moore said Feb. 28. "They're being squeezed by the rising cost of groceries, they're being squeezed by the rising cost of energy."
As session continues, Breeding says Caroline County has representatives in Annapolis fighting for relief from the potential cost shifts.
"We have a lot of heartburn with the proposed budget," Breeding said.

title: 'Cambridge is working:' city staff talks about plans at Council retreat
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
'Cambridge is working:' city staff talks about plans at Council retreat

 February 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 682
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Cambridge City Council and city staff looked both back into the past and forward into the future at a Council retreat Feb. 5.At the retreat, city officials reviewed the city's goals — which were determined a year ago — talking about the progress that has been made and what still needs to be done.
The first half of the meeting was dedicated to short presentations by city department heads, detailing the programs, initiatives and projects that they think contribute to the city's goals. The department heads talked about programs and projects that have already been started or completed, as well as those that are still in the works.
Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout called the written reports the department heads prepared, along with their presentations, "excellent."
"Turning Cambridge around is not something that is done on a dime or is done in a month, or six months, or a year or even many years," he said. "It is hard work that the staff has clearly put itself to — not only in preparing these documents, but in showing us what has been happening over this past year and what we look forward to in the coming months."
The city's goals, established last year, are to:
Be inclusive, consistent and fair retaining, assisting and attracting businesses with consistently applied rules and processes.Improve the City of Cambridge's organizational efficiencies and effectiveness.Create a more beautiful City with better and healthier housing, improved gateways, a vibrant downtown and a sense of pride within the City staff and the community as a whole.Engage Cambridge's youth and foster meaningful work for young adults.Develop improved infrastructure, long-term projects and capital plans, including the preservation and restoration of the old City Hall structure at 307 Gay Street by 2026.
The initiatives and projects brought up by department heads at the meeting ranged from upgrades to the city's camera systems and sidewalks to improving housing through the Homeownership Works pilot program and the creation of a land bank.
City Manager Tom Carroll said the city is in the process of implementing the government software, OpenGov. City staff hope this software will improve efficiency and accuracy when it comes to things like code enforcement, work orders and permitting.
City Engineer Carl "Bucky" Jackson talked about upcoming projects to resolve sewer issues in the city. These projects include the replacement of the West End sewer, located in the lowest lying area of the city at Water Street and Hambrooks Boulevard, and the replacement of the Trenton Street Pump Station.
Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd talked about its priorities with community-oriented policing and plans for focusing more attention on high-crime areas. Todd also talked about goals to implement more technology in policing. He mentioned wanting to start a drone program.
Rescue Fire Company Chief Adam Pritchett talked about recruitment being a focus this year. He said the fire company wants to start its cadet program back up and get back into schools to try to recruit the next generation of firefighters.
After the presentations, Rideout and commissioners discussed how to make these efforts known to residents.
"How do we get this information out to everyone else so they understand all the complexities, all the hard work that goes into this on some kind of a simplified basis?" Rideout asked. "Because I think its important for the community to become more engaged and to have a better understanding so that maybe they won't come and start picking on this one little thing when they know there's so much more that's being done."
Commission President Lajan Cephas said the phrase "Cambridge is working" comes to her mind when thinking about how to approach this.
"Because I know everything is working," she said. "We have a great city. We have great department heads, great employees, a great city manager. ... I guess to answer (Rideout's) question, is maybe if we have some sort of movement that says 'Cambridge is working.'"
Cephas said its important that the council recognizes city staff is short-handed and overworked.
"So I think this year should be more of a year of trying to complete what we've started in the previous couple of years," she said.

title: Ironman brings economic boost to Cambridge
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Ironman brings economic boost to Cambridge

 September 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge residents may have noticed it has been trickier getting around this past week.Traffic has increased, reservations at their favorite restaurant are difficult to get and all hotels and Airbnb's from Salisbury to Annapolis are filled, according to Operations Manager at the Ironman Angie Hengst.
1,250 athletes who will be participating in the Maryland Ironman on Saturday began making their way to Cambridge on Monday to preview the courses, enjoy their welcoming events and attend athlete briefings.
"Driving around town, it's about three times as busy as you would normally see it," Hengst said.
A few years ago, the Ironman did an economic impact study on Cambridge and Dorchester Counting post-event that discovered the event has a $7.14 million impact on the community, Hengst said. This number may have increased since the study.
This is the 11th annual Maryland Ironman, an extreme triathlon race that requires approximately 1,200 volunteers to pull off. The Ironman Foundation has grant funding available for local nonprofits that volunteer for the race, per this year's Race Director Brian Snow.
"We have over $40,000 in nonprofit money, and it goes to volunteers and groups to help stimulate the economy with people participating as volunteers," Snow said.
Both Hengst and Snow said Friday that they were still looking for volunteers for Saturday's big race.
The race will include a 2.4-mile swim in the Choptank River in between Gerry Boyle Park at Great Marsh and the Yacht Club, finishing at the boat ramp at Gerry Boyle Park. Next, there will be a 112-mile bike ride through Dorchester County and the scenic Blackwater Wildlife Refuge. The race will finish with a 26.2-mile run through historic downtown Cambridge and beyond.
Snow said athletes from all 50 states and over 30 countries will be participating on Saturday. He said every athlete generally comes with one other person considering the intensity of the race.
Both Snow and Hengst expressed their gratitude to the volunteers and residents of Cambridge and Dorchester County for being gracious hosts.
"I do want to put a huge thank you out to the community, you know, Cambridge, Dorchester County, everyone, for being so welcoming and supportive of the athletes," Hengst said.
"We're one of the smaller towns that hosts an event of this size, and we couldn't do it without the community's support. The athletes always comment about how nice everyone is and how welcoming it is here," she said.

 229
 Words

 Buddy Valastro from "Buddy Valastro's Cake Dynasty"Planet Earth III BBCA 8 p.m.In this new episode, Sir David Attenborough follows a pair of ostriches in the baked Namib Desert looking to raise a family.Meanwhile, near the equator, in a Brazilian grassland known as the Cerrado, he follows a rare fruit-eating maned wolf.A Merry Scottish Christmas HALL 8 p.m.Nothing says Christmas like bagpipes wafting over the Scottish Lochs. So, when estranged siblings Lindsay (Lacey Chabert) and Brad (Scott Wolf) travel to Scotland at Christmas to reunite with their mother, a huge family secret is revealed.Dead Shot SHOW 9 p.m.When an ambush along the border goes wrong, an ex-paramilitary soldier witnesses the fatal shooting of his pregnant wife by a British sergeant. Wounded and presumed dead, he escapes and heads to the paranoid streets of 1970s London to take his revenge.Buddy Valastro's Cake Dynasty A & E 10 p.m.Buddy has a lot on his plate as Mother's Day closes in. In addition to the regular Mother's Day rush, Buddy has to create a custom cake for the 50th anniversary of Secretariat's Triple Crown win and shoot his first ever Lifetime movie.Saturday Night Live WBAL 11:30 p.m.Live from the Rockefeller Center in New York, a hilarious ensemble of regulars, including Colin Jost and Chloe Troast, are joined by a weekly celebrity host and a musical performance as they perform sketches and shorts in front of a studio audience.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Salt of the earth
author: REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s Methodist Church, Denton
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Salt of the earth

 February 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s Methodist Church, Denton | Section: Columns 
 
 272
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Matthew 5:13 recounts Jesus' words, "You are the salt of the earth, but if salt has lost its taste, how shall its saltiness be restored? It is no longer good for anything except to be thrown out and trampled under peoples' feet."In the ancient world, salt had many functions. Of course, we know salt was widely used as a food preservative. It did not simply sit on the table waiting to cheer up a dull meal. It was also used as a "rub" of sorts for newborns (check out Ezekiel 16:4).
Strictly speaking, salt cannot lose its saltiness because it (sodium chloride) is a stable compound. So, what is Jesus alluding to with this illustration?
One possibility is that the Lord is referring to the preservative function of salt — Christians are to live and act in the world to prevent its moral degeneration. But it has more than the negative function of stopping the world's deterioration.
By speaking and living the gospel, believers will improve the societies in which they live. That is, we sprinkle the salt of the gospel onto the world.
Christians will turn the world aright when they submit to Christ. They should have no small ambitions; the whole earth will change through their salty influence. What was true for the first disciples is also true for us. We can serve Christ by applying the salt of anointed witness and service to the needs in our own locales.
Pray that we continue to salt our community with the salt of Christ's shed blood, that others may experience the true depth of God's life-preserving, regenerative power and not just the flavor of salt. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: End-of-life preplanning brings peace of mind
author: Mary Hunt
content:
End-of-life preplanning brings peace of mind

 August 23, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: A25 | Section: News 
 
 320
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Planning for their parents' end-of-life expenses is about the last thing most adult children want to deal with.A traditional funeral with end-of-life services with extras like flowers, obituary notices, acknowledgment cards and limousines can bring the total to $15,000 or more.Recently, I heard from one of my EC readers, responding to a previous column.She brought up an important topic, one that is not an easy to address. So let's gather into a huddle, wrap our arms around one another and take a collective deep breath.Dear Cheapskate: My comment is in response to "Where to Keep Money for Mom?" and Bonita in South Dakota, who was looking for input on how to invest $10,000 for her 62-year-old mother who has no savings, no life insurance and lives on disability.I would recommend they go to any funeral home and work with the person there who handles prepaid funerals.Essentially, you are purchasing an insurance policy to cover the funeral costs.We did this for my dad before he moved into a longterm care facility, which was going to drain his remaining assets to $0. A prepaid funeral policy is excluded from the asset base, is protected once the assets are gone and a person goes on medical assistance.With all the other drama that comes with aging parents, it is nice for my sister and me to know that the end is covered and won't create another drain/strain on everything. - Molly Dear Molly: Thanks for this wise advice. In fact, many elder law attorneys advise prepayment as a way to invest in assets that will not be countable by Medicaid or SSI.However, I want my readers to know that there are pitfalls on the road to prepaid end-of-life arrangements, which they need to know about in order to avoid falling into them. Buyers beware.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book Debt-Proof Living.© 2023 CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: ‘Day of Dance’ proves beautiful gift to the community
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content:
‘Day of Dance’ proves beautiful gift to the community

 March 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 630
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — As the piano played, young dancers filled the stage exploring master classes of ballet, modern dance, hip hop and choreography. A "Day of Dance" is one of the many gifts that Carole Cascio left to the community.On Saturday, Feb. 24, dancers, ages 12 and up, filled the Decker Theatre in the Gibson Center at Washington College in Chestertown for a free community event hosted by the Carole Cascio Fund for Mind and Movement Dance Connections.
Upon arrival, registered dancers signed in and received a bag full of healthy drinks and snacks. All dancers were invited to participate in four master classes taught by special guest artists Kristi Schaffner (ballet) with piano accompanist Joann Moorer, Renee Gerardo (modern dance), Adrienne Kraus Latanishen (hip hop), and Melinda Bloomquist (composition/choreography).
This was the fourth "Day of Dance" sponsored by the fund. Both Chesapeake College and Washington College have offered their theaters to host these events.
Each "Day of Dance" showcases different artists and a variety of dance styles with a mission of the Fund, "to introduce students of all ages and levels to connecting mind, movement and dance, and to support developing artistry in young people through choreography and dance."
Locally, Cascio was known as a beautiful artist for both watercolor and pottery, but many did not know about her former dancing career.
Peter Pucci, a former dance student of Cascio, said, "It was because of Carole that I became a professional dancer, a choreographer, a movement director, an artistic director, a professor of dance and composition, a dance filmmaker, a producer, a mentor to young dancers and finally the executive director of the Carole Cascio Fund at Carole's request."
In addition to dance and creating art, Cascio also taught Pilates at the Kent Island Senior Center in Stevensville and at Chesapeake College for many years. With a heart for creating and a love for the arts, Cascio was an inspiration to countless people.
"Carole and I had many conversations over the last five years of her life about how to bring dance into her community, to elementary schools, middle schools, high schools and to Chesapeake College," Pucci said. "They were fun, lively conversations with all kinds of ideas being tossed about. Little did I know then that she was preparing me for the job of directing her foundation. It is truly a full circle endeavor for me and, in the great tradition of modern dancers, of giving back to the community just as she did to hundreds of dancers over her career."
To honor Cascio's dreams of bringing dance into the schools, Pucci is actively working with Queen Anne's County Public Schools to encourage and enhance the dance programs at the middle and high schools. To date, the Cascio Fund has planned, sponsored and held many dance classes, including a combined hip hop master class with Queen Anne's County High School dancers and with students from Centreville Middle School.
The Fund also brought a four-century-old dance style and India Dance Teachers Deepti Mukund Navile, Gowrie Velayudhapillai and Tulsi Rughoonundun to teach dance workshops at Kent Island and Queen Anne's County high schools.
On Friday, March 8, there will be a free performance courtesy of the Carole Cascio Fund by the New York Dance Project from New York City at the YMCA in Centerville from 5:30 to 6:30 p.m. Seating opens at 5 p.m. For more information, visit newyorkdanceproject.org/programs/the-company.
Pucci shared this performance will be "very serendipitous" as Cascio donated the funds to create the new pickleball courts at the YMCA where the dancers will be performing. Before this event, there will also be a free ballet masterclass at QACHS for all dancers 12 and up. Pre-registration is required. See the website for more information.
For more information or to support the Carole Cascio Fund for Mind Movement Dance Connections, visit carolecasciofund.org.

title: Chesapeake Bay cleanup at a crossroads: new path or stay the course?
author: JEREMY COX Bay Journal
content:
Chesapeake Bay cleanup at a crossroads: new path or stay the course?

 October 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JEREMY COX Bay Journal | Section: State News 
 
 1014
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As the Chesapeake Bay cleanup's leaders close in on a revised working agreement, many of the effort's most influential supporters are endorsing a major thematic shift: putting less emphasis on improving the estuary's seldom-seen deep waters and more on helping people and living resources in the Bay watershed."This is an opportunity for our movement to understand our successes and failures, and adjust accordingly," said Kate Fritz, CEO of the Alliance for the Chesapeake Bay, in a letter to the Chesapeake Bay Program, the multi-state and federal partnership in charge of reviving the Bay. "This means … intentionally including people and living resources at the center of the partnership's work."
That closely aligns with the recommendations of the Bay Program team that was tasked with drafting an update of the 2014 Chesapeake Bay Agreement. A draft was released for public feedback on July 1.
The team urged the program to "better incentivize practices that maximize benefits to living resources and people." This, they argued, could be accomplished largely through actions that target water quality improvements — long the effort's central focus — but only if local community concerns take precedent.
More than 80 people and organizations submitted comments on the draft agreement by the Aug. 30 deadline. The Chesapeake Executive Council — the governors of the six watershed states, mayor of the District of Columbia, chair of the Chesapeake Bay Commission and administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency — is set to vote on a final draft during its annual meeting in December.
The revised agreement is intended to serve as a top-line strategy for cleaning up the Bay and its 64,000-square-mile drainage basin beyond 2025, when the deadline for goals in the current agreement expires.
For decades, the partnership has centered its work on reducing nutrient and sediment pollution flowing into the Bay. The main goal has been to shrink the annual "dead zones," pockets of oxygen-starved water in the estuary's deepest waters where aquatic creatures struggle to survive.
Despite billions of dollars invested in the effort, pollution reductions have been modest and slow in coming, according to the Bay Program's own calculations. Some advocates and scientists fear that the cleanup risks falling out of favor with the public if it doesn't shift toward more visible quests, such as restoring shallow waters along the edge of the Bay and its tributaries.
"Without renewed attention to those things that matter the most to people, we run the risk of leaving potential living resource benefits unaddressed and potentially losing public support for our efforts," wrote Larry Sanford, chair of the Bay Program's Scientific and Technical Advisory Committee (STAC), on behalf of the panel.
But in remarks to STAC on Sept. 12, Sanford, a professor at the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science, described the new draft agreement as a "compromise" between two factions: those seeking a pronounced change in direction and those who want to stay the course.
For his part, Sanford said the program needs to maintain much of its existing work but also "go back to the original reason for the Bay Program, and that was what was happening to the living resources."
If that recalibration is to move forward, it will have to survive a big test later this fall when the agreement goes before the Principals' Staff Committee — senior officials from the Bay states and DC, who sounded a note of caution about that approach when they met in March.
Meeting water quality goals is a legal requirement, enforced by the EPA. The committee appeared concerned that de-stressing that goal could lead to potential lawsuits. Several members at the time also said they believed that those authoring the revised agreement had gone beyond what they had been authorized to do.
A group of agricultural industry groups in Virginia, including the Virginia Farm Bureau, signed on to a letter that said they "appreciate" the draft's call to better address climate change and public engagement. But they are concerned that such measures would "change the original intent and shared goals" of the 2014 agreement. The state in its current two-year budget has set aside a record $207 million to reduce farm-based pollution.
Meanwhile, several environmental groups touted how reorienting the program toward people and living creatures would support other important goals. Much could be achieved, for example, through tougher enforcement of state and federal water pollution control laws, according to a letter signed by Waterkeepers Chesapeake and several local waterkeepers.
"While the status quo elevates considerations of nutrient pollutants and the dissolved oxygen levels in the mainstem of the Bay, the path forward must elevate the role that enforcement of illegal pollution from point sources has on protecting humans and wildlife from toxic and carcinogenic substances," the waterkeepers said.
The needs of people and wildlife will be difficult to meet without more land conservation, said the Chesapeake Conservation Partnership, an alliance of land trusts and related organizations. Bay leaders, they added, should elevate land conservation to stand as a "key guiding pillar" along those already on that top tier: science, restoration and partnership.
The document being readied for the Executive Council's approval this December isn't the final revised agreement but rather a framework for a more detailed compact to be worked out in the future. The current draft doesn't call for a full revision of the agreement until the council meets in 2026.
Several commenters urged leadership to put the finalized agreement on a faster schedule. To wait until late 2026 could lead to a pause or slowdown in oyster restoration activities in key Bay tributaries, said Oyster Recovery Partnership Executive Director H. Ward Slacum. It should be ready by the end of 2025 instead, he said.
A group of about 40 retired Bay scientists and former public officials also weighed in. The coalition, calling itself "Chesapeake Bay Program Veterans," echoed the push to have the revisions in place in 2025.
And the program should look at the problems and benefits that arise from local, state and federal greenhouse gas reduction goals, they said. They suggested that the transition from fossil fuels to renewable energy, for example, is likely to reduce nitrogen pollution that enters Bay waters from the atmosphere.

title: Next phase of Oxford's Strand Beach Project poses funding hurdle
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Next phase of Oxford's Strand Beach Project poses funding hurdle

 October 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 262
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Phase one of the Strand Beach Project has been completed, but the prospect of phase two is daunting for the town and its residents.The first phase was turbulent. Residents, commissioners and town staff were frustrated with the duration, expense and results of the project.
Funding for phase one came from the state and Department of Natural Resources. Currently, there is no additional funding for future phases of the project.
Phase two will cover stormwater mitigation, an Americans with Disabilities Act access ramp over the dune and bulkhead improvements.
"We're looking at funding options with the state to mitigate the stormwater on the roadway as well as town internal funds, which it's going to be likely that we're going to have to look at that, especially with mitigating the stormwater on the roadway and that failing bulkhead," Wahl said.
Engineering work is underway to design stormwater mitigation, like removing standing water from the roadway, creating a swale through the parking lot to channel water away and improving the failing bulkhead.
The standing water between the beach access point and the parking lot, known through town as the "perma-puddle," can be seen on sunny days and grows even more after a storm.
In addition, there's no ADA compliant entrance to the beach area.
These have been hot topics at recent town commissioner meetings. Commissioner Dave Donovan said it has been on the agenda every meeting for the past two months.
Once plans for the second phase of the project are ready, the town will seek permits. Whal said commissioners are unlikely to approve another contract with Underwood & Associates.

title: Escape or die - BI: 'Kidnapped, chained' woman escaped from cell built inside home
author: Molly O Brien; Herald & News
content:
Escape or die - BI: 'Kidnapped, chained' woman escaped from cell built inside home

 August 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Molly O Brien; Herald & News | Page: A3 | Section: News 
 
 932
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An Oregon man faces interstate kidnapping charges after a woman - who police say was "kidnapped, chained (and) sexually assaulted" - escaped from a sound-proof, cinderblock cell constructed in the suspect's garage.Negasi Zuberi, 29, rented a house in the 1300 block of North Eldorado in Klamath Falls, Oregon, with his wife and two children, Klamath Falls Police Chief Rob Dentinger told the Herald & News. Klamath Falls is in southern Oregon near the California border."This woman was kidnapped, chained, sexually assaulted and locked in a cinderblock cell," Stephanie Shark, the assistant special agent in charge of the FBI's Portland field office, said in a news release."We have identified three additional victims from other states where (Zuberi) has lived," Shark told the Herald & News.Information on the victims has not yet been released as the investigation is ongoing, Shark said.Zuberi is confirmed to have lived in 12 different states over the past decade."Those states could include: California, Washington, Oregon, Colorado, Utah, Florida, New York, New Jersey, Alabama, and Nevada," the FBI said in a statement.The suspect's residence on North Eldorado Drive was rented to him by Klamath Falls Mayor Carol Westfall and her husband, Kevin, who own the house.The mayor told the Herald & News that she and her husband rented the property to Zuberi and his two children six months ago. There was no mention of a wife or roommates on the lease, Westfall said.According to a criminal complaint filed in U.S.District Court in Oregon, Zuberi solicited the woman, identified only as Adult Victim 1, in the early morning hours of July 15 to engage in prostitution along Aurora Avenue in Seattle, an area known for sex work.Afterward, Zuberi told the woman he was an undercover officer, showed her a badge, pointed a stun gun at her, and placed her in handcuffs and leg irons before putting her in the back of his vehicle, the complaint says.The suspect then drove the victim 450 miles to his home in Klamath Falls, sexually assaulting the victim during the trip, according to the FBI and federal prosecutors.A news release from FBI's Portland office said after arriving at his home, the victim was moved into a cinderblock cell constructed in Zuberi's garage. A metal door made it so the victim could not open the door from inside the structure."Once Zuberi left, the victim says she repeatedly banged on the door and was able to break the door open and escape the room," the release said.She said after she was moved to the cell, Zuberi said he was leaving "to do paperwork." The victim "briefly slept and awoke to the realization she would likely die if she did not attempt to escape the room." Punching the metal door, she managed to break some of the welded joints and create an opening big enough to climb through, Klamath Falls Police Capt. Rob Reynolds said at the news conference."When she was trying to escape the cell itself, she repeatedly punched the door with her own hands," Reynolds said. "She had several lacerations along her knuckles." In Zuberi's garage, the victim managed to break into the suspect's vehicle and grab a handgun. She then escaped to the street, climbing over a wooden fence on which investigators found blood.The victim flagged down a passing motorist who helped her notify the police and the motorist transported her to the emergency room at Sky Lakes Medical Center."Her quick thinking and will to survive may have saved other women from a similar nightmare," Shark said in the news release.Evidence found at the suspect's residence included handwritten notes, one of which was titled "Operation Take Over." Entries on the bulleted list included "Leave phone at home" and "Make sure they don't' have a bunch of ppl in their life. You don't want any type of investigation." Investigators also found a handwritten document with a sketch for an underground structure using concrete blocks, foam insulation and waterproof concrete.After the victim's escape, Zuberi ran with his wife and two children to Reno, Nev.The criminal complaint said Zuberi and his family were located by two Nevada State Patrol officers in a Walmart parking lot the following afternoon, July 16.He was in his car holding one of his children in the front seat while talking to his wife, who was standing outside the vehicle. The complaint said Zuberi initially refused to get out of the car and attempted to cut himself with a sharp object which led to profuse bleeding. Zuberi also attempted to destroy his phone but eventually surrendered.The child was reported unharmed.The mayor said there were no indications of Zuberi's criminal activity."We had service people going there, and he would invite us in," Westfall said. "It was incredibly brazen." "He came into this town, but it's over for him," she added.The U.S. Attorney's Office for Oregon said the Klamath Falls man had been indicted on kidnapping and sexual assault charges."Zuberi, 29, also known as Sakima, Justin Hyche, and Justin Kouassi, has been charged with interstate kidnapping and transporting an individual across state lines with intent to engage in criminal sexual activity" the U.S. Attorney's Office said in a statement. 
 
 Caption: FBI
 
A man renting a home from the mayor of an Oregon town built a "cinderblock cell" and allegedly held a kidnapped and chained woman captive before her escape, according to FBI.
 
FBI
 
The FBI says a kidnapped woman escaped from a cell (pictured) built inside an Oregon home.
 
MOLLY O'BRIEN/HERA LD & NEWS
 
This is the house in the 1300 block of North Eldorado Avenue where Negasi Zuberi, 29, allegedly held a woman in a cinderblock cell in the garage.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/July 4
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/July 4

 July 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 372
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On July 4, 1776, the Declaration of Independence was adopted by delegates to the Second Continental Congress in Philadelphia.Also on this date:
In 1802, the United States Military Academy officially opened at West Point, New York.
In 1817, construction of the Erie Canal began in Rome, New York.
In 1826, 50 years to the day after the Declaration of Independence was adopted, former presidents John Adams and Thomas Jefferson both died.
In 1831, the fifth president of the United States, James Monroe, died in New York City at age 73.
In 1855, the first edition of Walt Whitman's "Leaves of Grass" was published.
In 1863, the Civil War Siege of Vicksburg, Mississippi, ended as a Confederate garrison surrendered to Union forces.
In 1910, in what was billed as "The Fight of the Century," Black world heavyweight boxing champion Jack Johnson defeated white former champ "Gentleman" Jim Jeffries in Reno, Nevada; race riots across the country following the fight killed more than 20 people.
In 1912, the 48-star American flag, recognizing New Mexico and Arizona statehood, was adopted.
In 1939, Lou Gehrig of the New York Yankees delivered his famous farewell speech in which he called himself "the luckiest man on the face of the earth."
In 1946, the United States and the Philippines signed the Treaty of Manila, recognizing Philippine independence from the US.
In 1960, the current 50-star version of the US flag was adopted.
In 1976, America celebrated its bicentennial with daylong festivities; President Gerald R. Ford made stops in Valley Forge, Pennsylvania, Independence Hall in Philadelphia and New York, where more than 200 ships paraded up the Hudson River in Operation Sail.
In 1987, Klaus Barbie, the former Gestapo chief known as the "Butcher of Lyon," was convicted by a French court of crimes against humanity and sentenced to life in prison (he died in September 1991).
In 1995, the space shuttle Atlantis and the Russian space station Mir parted after spending five days in orbit docked together.
In 2012, scientists at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) in Geneva cheered the apparent end of a decades-long quest for a new subatomic particle called the Higgs boson, or "God particle."
In 2013, the Statue of Liberty reopened on the Fourth of July, eight months after Superstorm Sandy shuttered the national symbol of freedom. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Martin Truex looks to add another NASCAR Championship to his resume
author: Roberto Jozef
content:
Martin Truex looks to add another NASCAR Championship to his resume

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Roberto Jozef | Page: 13A | Section: News 
 
 350
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's the moment NASCAR fans have been waiting for all season. The 2023 NASCAR Cup Series Championship Race has finally arrived, with all the action broadcast live on NBC from the Phoenix International Raceway in Avondale, Arizona, Sunday, Nov. 5.After a regular season that saw veteran racer Martin Truex Jr. battling it out with rising star William Byron and Kyle Larson, the three racers have continued fighting for the top spot on the podium.Still among the favorites to hoist the Bill France Trophy in Phoenix, Truex Jr. managed to keep himself above the cut line in the Round of 8, placing ninth at Las Vegas Motor Speedway, and achieving only his first top-10 finish in the playoffs. This came at the end of a disastrous pit strategy that almost looked to be the end for the No. 19 car. Prior to his Las Vegas race, his best finish came at the Texas Motor Speedway, where he would finish 17th Despite the slight drop in standings, Truex Jr. remains the top driver for Joe Gibbs Racing, leading in points over teammates Christopher Bell, Tyler Reddick, Chris Buesher and Ryan Blaney.Throughout the regular season, Truex Jr. has proven he's still one of the most dominant drivers on the track, with his team remaining optimistic."That group knows why they can do it because they did it over 26 weeks," car owner Joe Gibbs told NBC Sports."So, it's a matter of hitting it. Coming here, we thought we would have a real good shot. We're working our butt off. We're going overtime on pit road with practices. We're doing everything, I think, we can do." 
 
 Memo: Full name: Martin Lee Truex Jr.
 
Birthdate: June 29, 1980 (43) Birthplace: Mayetta, New Jersey, U.S.
 
Height/weight: 5-11/180 pounds Team(s)/number: Joe Gibbs Racing - No.19 Honors and achievements: Busch Series Most Popular Driver (2004, 2005), Named one of NASCAR's 75 Greatest Drivers (2023), NASCAR Cup Series Regular Season Champion (2017, 2023), Busch Light Crash winner (2023), Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series Champion (2017), Coca-Cola 600 winner (2016, 2019), Southern 500 winSolution is on page 19. ner (2016)

title: Fire significantly damages car junkyard in Greensboro
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Fire significantly damages car junkyard in Greensboro

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 160
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — A fire in Greensboro Thursday evening caused extensive damage to a car junkyard, according to the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal.Just after 5:20 p.m. Thursday, firefighters responded to a fire at Mitchells Used Auto Parts on Drapers Mill Road.
According to the fire marshal's report, "a victim sustained minor burns from the fire, but refused treatment." No other injuries were reported.
The Greensboro Volunteer Fire Company was the primary unit responding to the scene. Around 60 firefighters from various departments responded. The fire marshal's report stated the blaze took an hour to control.
Estimated losses in structure amount to $80,000 and estimated losses in contents amount to $100,000, the report says.
The fire marshal described the fire as a "one-story," "pole barn" fire, and said it originated in the interior. The preliminary cause is still under investigation.
Anyone with information about the fire is asked to contact the Upper Eastern Regional Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal at 410-819-3500.

title: Mid-Shore Community Band celebrates differences
author: Tom McCall
content:
Mid-Shore Community Band celebrates differences

 November 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 476
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Copper timpani, sliding trombones, heraldic trumpets and a focused baton are just some of the instruments making up the 45-member Mid-Shore Community Band. Band Leader Matt Fullerton keeps all the moving pieces in order.The band brought its music to Thompson Park on Nov. 9 during the Waterfowl Festival, and band members commanded a range from flutes to thundering drums.
But the most significant diversity the band exhibits is not in its musical abilities, but in the ages of its members.
Members of the band range from high schoolers to those in their upper 70s. There are people from all different walks of life who come together to make music.
"We do this because we love music. If nothing else it is therapy. No, it is a lot of fun," Fullerton said.
Fullerton has been conducting since 1975 and has a masters in music. He taught the band at Easton Middle school for 30 years. He said he can play most of the instruments in the band.
Tracie Thomas, who plays clarinet, has been in the band since its founding in 2009.
"One of the best parts is getting to play with my old musical director from middle school, Matt Fullerton," she said. "Just being able to play is the best part. We generally have a season, and we will have a repertoire for the season that we select for each concert. Of course we already have Christmas music out. We have started rehearsing for that."
She said they have everything from jazzy Christmas to sleigh ride Christmas music.
"We really try hard to be a part of the community. Our band is here to serve other nonprofits like we are today. Every concert we have played is no charge and often raising money for another organization. Everybody here is volunteering their time," Thomas said.
There was also a vast expanse of musical choices on display at the Nov. 9 concert, including a theme from the Disney film Fantasia "Night On Bald Mountain," a medley of computer gaming songs, a march and a hoedown.
"It includes themes from Assassin 33, 'Bratja' from Full Metal Alchemist, 'Dragon Born' from Skyrims, 'Sadness and Sorrow' from Naruto and 'Baba Yetu' from Civilization 4," Fullerton said of the gaming medley.
He noted that Hollywood used to produce most music, but the successful gaming industry is paying composers to make the digital worlds come alive.
"The same backing that creates that, as they do for themes for movies. It is possible that more people hear these than some of the pieces more than some of the movie themes," Fullerton said.
Of course the band also played a crisp "Star Spangled Banner" and got the crowd on their feet.
They practice at the Easton High band room every Tuesday at 7 p.m. They always looking for new players, even if they haven't dusted off their tuba in 10 years. To learn more, visit mscb.org.

title: Free world is divorcing us
author: Staff Writer
content:
Free world is divorcing us

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 389
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The March 8-9 edition of your paper gave some good reasons not to reelect Andy Harris.You quote Harris saying: "…I'm hoping with the economic growth we have, we're going to provide plenty of private sector jobs for those leaving the federal government."
Your paper also reported on two NOAA scientists who were fired from the lab in Oxford. I am sure they were not fired for cause. They were fired because Elon Musk was given authority to fire government employees, and he appears to get his gets kicks doing that. (See his chainsaw antics at CPAC.)
Where are those two fired scientists going to get private sector jobs? As reported in the Chesapeake Bay Journal March 2025, Trump is destroying all Bay protection agencies. Musk is firing federal scientists everywhere. Will Harris name some private companies that are going to take over protection of the Chesapeake Bay? Tesla? Starlink? Meta? Amazon? Maybe the two Oxford scientists can get jobs at an Amazon warehouse.
Jobs for the thousands of employees working for Veterans Affairs have been targeted for firing. People have been fired from security agencies that protect us from Russia. What companies are going to do that work? United Heath Care? Pfizer? Maybe each person buying Trump's gold card for $5 million to enter the U.S. will be required to adopt two veterans and assign one person to provide cybersecurity for America.
Mr. Harris's answer that private sector jobs will fulfill these requirements is a tragic joke.
Mr. Harris is also quoted as saying what an honor it was for him to sit next to the leader of the free world. That can't be Trump. He directed the U.S. to vote with North Korea, Iran and Russia denying a resolution supporting Ukraine. A prominent Republican of old called North Korea and Iran part of the "Axis of Evil." The free world, they ain't.
Many countries in the free world are at economic war with us. Our free world friends, such as Canada, are being courted by China to get themselves out of Trump's toxic world order.
The free world is divorcing us, and it seems everyone knows that except Mr. Harris.
If you disagree with Musk disemboweling the government while gleefully prancing around and ruining lives, and you disagree with Trump catering to Putin while making economic war against allies, vote Harris out in 2026.
MICHAEL DAVIS
Easton

title: Marine museum welcomes rays and 'benders to exhibit
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Marine museum welcomes rays and 'benders to exhibit

 May 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 408
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There are new creatures to feature at Calvert Marine Museum in Solomons. Earlier this week Matt Neff, the museum's curator of estuarine biology, introduced the new tank inhabitants, including four cownose rays.It was about eight years ago that an environmental group called Showing Animals Respect and Kindness — or SHARK — raised awareness about a local event at which cownose rays were clubbed to death for sport.
Neff, who said he has had a love for all of nature's creatures since he was a small child, dismissed reports that the cownose rays, which are prevalent in the Chesapeake Bay region during the warm weather months, are pesky and invasive.
Recently, Neff and other museum personnel traveled to an aquarium in Kansas City, Mo., and returned with the cownose rays, along with some Atlantic rays and skates. The creatures were kept in an aquarium during the 22½ hour trip back to Maryland.
Neff explained that the Kansas City aquarium was the only institute that responded to Calvert Marine Museum's request for cownose rays "when we had a need for animals to exhibit."
The cownose rays, all male, seem to be getting along fine in the circular tank at the museum with the other local waterway denizens.
"They're pretty docile," Neff said, adding that the rays "were born in captivity."
Neff, who grew up in the Mid-Atlantic area and went to college in New York, majoring in biology, has previously worked at a nature center and at the National Zoo.
Of his job at the local marine museum he said, "I do like that we only have native species here."
Neff also showed off one of the museum's newest exhibits, a pair of eastern hellbenders, the largest salamander in North America. However, the hellbender, first discovered in 1803, can no longer be found in the Chesapeake Bay region.
The eastern hellbender can grow as long as 29 inches and weigh up to 5.5 pounds.
"It's kind of a fascinating animal," Neff said, noting that some of the factors, including development and pollution, "ended up being a perfect storm" and put the hellbender's population in peril.
Bonnie Farmer, the museum's communications and marketing coordinator, confirmed that the annual Sharkfest is coming up at the Solomons facility on July 13. The extremely popular event will feature live sharks for viewing at Corbin Pavilion. It's recommended that anyone wanting to attend Sharkfest 2024 purchase tickets in advance since the museum has limited capacity.
For more information about the Calvert Marine Museum, go to calvertmarinemuseum.com
