title: Hosler at 100 and counting
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Hosler at 100 and counting

 October 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 693
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — As Queen Anne's County High's boys soccer team prepared for its victory jog across the field Wednesday night, a handful of Lions coaxed head coach Wade Hosler to find a place in line and join the run.Hosler made it halfway across the field then started applauding.
"It's senior night," he said. "Let them have it."
It was also the night Hosler earned his 100th career victory, as Jamison Kendall's first-half goal proved enough in a 1-0 victory over a no-quit North Dorchester bunch, keeping the Lions atop the North Bayside.
"I guess it means I'm getting old," said a smiling Hosler of his milestone. "I didn't really sit down and think about it too much. It's been a lot of tremendous players, a lot of great assistant coaches, administration. A lot of people have helped me along the way.
"It's been an amazing journey," continued Hosler, now in his 13th season at the helm. "We have great kids. They come out and they work hard every year. We graduate good kids, and good kids fill their shoes. So it's a good place to be. If it wasn't I wouldn't have lasted this long."
With their fourth win in five games, the Lions (5-3 overall, 5-0 North Bayside) remained in first place in the division via their fourth one-goal win of the season.
"It's always a little stressful," Hosler said of senior night. "We didn't finish the ball, which makes it difficult. We finish a couple more early (chances) and it would be a different game. But we don't put the ball in the back of the net and it becomes a struggle."
Queen Anne's got four corner-kick chances in the opening 15 minutes but couldn't convert. And though the Lions controlled possession for much of the first half, the Eagles (4-4-1, 1-4-1) found openings and opportunities, the biggest coming with 26 minutes, 18 seconds remaining, when Christian Chase drilled a strike off the crossbar.
The Lions cranked up the intensity on the offensive end, with James Rath sending a pair of shots on goal that North Dorchester keeper Jayden Coleman stopped. But with just under 18 minutes left before half, the Lions worked the ball down the right side and over to Kendall, who steered a left-footed shot past Coleman for a 1-0 lead.
"We had good pressure," Eagles head coach Gabe Guzman said. "It's one of those nights where things don't fall your way and you have to live with the results. Unfortunately, we had one mistake in the back end."
Queen Anne's continued building chances toward padding its lead in the second half. Coleman stopped Trey Moore's header with 27:27 to go. Kendall was denied with 13:30 remaining and Rath unloaded a drive wide left 2 minutes later.
North Dorchester pushed into the Lions end in the final 5 minutes in a bid for the equalizer. Senior captain Chris Sanchez, who booted a number of long clears and balls into the Queen Anne's end throughout the game, drove a direct kick wide left with a little over 5 minutes left. The Eagles got a corner with 3 minutes to go, but couldn't muster a shot.
About a minute later, the Eagles sent a through ball into the box. But Lions sophomore keeper Braeden Livingston sprinted off his line and scooped the ball before anyone else could get a touch.
"It makes it stressful," Hosler said of his team's one-goal wins. "But hey, we're playing well. We're still undefeated in the North. And I'm proud of the way we grind. It's not pretty. We're not finishing as many opportunities as we would like, but we keep grinding. We keep fighting. And we find a way to win."
Guzman also liked his team's fight, and with a little work, hopes to be a force in the Class 1A East playoffs.
"We're still working things out," said Guzman, whose team is 4-1-1 against 1A competition this season. "Finishing is still a little bit of an issue. It's a work in progress. Hopefully come playoff time we won't have that issue.
"Kudos to them," Guzman added of Hosler and Queen Anne's. "Hundredth win. That's a wonderful feat. Hopefully one day I'll be there. But they did their job."

title: EPA announces historic funding for Chesapeake Bay restoration
author: BRENNAN STEWART Capital News Service
content:
EPA announces historic funding for Chesapeake Bay restoration

 March 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BRENNAN STEWART Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 576
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ARLINGTON, Va. — The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced Wednesday that $206 million in funding will be allocated towards projects aimed at continuing the restoration of the Chesapeake Bay.The historic levels of funding reflect the Biden administration's increased investments in environmental programs and infrastructure projects.
"For a long time, the EPA's budget has been so small, roughly about $10 billion a year," EPA Assistant Deputy Administrator Mark Rupp said during a ceremony at the recently-built Lubber Run Community Center here. "Between the
Bipartisan Infrastructure Law and the Inflation Reduction Act, there's now over $100 billion flowing through our agency, and it really has been a game changer."
With $96 million of the funds coming from President Joe Biden's so-called "Investing in America" agenda alone, the announcement marked the largest single contribution to the Chesapeake Bay Program in its 41-year history.
Maryland is expected to receive over $14 million from the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation's share of the funds, which in turn makes up 40 individual grant projects.
Grant recipients include the Baltimore Tree Trust, which plans to educate city residents about planting trees in their communities.
The Severn River Association will be another recipient. The organization intends to increase and improve stormwater treatment practices on the Severn River, which flows into the Chesapeake Bay in Annapolis.
"Agendas matter, elected officials matter, vision matters," Rep. Gerry Connolly (D-Virginia) said. "For the sake of the country, thank God we have the 117th Congress and Joe Biden to sign those bills into law."
Attending the ceremony were not only federal officials and members of Congress but also legislators from state and local governments around the Chesapeake Bay.
Libby Garvey, chair of the Arlington County Board, said funds are going to be used in her community on a small tributary called Grandma's Creek.
"(The Grandma's Creek project) is a great example of community involvement and advocacy for a beloved neighborhood stream," Garvey said. "This project is going to propose the installation of rain gardens to better manage stormwater and increase the protection of the creek."
In addition to rain gardens, the Arlington community will also have the opportunity to participate in organized tree plantings and pop-up educational events centered around nature, Garvey said. The funds for these projects will be derived from the Small Watershed Grants Program, one of three grant programs administered by the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, which is to receive $193 million of the $206 million.
The NFWF already has announced it will be giving $1 million to farmers in Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia, with the intention of implementing high-priority conservation practices that improve water quality.
"There are 40,000 farms in Pennsylvania, and many of them contribute nutrients and sediment to the bay," Rep. Don Beyer (D-Virginia) said. "So anything we can do to get Pennsylvania on board with Maryland, Virginia and Delaware will be incredibly important."
The Chesapeake Bay Trust, another non-profit grant-making organization, will receive the remaining $13 million from the EPA. The trust will use the money to assist local organizations involved with improving the bay.
This could include providing operational infrastructure like computers and other hardware, or funding employee training and professional development sessions.
"We have to do better on agricultural runoff, and we have to do better on stormwater runoff. We do well on sewage treatment and on other point source pollution," Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Virginia) told Capital News Service. "This $200 million is going to be heavily focused on grants that focus on non-point sources, and we should continue to see significant improvements."

title: Caroline County Commissioners, state legislators discuss priorities for General Assembly
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County Commissioners, state legislators discuss priorities for General Assembly

 September 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 463
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners hosted multiple state legislators at the Health and Public Service Building for their annual meeting with the county on Tuesday.The meeting gave the commissioners a chance to make requests for the upcoming General Assembly, which will begin in January.
All towns within Caroline County were allowed to add to the list of requests. The town of Denton was the lone town to make a request this year.
Here are the requests made by Caroline County:
Local Legislative Requests
The county made a request that the state allow the county to designate a newspaper of record. A paper of record is the paper in a county that is designated by a government or entity to publish official notices, laws and public information.
Bond Bills
Denton is requesting a bond upgrade for the town's wastewater treatment facility. According to the county's request, the facility's "sludge drying system is nearing the end of its usable life and requires replacement. A Preliminary Engineering Study identified the best upgrade alternative, with an estimated cost exceeding $8 million."
The town applied for grants for three years but only received loan options with partial forgiveness. The request said state funding is critical.
Sharp Road Park Expansion
Denton is also requesting a bond for a playground at Sharp Road Park. According to the request, the "total project costs are estimated at more than $1 million. While the town has secured some funding from the Department of Natural Resources and submitted additional applications, further support is needed."
Items of Concern
Restore full funding for the Rural Maryland Prosperity Investment Fund. The Mid-Shore Regional Council and the Rural Maryland Council are requesting the state restore full funding for the Rural Maryland Prosperity Investment Fund to its intended level of $9 million in fiscal year 2027. The fund aims to help raise the overall standard of living in rural areas to a level that meets or exceeds statewide benchmark averages by 2030.State highway request to build Gay Street/Shore Highway intersection with coordinated traffic light. Denton has supported the construction of Commerce Drive, a roadway connecting Gay Street to Legion Road at the Walmart intersection. The Maryland Department of Transportation previously approved a signalized intersection at Gay Street and Route 404. While private partnerships to build the road have stalled, the town remains committed to advancing the project and requests county support.Renewal of highway user revenue. Denton and the county request the restoring of the highway user revenue. The request states how important the highway user revenue is for residents of Caroline County. "Without these funds, roadway conditions deteriorate, creating safety concerns and vehicle damage for residents and visitors. Restoring local Highway User Revenues would provide the Town with the resources necessary to address road maintenance needs in a timely and responsible manner," The county said in the request.

title: Department of Community Services highlights caregivers and resources
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Department of Community Services highlights caregivers and resources

 November 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Proclaiming National Caregivers Month and celebrating all family caregivers in the nation, the Department of Community Services also presented annual updates to the Queen Anne's County Commissioners Nov. 12.Families are often the primary source of support and care for older adults and people with disabilities and according to the National Caregivers Month proclamation, over 53 million Americans are currently family caregivers for loved ones and a large number provide care 24 hours a day.
"Ironically we depend more so on family caregivers than on paid caregivers to manage needs with family, elders, young adults, anyone who is requiring caregiving," said Cathy Willis, director of the county's Community Services.
Caregivers are encouraged to take moments for themselves to re-vitalize and attend caregiver meetings and reach out to the Queen Anne's County Area Aging Agency for support resources.
The Queen Anne's County Department of Community Services includes the Area Agency on Aging, County Ride public transit, Housing Authority and the Local Management Board.
The Housing Authority division is newly a part of the Community Services Department, and putting a face to the names of the essential work, Executive Director Mike Clark of the Housing and Family Services introduced staff to the commissioners during the Nov. 12 meeting.
The Division of Housing and Community Services aims to help residents with affordable housing with the ultimate goal of creating opportunities for brighter futures by offering "a hand up, not a handout," according to Clark.
The county's transit service, County Ride, takes around 100 riders to and from work weekly and goes to all four senior centers on a daily basis, according to Chief of Aging and Transportation Anne Sparks.
County Ride also partners with high schools to teach graduating seniors with special needs how to ride public transportation.
For 2024, County Ride is shaping up to finish with over 5,000 rides more than 2023 and 20,000 rides more than 2022, she said.
"It's very successful," Sparks said.
Currently the Queen Anne's County Local Management Board is focusing on Community Reinvestment Repair Funds, which were established by the Queen Anne's County Local Management Board under Maryland's 2023 Cannabis Reform Act in support of initiatives to uplift communities impacted by historical inequities, fostering economic empowerment, youth development, and housing stability, according to Clark.
Through the Local Management Board and the Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development, priorities include homelessness prevention, after-school programs, community resource needs and minority business programs, Clark said.
The Active Aging Center at the Queen Anne's County YMCA in Centreville is also celebrating its one year anniversary, according to Sparks. With an overall attendance of more than 4,000 participants, the new location has seen over 500 new memberships, as well as a large number of congregant meals served, she said.
More information about community services, including County Ride schedules can be found at qac.org/1291/Community-Services.

title: 'Stage Fright' brings dark humor to Avalon
author: Staff Writer
content:
'Stage Fright' brings dark humor to Avalon

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — This Halloween, immerse yourself in a haunting, unforgettable journey as "Stage Fright: Curtain Call" returns to the Avalon Theatre from Wednesday, Oct. 23, to Sunday, Oct. 27. With shows at 6:30 p.m. each night and additional 9:30 p.m. performances on Thursday through Sunday, this locally written and directed show promises a macabre experience that blurs the lines between reality and delusion.The production is recommended for ages 16 and up; guests under 16 must be accompanied by a responsible guardian. Tickets are available through the Avalon Foundation website at avalonfoundation.org/event/stage-fright-curtain-call.
Set in 1997, "Stage Fright: Curtain Call" invites audiences into the dark, twisted world of Lou Baker, a 95-year-old former showman tormented by a violent past and spectral figures. Facing release from a psychiatric institution after over three decades, Lou's story unfolds through a captivating, immersive theater experience filled with unresolved mysteries, dark humor, and a chilling confrontation between past and present.
Inspired by real ghost stories, the experience features sound and lighting effects, unique smells, special themed drinks and specially crafted Lyon Rum cocktails, making it an evening attendees won't soon forget. Mature themes and extensive walking are part of this production.
"Stage Fright: Curtain Call" is the thrilling final act of a trilogy, with each installment having been set in a different era — 1927, 1964 and now, at the turn of the century in 1997. The production explores the final days of Lou Baker, who is "95 and can barely get out of bed on his own." When presented with one last chance to release the spirit of Marguerite, his long, lost love and the ghost of the Avalon Theatre, he is met with a harrowing twist in his spiraling and tortured tale.
Attendees are encouraged to dress up in their favorite '90s attire or Halloween costume. The play draws heavy inspiration from '90s MTV, and The Factory invites guests to arrive as their best Britney Spears, Madonna, Notorious B.I.G., Spice Girls, and other '90s celebrities.
Cecile Strom directs the production, with Talley Wilford as assistant director and Casey Rauch as writer and co-collaborator.
"A key element of The Factory's immersive productions is the integration of film," Director Cecile Storm said. "It adds depth, context, and atmosphere to the live experience. This production takes this idea to new heights. I don't want to give too much away, but expect the boundary between stage and screen to blur in exciting and unexpected ways."
Katie Cox stars in the leading role, supported by the Beauty Shop Quartet: Jennifer Madino as Marguerite Gardot, Grace Vorosmarti as Shirley Boudreaux, Maddie Megahan as Vivian Baker and Jeri Alexander as Minnie Valentine. Art and production are managed by Maggii Sarfaty, and Ray Nissen leads the music direction.
"The acting is captivating and intense. The music is well done and is such a nice touch to this already so creatively awesome haunted house-like experience," shared an audience member from a past production. Another remarked, "It was great to see how the connection is made and everything is so eerily familiar, seeing as it's about the ghost that has haunted the Avalon for many years right here in Easton."

title: Women banned from speaking in public in Afghanistan under new Taliban restrictions
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Women banned from speaking in public in Afghanistan under new Taliban restrictions

 August 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: World 
 
 567
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Women are not allowed to speak, sing or show their faces in public under new laws in Afghanistan imposed by the Islamist Taliban regime.The Taliban laws silencing women come along with Islamic restrictions prohibiting women and girls from attending schools and colleges and interacting with men who are not their relatives.
Human rights groups — including Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch — as well as the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights condemned the new restrictions.
The Taliban law "silences women's voices and deprives them of their autonomy, "effectively attempting to render them into faceless, voiceless shadows", said UN spokeswoman Ravina Shamdasani. "This is utterly intolerable."
The restrictive Sharia law-based Islamist regime returned to power in 2021 after the Biden-Harris administration withdrew U.S. troops from Afghanistan and the American-backed government and military immediately collapsed.
The U.S. invaded Afghanistan in 2001 after the 9/11 terror attacks against New York and Washington deposing the ruling Taliban and installing an American-supported government and military.
The U.S. occupied Afghanistan until its chaotic exit and retreat from the mountainous country in 2021. Afghanistan is the world's largest producer of opium — the prime ingredient in heroin and other opiates.
The Taliban seized $7 billion worth of U.S. weapons and military vehicles and systems after the American retreat. More than 2,400 American troops died during the war and occupation and there more than 221,000 deaths overall, according to Uppsala University in Sweden.
A U.S. State Department inspector general's report last month said the U.S. may have mistakingly sent as much as $293 million in foreign aid to the Taliban after the 2021 withdrawal.
Since regaining power, the Taliban have put in place restrictive Sharia Law based on Islamic rules aimed at women and girls, including requiring full coverings of women's faces and bodies.
"Taliban have issued more than eighty edicts targeting the twenty million women and girls who make up just short of 50 percent of Afghanistan's population. Women and girls face draconian restrictions in public life, namely, on education, employment, access to the justice system, and activities and travel outside the home. These include prohibitions on education beyond sixth grade, veiling and dress codes enforceable by the morality police, and bans on leaving the house without a mahram, a male relative chaperone," the Council on Foreign Relations in a summary of the regime's actions.
"Afghanistan's Taliban rulers have issued a ban on women's voices and bare faces in public under new laws approved by the supreme leader in efforts to combat vice and promote virtue."
The new bans on women's voices and bare faces in were handed down last month after they were approved by supreme leader Hibatullah Akhundzada. The Taliban set up a ministry for the "propagation of virtue and the prevention of vice" after regaining power in 2021.
The U.S. State Department also criticized the Taliban's actions.
"The Taliban's relentless, discriminatory edicts and extreme policies are unparalleled and self-defeating. We have made clear to them in the last three years that they have a forked road ahead. If they respect the rights of the Afghan people and abide by Afghanistan's normative obligations, that is the road to reintegration into the international community. But the path the Taliban are pursuing is the same approach that made them a pariah in the 1990s. Their institutionalized campaign targeting women and girls constitutes gender persecution. The world is losing patience," said Rina Amiri, the U.S. Special Envoy for Afghan Women, Girls, and Human Rights. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Critically important': Frederick Douglass Day brings insight
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
'Critically important': Frederick Douglass Day brings insight

 September 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 529
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Cloudy and rainy weather did not stop hundreds of people from attending Frederick Douglass Day at the Talbot County Court House in Easton on Saturday.Douglass has strong roots in Talbot County and throughout the Eastern Shore.
Born in Talbot County in 1818, Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey Douglass was enslaved for 20 years in Baltimore and on Talbot County farms. He fled north in 1838 and changed his name to Frederick Douglass. His brilliance, eloquence and courage, quickly brought him to the forefront of the abolitionist movement.
He was known for his skills as an orator, with many of his speeches remembered to this day.
"I would say critically important," James Young, the event's publicist, said said about Douglass. "He's one of, if not the most respected and important figures in the history of the region. I think it's important for anybody to know more about his life and his work but especially for people who come from where he came from."
Frederick Douglass Day kicked off with a parade led by Grand Marshal Childlene Brooks, former president of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society. The parade featured local groups including Building African American Minds, Easton High School NJROTC Color Guard, Polaris Village Academy, and the Easton and Oxford Fire Departments and many more.
This year, a big focus for the Frederick Douglass Honor Society was getting the younger generation involved in celebrating Douglass.
Gabriella Thompson, the mistress of ceremony, described as a "ambitious 14-year-old entering her freshman year of high school," and Javion Jones, a 15-year-old minister at Union Baptist Church, were some of the youth featured throughout the day.
"I would say there has been some effort to get new people involved. As you know, a lot of people on the committee itself are getting up there," Young said. "So it's a thing that we want to keep going for the foreseeable future, and so at some point you've got to bring in some some fresh blood."
Multiple local leaders attended and participated in Frederick Douglass Day.
Jaelon Moaney, vice chair of the Maryland Commission on African American History and Culture, recited a famous speech by Douglass. The honor society believes having connections like Moaney are important for the success of the society and the annual event.
"Having that connection to African-American history more broadly, as well as current African-American issues, I think is very important," Young said. "That's also something that we try to focus on with the keynote speaker that we bring every year. It's somebody who can bring a perspective of speaking on Douglas but also how he kind of fits into the history of African-American intellectual philosophy."
In an email following the event, Moaney emphasized his own Eastern Shore roots, similar to those of Douglass.
"I, too, am from and decidedly of Talbot," Moaney said. "The Bailey and Moaney families remain connected today. Although two agitators separated by time, my chest began to swell with inexplicable energy while echoing the words delivered on November 25, 1878 from exactly where he stood nearly two centuries prior. As the country commemorates the semiquincentennial and Talbot reaches its 365th anniversary next year, I'm both troubled and moved by the parallels of reality that this experience has revealed." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland gas prices stay almost level for week
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland gas prices stay almost level for week

 July 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 455
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Baltimore have fallen 0.4 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.44 per gallon today, according to GasBuddy's survey of 663 stations in Baltimore. Prices in Baltimore are 12.7 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 30.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has fallen 1.2 cents in the last week and stands at $3.78 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Baltimore was priced at $3.19 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $3.99 per gallon, a difference of 80.0 cents per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 0.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.47 per gallon today. The national average is down 0.8 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 25.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Baltimore and the national average going back 10 years:
July 29, 2023: $3.74 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.73 per gallon)July 29, 2022: $4.13 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.21 per gallon)July 29, 2021: $3.07 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.16 per gallon)July 29, 2020: $2.28 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.19 per gallon)July 29, 2019: $2.59 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.72 per gallon)July 29, 2018: $2.76 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.84 per gallon)July 29, 2017: $2.25 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.31 per gallon)July 29, 2016: $2.06 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.13 per gallon)July 29, 2015: $2.63 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.68 per gallon)July 29, 2014: $3.52 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.51 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Maryland: $3.46 per gallon, down 1.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.48 per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: $3.64 per gallon, down 2.6 cents per gallon from last week's $3.66 per gallon.
Hagerston: $3.69 per gallon, down 4.5 cents per gallon from last week's $3.74 per gallon.
"We continue to see a mixed bag when it comes to gas prices across the country: states in the Great Lakes region are still being jolted by the Joliet, IL refinery outage, which has also impacted gas prices in some areas of Canada, while areas like the West Coast continue to see notable declines," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With the summer winding down and GasBuddy data showing disappointing gasoline demand and struggling oil prices, we could eventually see the national average falling a bit more, especially once the refinery in Illinois restarts operations. While hurricane season hasn't been a factor yet, it's also just starting to get into its prime, and that does remain a quiet wildcard for now."

title: Easton department announces first Community Police Academy
content:
Easton department announces first Community Police Academy

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 437
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Easton Police Department announced its first Community Police Academy.The goal of this program, the department said in a press release, is to educate the public about the Easton Police Department and to increase the rapport between community members and police officers.The Community Police Academy will take place from 6 to 9 p.m. on the following eleven evenings: Jan. 17, Jan. 24, Jan. 31, Feb. 7, Feb. 15, Feb. 21, Feb. 28, March 6, March 13, March 20 and March 27.Most of the classes will meet at the Easton Police Department on 106 W.Dover St. in Easton. To "graduate," attendees may not miss more than two classes.The class curriculum will be different each week.Students will become familiar with the different functions in the police department and experience the decisions that officers must make in different situations, according to the release."We hope the graduates of the Community Police Academy complete the program with a better understanding of the Easton Police Department and will encourage others to participate in this rewarding program," EPD wrote in a release. "We invite Easton residents to apply and learn more about their Easton Police Department. If you are interested in attending, please contact the Easton Police Department. Class size is limited, so don't wait."Questions about this program can be directed to: EPDCareers@eastonmd.gov. Applications can be filled out at: eastonmd.gov/604/Community-Police-AcademyQUALIFICATIONSEligible applicants must meet the following criteria:. Resident of the Town of Easton. At least 18 years of age. Willing to sign a waiver of liability, consent to criminal history check form, and a limited confidentiality agreement form.An applicant may be disqualified from participating for any of the following reasons, including but not limited to:. Outstanding warrants of any type.· Having a conviction or being under indictment for, or currently charged with any violent felony offense.· Having a history of/or conviction for any sexual or family violence related offense.· Cannot be a suspect of any criminal case, regardless of the case outcome within the past three years.· Association with any person or organization which advocates hatred, prejudice or oppression of any person or group or which disseminates such material.· Association with any organization, association, movement, or group which advocates the commission of acts of force or violence to deny others their rights under the Constitution of the United States or which seeks to alter the form of government of the United States by unconstitutional means.· Has a pending lawsuit against the Department.Any other indications of criminal history, criminal involvement and/or previous law enforcement involvement will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis and considered in the application process.

title: Survey for Talbot County comprehensive plan update is open
author: Konner Metz
content:
Survey for Talbot County comprehensive plan update is open

 May 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As Talbot County prepares to update its comprehensive plan, residents are asked to share their thoughts through an online survey.Bryce Yelton, the county's assistant planning officer, said Tuesday that updates to the actual comprehensive plan language haven't started. But the process is beginning, he said, with an emphasis community input.
The survey, which takes around 10 to 15 minutes to fill out, is available online through May 23. The county has already received 250 responses as of Tuesday, Yelton said.
"You'll put in some stuff you think Talbot County's doing well, some things you think we could improve," Yelton said. "It's an overall messaging to try and get the community's feedback before we highlight the important parts of the plan, what we really want to focus in and update on."
Talbot County's comprehensive plan was last revised in 2016. It directs how the county will move forward in regard to land use, housing, preservation, transportation and more.
Yelton said the planning and zoning department is looking for the plan to be updated by the fall of 2026.
County Manager Clay Stamp thanked Yelton, Communications Manager Sarah Kilmon and staff for meeting the council's overarching goal of transparency by including the public in the first step of the process.
"I'd just like to give a shoutout to staff on this," Stamp said. "Council, you've really kind of created a mandate for staff to try to enhance our transparency and communication with the public."
The survey can be accessed at surveymonkey.com/r/B83RG3X. For more information and updates on the comprehensive plan update, visit engage.talbotcountymd.gov/compplan.

title: The Maryland Ironman is not for the weak
author: Lily Tierney
content:
The Maryland Ironman is not for the weak

 September 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Headlines 
 
 156
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I was cranky because my socks and shoes were wet, and I was struggling to get a good shot in the light rain.But then I watched athletes, one by one, cross the finish line after swimming 2.4 miles in the Choptank River, biking 112 miles through Blackwater Wildlife Refuge and running 26.22 miles through historic Cambridge, and I realized I didn't have a single thing to complain about.
One of the athletes immediately collapsed in the nearest chair and began to sob. His teammates, one bleeding from his knee and elbow, embraced him and gave him a water. Literal blood, sweat and tears.
When describing his eight-and-a-half-hour endeavor, the first place athlete described feeling a jellyfish wrap around his face and neck during the swimming portion.
The Maryland Ironman is not for the weak.
Read about the 11th annual Maryland Ironman and much more in today's paper. As always, thanks for reading and have a great day!
— Lily Tierney

title: Photo talk to explore junction of science and art
author: Contributed
content:
Photo talk to explore junction of science and art

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 278
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If it's the aim of the fine arts to give insight or inspiration, then the scientific image is worthy of consideration as an artistic medium, argues Norm Baker, a professor of pathology and art as applied to medicine at Johns Hopkins University.Baker will be speaking at the Tidewater Camera Club's Nov. 6 meeting, to be held at Unitarian Universalist Church in Easton from 7 to 9 p.m., on the subject, delving into the history of photography as a scientific discipline.Ironically, photography was invented by a scientist and not an artist.It was the scientists who realized the importance of this new and novel process to document and to elucidate their scientific activities. The idea of having objects draw themselves on a plate without the aid of an artist's hand is a concept that is foreign now, but that's exactly how one of the early inventors, William Henry Fox Talbot, described his Calotype process.Baker will make his case on the subject at the meeting, which is free and open to the public. This talk will examine how the context in which a photograph is viewed can have an effect on how the image is interpreted.Baker's photographs are in the permanent collections of more than forty museums, including The Smithsonian, The George Eastman Museum, The American Museum of Natural History, The Nelson-Atkins Museum and The Science Museum in London.He has published 9 books and numerous scientific articles and book chapters.His current traveling exhibition "Hidden Beauty: Exploring The Aesthetics of Medical Science" shows the beauty of medicine and the human body and will be going on a museum tour in 2014-2023. His latest book "Perambulations" was published in 2022 by Man & Lion Press.

title: Indictment returned for man who allegedly killed girlfriend, buried her in forest
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Indictment returned for man who allegedly killed girlfriend, buried her in forest

 April 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 432
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A man charged with murdering his girlfriend is back in Charles County after being returned from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement custody.The state's attorney for Charles County advised that on Friday, April 25, a grand jury returned an indictment for Keycy Robinson Alexi Barrera-Rosa, 24, of Waldorf for the murder of Lesbia Mileth Ramirez Guerra.
The indictment charges Barrera-Rosa with first-degree murder, second-degree murder and making a false report, a release from the state's attorney's office said.
On April 2, Barrera-Rosa contacted the Charles County Sheriff's Office to report that his girlfriend, Guerra, was missing from their Waldorf residence. During the investigation, detectives reviewed video surveillance showing the victim entering their residence on March 31 but never exiting, the release said.
Witnesses reported that during the early morning hours of April 1 Barrera-Rosa and Guerra were allegedly in a violent argument.
During the afternoon of April 1, video surveillance allegedly captured Barrera-Rosa grabbing a large plastic bin from a shed in his backyard and carrying it to the back of the house, the state's attorney's office said.
Barrera-Rosa then drove his truck to the back of the house.
Cellular tower data records indicate that Barrera-Rosa traveled to Prince George's County to meet with his uncle, Rolvin Eduardo Barerra-Barerra, at a construction worksite, according to the release.
Further cellular records indicate that Barrera-Rosa and his uncle traveled to a secluded, densely wooded intersection in the area of Cedarville State Park.
Barerra-Barerra was interviewed by detectives and reported that on April 1 his nephew told him that he had killed his girlfriend by strangulation and asked for help with hiding the body, the release said.
He further stated that when Barrera-Rosa allegedly traveled to his work site in Prince George's County, the woman was already deceased and in a plastic bin in the back of Barrera-Rosa's vehicle.
The uncle, Barerra-Barerra, allegedly told detectives that he and Barrera-Rosa disposed of the Guerra's body by burying her in a wooded area near Cedarville State Park, the release said.
On April 18, Charles sheriff's officers located Guerra's body in a plastic bin buried at a location described by Barerra-Barerra and in proximity to where phone records indicated Barrera-Rosa and his uncle parked their vehicles on April 1.
On April 5, Barrera-Rosa was arrested and detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement for unrelated charges.
On April 22, he was transported by ICE agents and turned over to the Charles County Sheriff's Office. He is being held without bond at the Charles County Detention Center.
Barerra-Barerra has been charged as an accessory after the fact to murder in Prince George's County and is also being held without bond in that jurisdiction. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Eagles rally to oust Colonels - Mistakes, Granado's fourth-quarter TD end season for Colonel Richardson
author: Kyle Ingerson; Special To The Cecil Whig
content:
Eagles rally to oust Colonels - Mistakes, Granado's fourth-quarter TD end season for Colonel Richardson

 November 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Kyle Ingerson; Special To The Cecil Whig | Page: 23A | Section: Sports 
 
 484
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESAPEAKE CITY - Despite being in the midst of a long offensive slump, Bohemia Manor High put together its best quarter of football in recent weeks Friday night, rallying in the fourth quarter to defeat Colonel Richardson in a Class 1A East Regional first-round playoff game.The Eagles advance to Friday's semifinals, traveling to top-seeded Perryville at 7 p.m.Trailing by a point with just under nine minutes to play, Bohemia Manor stopped Colonel Richardson on a fourth-and-2 to get the ball back in Colonel Richardson territory. Two plays later, Junior Council ripped off a 25-yard run to set the Eagles up with a first-and-goal. Xavier Granado then took it in from four yards out to give the Eagles their first lead of the game with 7:12 remaining.Granado credited his offensive line for helping him find the holes necessary to get the go-ahead score."I love my line," Granado said. "They got me anywhere I needed to go and that's all you can hope for in a playoff game." After another defensive stop on the ensuing Colonel Richardson possession, Bohemia Manor found its in familiar territory as its offense had the ball in the final minutes with a chance to seal the victory.The Eagles did just that as a key 18-yard run by Granado, followed by Chris Harris' quarterback keeper on a third-and-3 resulted in a first down. Harris' rushing touchdown in the second quarter put the Eagles within a point at the half."I just let my running back and my o-line do the work," Harris said. "Let them get the yards, burn the clock, get the first downs and seal the win." Colonel Richardson head coach James Jackson thought his team made too many self-inflicted mistakes down the stretch that cost them in a close game.Colonel Richardson led for the majority of the game after taking an early 7-0 lead in the first quarter on quarterback Tarron Hammond's 5-yard touchdown run."We were our own 12th man," Jackson said. "We had some bad snaps and got behind in the distance on drives and it hurt us. It's been like that for us all year but in a playoff game you can't have that." Bo Manor head coach Vince Ricci praised his team for its gritty performance and not letting the results from the previous two weeks carry into the playoff openere. The Eagles entered Friday's contest coming off back-to-back losses against Perryville and Fallston.Bohemia Manor scored a combined two points in the pair of losses.Perryville defeated Bohemia Manor 42-2 in the regular season three weeks ago."We knew coming in that we needed to get back to being gritty and playing Bo Manor football," Ricci said."It takes us back to those first couple weeks when we were winning by grinding out the end of game situations." 
 
 Caption: KYLE INGERSON/CECIL WHIG
 
Bohemia Manor's Drew Lenz (4) is wrapped up by a trio of Colonel Richardson players during Friday night's Class 1A East Regional playoff.

title: New lineup featured for annual jazz, funk and R & B festival
author: Ted Black; tblack@somdnews.com

New lineup featured for annual jazz, funk and R & B festival

 August 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Saturday afternoon, Aug. 26, the Calvert County Fairgrounds will undergo a modest transformation of sorts when it hosts the Southern Maryland Wine, Jazz, R & B and Funk Festival, with a new lineup of musical talent and ample food, fun and wine among the more notable featured attractions.During most summers since 2015, the R & B and Funk Festival has attracted numerous local musical talents and also offers patrons with the chance to savor the music and wins produced by various Maryland distilleries.Organizers have promised a relaxing day for a mature crowd - guests must be 21 years of age or older to attend - with live music provided by local and regional artists and bands."Since day one, we've built a following of attendees who look forward to great music, food and fun that we bring each year," Onyx Linthicum said. "We are revered as a premier event in Southern Maryland that has brought travelers from as far west as Arizona. We pride ourselves on our platform that gives local and regional talent the recognition they deserve." Among the artists and bands expected to perform on Saturday include DJ B-Blast, Janelle Sy'mone, Kevin Powe, Marcus H. Mitchell, Natalie Redd, Ronny Smith, The Vaughn Bratcher Project and Soundcheck. The Funk Festival, which kicked off in 2015, was idle in 2020 and 2021 amid the COVID-19 pandemic before returning last summer."We are excited about the return of the Original Southern Maryland Wine, Jazz, R & B and Funk Festival for its sixth year," Linthicum said. "This year promises to be even greater with an all-new musical lineup, newly added spirits tasting, and the return of the VIP tent that features an all-inclusive package with massages, open bar and exclusive buffet." There will be wine on tap, with tents and coolers acceptable although no outside alcoholic beverages are allowed.Organizers remind those planning to attend that tickets must be purchased online and will not be sold at the gate."We are excited about 2023 and already eagerly looking forward to partner with community businesses and sponsors for the upcoming 2024 season," Linthicum said.

title: Donations ease financial needs
author: Staff Writer
content:
Donations ease financial needs

 November 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 339
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Association of Social Services Boards (MASSB) Foundation is composed entirely of volunteers who serve on local boards in all 23 counties in the state of Maryland.For those of you who are not familiar with the Caroline County Department of Social Services' Advisory Board, our mission is to provide assistance to support families in financial crisis that do not meet federal and/or state program eligibility but need assistance.
Under the auspices of the Maryland Association of the Social Services Boards, an established nonprofit, the Caroline County Department of Social Services' Board of Directors oversees the Community Assistance Fund, which responds to unmet needs that are fundamental to the safety, health and well-being of Caroline County's children and adults.
Since its inception in 2012, Caroline's Community Assistance Fund has assisted county residents with rental, utilities arrearages and food insecurities. Additionally, the fund provides support in the form of medical supplies and emergency repairs for the elderly.
As you may be aware, there continues to be a growing number of county residents with unmet needs. As we move into the winter months and the holiday season we anticipate an increased need for holiday assistance for families with children and our elderly who are not as fortunate. Any assistance garnered through this drive will also go towards assisting our seniors in need.
We would like to thank you for the generous support you've provided in the past and encourage you to donate whatever you can to our organization to help our less-fortunate neighbors. Please make your checks payable to MASSB Foundation and mail them to:
Juanita A. Webster, Board Chair; Caroline County Department of Social Services; P.O. Box 400; Denton, MD 21629.
Donations can also be made via credit card at massbfoundation.org. Please add a note that your donation is in support of Caroline County Department of Social Services. All donations are 100% tax deductible.
MASSB is an all-volunteer organization so you will have the comfort of knowing that your funds will go directly to those in need.
Thank you for your kindness and your support.
JUANITA A. WEBSTER
Denton

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/May 14
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/May 14

 May 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 268
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On May 14, 1804, the Lewis and Clark expedition, organized to explore the Louisiana Territory as well as the Pacific Northwest, began its journey near present-day Hartford, Illinois.Also on this date:
In 1607, Jamestown, the first permanent English settlement in North America, was established by members of the Virginia Company.
In 1796, English physician Edward Jenner successfully inoculated 8-year-old James Phipps against smallpox by using cowpox matter. (Smallpox would be declared the first fully eradicated human disease in 1980.)
In 1948, the independent state of Israel was proclaimed in Tel Aviv by David Ben-Gurion, who became its first prime minister.
In 1955, representatives from eight Communist bloc countries, including the Soviet Union, signed the Warsaw Pact in Poland. (The pact was dissolved in 1991.)
In 1961, Freedom Rider civil rights activists were attacked by violent mobs in Anniston and Birmingham, Alabama.
In 1973, NASA launched Skylab, the first American space station, from Kennedy Space Center in Florida.
In 2022, an 18-year-old white supremacist wearing body armor opened fire in a supermarket in a predominantly Black neighborhood in Buffalo, New York, killing 10 people before being taken into custody. (The gunman, Payton Gendron, was sentenced to life in prison without parole in February 2023.)
Today's Birthdays: Baseball Hall of Famer Tony Pérez is 83. Filmmaker George Lucas is 81. Filmmaker Robert Zemeckis is 74. Musician David Byrne is 73. Actor Tim Roth is 64. Actor Cate Blanchett is 56. Filmmaker Sofia Coppola is 54. Former NFL running back Frank Gore is 42. Actor Amber Tamblyn is 42. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg is 41. Former NFL tight end Rob Gronkowski is 36. Actor Miranda Cosgrove is 32.

title: America's haunted tourism industry generates up to $500M annually: 12 spooky destinations to visit
author: Elise Armitage Wealth of Geeks
content:
America's haunted tourism industry generates up to $500M annually: 12 spooky destinations to visit

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Elise Armitage Wealth of Geeks | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1135
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every year, haunted tourism in the United States scares up profits of paranormal proportions.According to America Haunts, a group of 20 haunted attractions nationwide, the U.S. industry brings in between $300 and $500 million annually. Haunts throughout the country attract large crowds year-round, especially around Halloween.
In its 2023 Haunt Industry Report, HauntPay, a haunted attraction ticketing platform, reports 33% of haunts were expecting to receive upwards of 10,000 visitors, a notable increase from 2022. That year, 42% of haunted attractions saw visitor numbers between 1,000 and 5,000.
Venture beyond the grave and visit some of America's scariest real-life haunts to celebrate the season.
12 Terrifying Places in America to Embrace Your Spooky SideFrom abandoned prisons to historic homes and even a zoo, these are 12 of the scariest haunted locations in America worth visiting this month.
Eastern State Penitentiary, PennsylvaniaExplore the supposedly haunted grounds of Philadelphia's Eastern State Penitentiary — if you dare. This abandoned prison once held famous criminals like Al Capone and Willie Sutton before closing in 1971 and falling into disrepair.
"Visiting Eastern State Penitentiary is like stepping into a real-life horror movie," says Partners in Fire owner Melanie Allen. "The desolate, crumbling halls and long-abandoned rooms hold an unyielding tension."
Visitors can tour the prison year-round. The facility also hosts seasonal Halloween Nights, which feature haunted houses, spine-tingling tours, themed bars, and live entertainment.
The House of the Seven Gables, MassachusettsThe House of the Seven Gables, built in 1668, is among Salem's eeriest attractions. Nathaniel Hawthorne's novel of the same name mainstreamed the property.
The home is a must-visit for those interested in colonial architecture and Salem lore. Every October, tourists can enjoy autumnal storytelling performances that heighten the unsettling atmosphere ahead of Halloween.
Waverly Hills Sanatorium, KentuckyGhost-hunting enthusiasts flock to Waverly Hills Sanatorium, a former tuberculosis treatment center operational from 1910 to 1961.
Many visitors report supernatural encounters, from doors slamming on their own to sightings of a young ghost boy. Delve into the property's dark past on a guided tour, or pack a tote with essentials for a private overnight investigation.
Waverly Hills Sanatorium also hosts a terrifying haunted house during the fall, made scarier by the sanatorium's paranormal reputation.
Stanley Hotel, ColoradoThe Stanley Hotel opened in 1909 as a getaway for guests seeking upscale accommodations in Colorado's Rocky Mountains. Its reputation faltered in the 1970s, but one visit from author Stephen King changed everything. King later wrote his horror classic The Shining, drawing inspiration from Stanley Hotel.
Guests often claim to hear disembodied laughter, feel phantom touches, and sense ghostly presences. Amp up the scares during your overnight stay with a theatrical séance or nighttime tour.
Lincoln Park Zoo, IllinoisIn addition to the zoo animals you'd expect to see, Lincoln Park Zoo is reportedly home to several spirits. Lincoln Park was once the site of Chicago's official city cemetery, and some say thousands of bodies remain buried there today.
The zoo hosted its first official paranormal investigation in 2013 after reports of apparitions and disembodied voices in the Lion and Primate Houses.
October visitors can join an evening Haunted History Tour to learn more about the zoo's hauntings. Wear comfortable shoes like boots to enjoy the eerie surroundings while exploring the zoo after dark.
Ohio State Reformatory, OhioThe historic Ohio State Reformatory operated from 1896 to 1990 and is the ideal destination for supernatural lovers. Visitors may recognize it from The Shawshank Redemption, filmed there in 1993.
There have been many documented instances of dark figures and incorporeal voices at the Ohio State Reformatory, even among inmates before its closure.
The reformatory boasts an impressive program for those seeking a supernatural encounter, including group ghost tours and private, hours-long investigations.
The Mark Twain House, Connecticut
Step back in time at the Mark Twain House in Connecticut, where the famous writer and his family lived in the late 1800s.
This Victorian home is a hotspot for unexplained phenomena, including sightings of a ghostly woman in white — possibly the spirit of one of Twain's daughters who died there.
Guests eager to explore this haunt can embark on a Graveyard Shift Ghost Tour to learn the home's most fascinating tales from beyond the grave.
St. Augustine Lighthouse, Florida
The spirits of several young children who died there in 1873 supposedly haunt Florida's St. Augustine Lighthouse.
Some lighthouse employees and visitors claim to hear giggling and see ghostly apparitions, while others feel an otherworldly presence throughout the site.
Hear spine-chilling stories of the lighthouse's hauntings on a group tour, or bring ghost-hunting equipment to conduct a private nighttime investigation.
Winchester Mystery House, CaliforniaThe Winchester Mystery House is among San Jose's strangest attractions. The owner, arms company heiress Sarah Winchester, began the bizarre multi-decade renovation following her family's death. She expanded the home to 24,000 square feet, installing 160 bedrooms, 13 bathrooms, and six kitchens.
"Doors open to nothing, stairs lead to solid walls, and there seems to be an overall feeling of chaos and unsettling vibes that bothered me when visiting," explains Chantelle Kincy of Flannels or Flipflops.
Over the years, many guests have claimed to see specters and hear footsteps in the Winchester Mystery House. Visitors can see areas of the home on year-round guided tours or embark on a seasonal haunted maze through four of the mansion's floors.
Bonaventure Cemetery, GeorgiaWhile southern Georgia's Bonaventure Cemetery is among the world's most beautiful cemeteries, it's also incredibly unsettling.
"It was extremely quiet, and there was an overwhelming feeling of sadness as we walked around," Jessy Hamel of Brighter Things shares about her visit.
Various local legends surround the cemetery, including voodoo rituals and a child spirit that roams the grounds. In October, the cemetery allows guests to embark on a full moon tour, enhancing the creepy atmosphere.
The Conjuring House, Rhode IslandSee the terrifying real-life home that inspired The Conjuring movie universe. The house's haunted history stretches back centuries since its construction in the 1730s.
In the 1970s, the Perron family bought the home and immediately started having ghostly run-ins. At one point, famed paranormal investigators Ed and Lorraine Warren took an interest in the house.
According to the Perron family, at least two spirits — a married couple who passed away in the 1800s — haunt the house. Interest in the property spiked following the 2013 release of The Conjuring, a hit horror movie that spawned an entire franchise.
The current homeowner offers a variety of spooky experiences, from guided daytime tours to overnight investigations where you can bring a blanket and settle in for a night of ghost-hunting.
San Fernando Cathedral, TexasSan Fernando Cathedral, established in 1731, is a beautifully haunting church. It's the oldest of its kind in Texas and is said to be among San Antonio's most haunted locations.
Numerous bodies lie within the cathedral walls, and visitors have reported spectral sightings of dark silhouettes and mysterious orbs. Many San Antonio ghost tours visit the historic cathedral to highlight its storied past.
This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Vikings look to complete year-long bid
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Vikings look to complete year-long bid

 March 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 739
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The day after last year's loss in the Class 1A state championship, Cambridge-South Dorchester High boys head basketball coach Shawn Tucker received a text message from forward Kobe Ennals."He already had next year's (state-title) date circled on his calendar," Tucker said.
That date has arrived, as the top-seeded Vikings (24-1) will face the The SEED School (17-5) on Friday at 2 p.m. for the Class 1A state championship at the University of Maryland's XFINITY Center in College Park.
"They've got size," Tucker said of SEED, which has three players listed at 6-foot-8 and another at 6-7. "We're going to have to really rebound by committee and get on the glass. But I like our chances."
A chance created Tuesday night, when Thomas Wilson Jr. banked home an off-balance fadeway jumper with 7.3 seconds left to boost the Vikings to a 65-63 victory over Liberty in the semifinals. A chance that was created on the SEED side of the ledger about two hours later, when Khaled Al-Matten Evans banked in a winner with 8 seconds remaining to help the Sabers complete a 60-59 come-from-behind victory over defending state champion Edmondson-Westside.
"I saw them play Edmondson last year," SEED head coach Edward Green Jr. said of Cambridge-SD Thursday during a phone interview. "I've been keeping up on them all year. So of course, very good team. Back in the title game, so that says a lot about their program. So that loss last year in the final, and to be able to come right back and reach the final again, I have a lot of respect for them doing that. I think they have overall good team size, and they're very talented."
A talented team that will bid for the school's first state title since 1996, and can have a different scoring leader any game.
A senior, the 6-5 Ennals has averaged 20 points and 11 rebounds an outing this season, while 6-4 junior Semaj Pinder comes in averaging 19 points a game. Junior guard Sterling Perkins Jr. has scored 15 a game, and Wilson, who has emerged down the stretch, had averaged 10 per contest. The Vikings have also gotten big contributions from seniors Anthony Hughes and Jaden Harris, and sophomore K'Marion Hall.
"We're a year older," said Tucker, who noted his team leaned heavily on graduated guard LaShaun Moody last season. "Our juniors were sophomores last year and they were out there just playing. Now, they're out there understanding our goal.
"And we're better this year because we had a guy like Thomas Wilson on our roster, and nobody knows about him," Tucker continued. "The kid can shoot the cover off the basketball. And he's getting opportunities. Now, he's been in the starting lineup and nobody really talks about him."
Green may have wondered if anybody was going to talk about his team after the Sabers suffered a 59-43 loss to St. Vincent Pallotti on Jan. 28. But SEED hasn't lost since and arrives to its first state final in program history riding a 10-game win streak.
"In our last loss to St. Vincent Pallotti, we didn't really step up and show our best selves," Green said. "So it was as matter of us not taking advantage of opportunity in the big games. As a small school, we're trying to make a name for ourself. But every opportunity we got against like an A Conference school, or we'd play Philly teams and teams in Virginia, and we didn't play our best basketball."
The Sabers played some of their best ball Tuesday against No. 2 seed Edmondson-Westside, erasing a seven-point, third quarter deficit en route to upsetting the defending champs.
"It's about understanding our identity," Green said. "And we have a defensive identity."
SEED has also established a winning identity since February. In addition to junior shooting guard, Al-Matten Evans, the backcourt features sophomore point guard Chase Pralieau and junior Tyler Dubose. Senior Ahmad Evans, a 6-8 center, 6-8 junior forward Merdi Tshiabide and 6-5 junior sixth man Omar Williams will look to make impacts inside and on the boards today.
"We just have to be true to ourselves," Green said. "I think defense travels. If we can limit some of the things they like to do, maybe take one thing away from them, I think it will give us a chance. But they have a lot of guys who can contribute. So we can't really focus as much on what they're going to do as much as what we have control over."

title: Attorney general visits Easton to honor first responders at annual celebration
author: Konner Metz
content:
Attorney general visits Easton to honor first responders at annual celebration

 June 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 433
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — First responders across different Talbot County agencies were honored Thursday in Easton by local residents, business leaders and Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown.Bluepoint Hospitality Group hosted the fifth annual First Responders Celebration, closing down North Washington Street temporarily on Thursday afternoon to pay thanks to the county's police officers, firefighters, EMTs and other first responders.
"These people put their lives on the line so that we can live in a civil and safe community," said Bluepoint Hospitality owner Paul Prager.
The event was headlined by Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown, who called the Talbot County first responders — paid or volunteers — "heroes."
"When others run away from danger, you run toward it," Brown said. "From volunteers who respond to dangerous house fires in the middle of the night, to police officers who take drugs, and guns and bad people off our streets, to emergency medical service personnel who rush people to the hospital for life-saving care, our first responders are the backbone of public safety and the cornerstone of our communities."
During the brief ceremonies, Ed Forte, vice president of the Friends of Easton Volunteer Fire Department, revealed a new rendering of an in-construction training campus to Easton Fire Chief J.R. Dobson.
The A. James Clark Emergency Services Training Campus, located on Mistletoe Drive, will be 7,200 square feet and provide state-of-the-art training opportunities for all first responders.
As the rendering showed, a building on the training campus will be named after Paul Prager and his wife, Joanne. The Pragers donated $500,000 to the project.
Forte said Thursday that $4.5 million has been raised in the last two-and-a-half years, nearly all of the project's $5 million goal. Project leaders hope for the campus to open by the end of this year.
"(It's) taken many, many years; many, many people; many hours; many ideas," Forte said. " … Raising the money was the hardest thing."
After the event, Brown said in an interview he's impressed with the coordination between the different first responder agencies in Talbot County.
"Often people think small, rural community on the Eastern Shore, 'how busy does it get?'" Brown said. "But clearly the numbers show that they're busy. It's important to stand ready. The facility that is going to be built is going to help them do that."
When asked afterward if the First Responders Celebration is becoming a tradition, Prager had no hesitation.
"It's gotta be, absolutely," Prager said. "These people do thankless jobs. And there's not a whole lot you can do to enable them to make their lives better. So I think if you at least just say thank you, that goes a long way."

 CHESTERTOWN - Maryland Lottery winners continued to claim winning tickets last week as the holiday season was in full swing, including several at the $50,000 level.In the weekly roundup of big winners was one woman claiming $50,000 in the state lottery Money Bag Multiplier. The ticket was sold at Lewes Dairy Market, 840 High Street in Chestertown.
The woman who did not wish to be named was from the area, store owner Hassan Mahmood said, but has redeemed her ticket. It was the fourth winning ticket sold by the store in the last couple of months he said.
Total winnings for the week remained on par with other weeks this year, coming in at $31 million, a figure that includes unclaimed draw game and FAST PLAY wins.
In all, 24 Maryland Lottery tickets worth $10,000 or more were sold or redeemed in the seven days ending Dec. 23. The Lottery paid more than $31 million in prizes during that period.
Winners of prizes larger than $25,000 must redeem their tickets at the Maryland Lottery Claims Center in Baltimore, which is open by appointment only. Prizes of up to $5,000 can be claimed at any of more than 400 Expanded Cashing Authority Program (XCAP) locations.
All Maryland Lottery retailers are authorized to redeem tickets up to and including $600. More information is available on the How To Claim page of mdlottery.com.
The Maryland Lottery encourages players to check their tickets by scanning them at any Lottery retailer or with the Lottery's mobile apps. Draw game winners have 182 days from the date of a drawing to claim their prizes, and scratchoff winners have 182 days from the announced end-of-game date.
Last claim dates for scratchoff tickets are published in the scratch-off section of mdlottery.com.
