title: Family fights Dunkirk cemetery's plan to move plot
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Family fights Dunkirk cemetery's plan to move plot

 December 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 508
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to her daughter, it was in 1989 that Gloria Moseley purchased two plots at Dunkirk's Southern Memorial Gardens. It was supposed to be a modest resting place in a quiet rural setting.Laura Dodgson, Moseley's daughter who now lives in North Carolina, said her sister died in 1994 and her brother died four years later. Urns containing their ashes were buried side-by-side on the site.
Gloria Moseley died in 2002 and eight years later her husband, Robert, passed. Both were laid to rest at the family gravesite.
Southern Memorial Gardens has had different owners since 1989, when the Moseleys purchased the plots.
Now the cemetery owners say mistakes have been made. Their solution has brought distress to the family.
In a letter to Southern Maryland News, Dodgson said she received a phone call from cemetery officials back in September.
"They stated that my family had been buried in the wrong plot and that they would have to be dug up and moved," Dodgson wrote.
During a phone conversation with Dodgson after the letter was received, Southern Maryland News learned cemetery officials, via mail, told her to sign papers for moving the family members to another location.
"I don't want them moved," Dodgson said.
When Southern Maryland News contacted the cemetery about the situation, the employee answering the phone provided contact information for the business's attorney, Kevin Vitelli.
"It happens at every cemetery," Vitelli said of the Moseley family's situation. "Mistakes were made in 1989. We're just trying to make it right."
Vitelli, whose law practice is based in Pennsylvania, said the relocation of the family's plot would be done at no additional cost.
The local cemetery has a well-documented history of problems.
Nearly 20 years ago, fraudulent activity on the part of former owner, Larry Deffenbaugh, came to light after a Maryland State Police investigation. Deffenbaugh was later convicted of defrauding over 500 people out of funeral and memorial items.
He had entered an Alford plea, which is not an admission of guilt, but an acknowledgment that prosecutors have evidence to support a charge, received a 15-year suspended sentence and ordered to pay restitution to the victims.
Deffenbaugh's story then gets more convoluted, as he was summoned back to court for a violation of probation hearing but failed to appear. Apparently not wishing to go to prison, Deffenbaugh reportedly fell off a fishing boat. He was, however, recaptured in 2010 and sent to prison.
Dodgson said her late sister's daughter, Pam, filed court papers to have her mother's urn removed from the cemetery and given over to her. Dodgson and another family member confirmed that the urn was flooded with water.
Dodgson said she fears the disturbance of the plot could result in the collapse of the vaults where her parents' coffins are laid.
The family has been in contact with attorneys for a possible breech of contract and gross negligence lawsuit.
"There were some mistakes made by prior owners," Vitelli said of the Southern Memorial Gardens situation. "We have to correct those mistakes."
The attorney added that while aggrieved plot owners have been urged to file suit, "nobody has filed any action against the cemetery." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Don't let challenges overcome your Christmas season
author: GLENN MOLLETTE
content:
Don't let challenges overcome your Christmas season

 December 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENN MOLLETTE | Section: Columns 
 
 525
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Christmas is a joyful season but always has some challenges.The place of Christmas is often a question. Mary and Joseph ended up in Bethlehem when Jesus was born. They had gone there to pay taxes. Paying taxes is never fun but something we have to do. The place they ended up when Jesus was born was probably not their desired location to bear their first child, but they made the most of the location.
Location trips a lot of people up on Christmas. Many have no choice. They will spend Christmas in the nursing home or jail. Many have no options. They may be too elderly or sick to travel. They may not have any place to go. If you have options then be thankful. If you have a place to spend Christmas then this is one of your best gifts of all. Don't fight about the place where you will spend Christmas. Make the best of wherever you end up and celebrate with whoever is around.
The presents of Christmas are often stressful. Presents are expensive and often we don't know what to buy and how much to spend. You may have a lot of gifts to buy or maybe you don't have a single person for whom you will buy a gift. If you can afford to buy gifts and want to then enjoy the opportunity. If finances are meager this year, then be honest with yourself and others and say our list and budget is very limited this year. Don't put yourself in financial jeopardy by spending money you don't have. The greatest gift is the baby Jesus. Focusing on Him will bring more peace than a house filled with gifts.
The pageantry of Christmas often becomes work. How many lights can you string on your roof or around your shrubbery? I enjoy putting up lights on a warm day but despise taking them down in January. Just remember what goes up must come down, eventually. Try to find a mild weather day, and you won't feel like the grinch.
The pressure of Christmas gets to a lot of people. People die in December. Loneliness takes over. Stress becomes paramount. People get depressed. Christmas should never be a time of loneliness, stress or pressure, but it was a difficult time for Mary and Joseph. They were poor people. Bringing a child into the world in a stable would not be considered an option for most of us. Traveling was a hassle and very difficult back then. While they were overjoyed with the baby Jesus, life's circumstances were not easy. Later, they would flee to Egypt for the safety of their family which had to add to their pressure.
The person of Christmas must be our focus in order to truly celebrate this season. Let's not lose sight of the main character in the Christmas story. If we do, then we will focus on the place, presents, pageantry and pressures of Christmas. Thus, we will miss out on the real joy that the heavenly host proclaimed to those shepherds watching their sheep.
"Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good will toward men." (Luke 2:14). 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Brewster's books honor first responders
author: Staff Writer
content:
Brewster's books honor first responders

 June 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1168
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Writers' Association created the Writers' Round Table Program to encourage writers, poets, playwrights and authors through monthly articles and activities.The Notable Maryland Author articles and associated Fun With Words writers' prompts are the centerpiece of the program. Each month, Southern Maryland Newspapers will feature a Maryland Writer's Association article about an author. Marylanders are encouraged to read the articles and try their hand at the writing prompts each month.
Author: James Burd Brewster
Genre: Children's picture books. Books contain pictures or illustrations that complement the story, often mirroring the plot. Both the text and the illustrations are important to the story. The pictures get the reader's attention and the text tells the complete story.
Sample reading list: "Uncle Rocky — Fireman: Fire!" "Sparky Protects, Ice Rescue," "Officer Jack: Underwater, Baby's Breath, Tourniquets for Heroes, La Plata Maryland — Team Effort; EMT Morales: Clamshell Stretcher, Deep Snow.
"Glad to do it!" — James Burd Brewster
Brewster was born a twin in Rochester, N.Y., on Dec, 8, 1954. Raised in Albany, he attended the United States Coast Guard Academy. Assigned to Wilmington, N.C. after graduation, he met and married Katie Spivey and careers later led them to Baltimore in 1987.
Hoping to give his sons a desire to help others, he began telling "Uncle Rocky — Fireman" stories.
Twenty-two years later, the family moved to Pomfret and after their youngest son Sam Sam left for college, they took a Wayne Karlan creative writing course at the College of Southern Maryland where the idea of turning the Uncle Rocky stories into books bubbled to the surface. With St. Mary's County illustrator Christina Allen and the support of Yvonne Medley's Life Journey's Writer's Guild, the couple started a publishing company and published their first book, "Uncle Rocky — Fireman" in 2013.
Initially, Brewster made up the stories and only had firemen books but at their first book show, a woman told him about a fire rescue her father had performed in New York City and Brewster realized he should base his future stories on real rescues. Her story evolved into "Face Mask" in the "Uncle Rocky — Fireman series."
Other first responders later asked Brewser to write about them and to date, the "Glad to do it!" series consists of 21 books, 10 about firemen, eight about police, and three about EMT.
Through a grant provided by the Maryland State Arts Council, Brewster customized a "Glad to do it!" book specifically for the La Plata police department, titled "La Plata, Maryland — Team Effort."
Brewster joined the MWA in 2017 and a year later initiated the Notable Maryland Author series as part of its 30th anniversary.
Next month's Notable Maryland Author article, the 77th in the series, will be the last as Brewster and his wife are moving to be closer with their grandchildren.
For more information on the "Glad to do it!" books, go to www.GladToDoIt.net.
Fun With Words
The MWA invites writers to have fun writing children's books about first responders like Jim Brewster. Using up to 100 words, pick a first responder service and write dialogue between first responders before, during, and after the dispatcher calls them.
Title your work and send to https://marylandwriters.org/Notable_Maryland_Authors by June 30th to receive an MWA Fun With Words submission certificate.
Last month, readers were asked writers to write metafiction like John Barth and in 100 words pick a literary convention and parody it or explore a relationship between literature and reality, life, and art.
Here are some regional selections:
Anything Goes in our Town
This fairy tale it may sound 'Grimm', but The Princess Bride has heard/
That Don Quixote he has said "I Want to Kill a Mockingbird."/
And Uncle Remus has just crossed, The Bridge Over The River Kwai/
He's on The Hunt for Red October, with The Catcher in the Rye/
All their noise stirred Rip Van Winkle, who is no longer fast asleep/
From Wuthering Heights he asks us now, "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?/
Then The Maltese Falcon shared, a lesson from The Mouse That Roared/
The author's pen it really is, much more mighty than the sword. /
Steve Baker, Waldorf
Folly's Wisdom
In ancient Baghdad there lived a scribe named Abeez. Every day he scratched down with a distracted qalam on papyrus grain counts half-heard. Truly, he wished to write stories but lacked plots.
One day he learned in the Storytellers' Precinct of the Plot Djinn. This magical being knew tales yet told. From that time on, Abeez searched for the storied spirit.
Ten years later, he found the djinn haunting ruined Antara.
Abeez said, "I desire original plots."
"Turn around," the djinn said. "What do you see?"
"My footprints shadowing dunes."
The djinn smiled. "In them find the stories you seek."
Lawrence McGuire, Waldorf
Chatter Boxing
You hear continuous chattering through walls pretty thin. What you hear is from two male dwellers, Bosco and Letague. Between the chatter you hear music playing, tenors singing opera or show tunes. The music prompts more activity like furniture moving, clatter of dishes.
I recognize Bosco plainly. He sounds louder and even caustic. Letague, a more gentle soul, is meek in manor and does not retort.
Sounds are shadows not permitting a full picture. Bells tinkle, doors close, and at middle age they rarely leave home. They are occupied by daily events between sunrise and sunset.
How I came to adopt these two parakeets is another story.
Christine Hickey, Deale
Happy Endings
Within the zeitgeist of modern culture, three forms of "happy endings" abide: The satisfying organic resolution to a real or fictional narrative that begins fraught and concludes well; the overwrought and over-written Hallmark Network tear-jerking formulaic caca-show that requires a complete suspension of belief and rationality; and the mirthless carnal conclusion to an unlicensed and medically useless non-therapeutic massage by a bored and contemptuous "masseuse."
I remain a fan of two out of three of those. It's silly, I know. Cannot help it. I bubble up, start quivering and soon need a Kleenex. If that's a crime, arrest me.
Jon Ketzner, Cumberland
Scenes from (Not Quite) True TV Detective
The night was dark, no stars, no moon. The building stood before them, a hulking half-acre maze of pitch-black rooms and hallways. The perps were in there, somewhere. Ignoring the obvious need for support, the detectives entered, the beams from their tiny flashlights dancing off the walls and corners.
I want to scream, "No, you idiots! Wait for backup! Or at least turn on a freakin' light!"
Who writes this stuff?
Then…"Clear!"
Wait, what's clear, that room you scanned for two seconds without looking in any closets or other obvious hiding places? That's clear?! Who writes this stuff?!
Jim Coleman, Ridgely
Train Encounter
As Maggie sat down, the woman next to her whispered. "Hello, Maggie."
Maggie turned. The woman looked familiar. "Do I know you?" she replied.
"I am Lilly, the mousey woman from Strangers on the Beach. I just loved being in your novel. It was a best seller, but basically a beach read, don't you think? Not up for a Pulitzer," the woman replied.
Maggie stared at her.
"Another thing, if you put me in a novel again, could I have big boobs and ooze with sex appeal?" The train bumped.
"Gotta go," she said exiting her seat. Maggie sat stunned.
Beth Smith, Cockeysville 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Tred Avon Players announce new president, officers - Localtheater
content:
Tred Avon Players announce new president, officers - Localtheater

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 441
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Tred Avon Players' board of directors announced Oct. 12 the appointments of Melissa Bar-comb-Doyle as president, Susan Patterson as vice president, Joe Tyler as theater manager and Cavin Alexandra Moore as secretary. Bill Gross continues in his role as treasurer.The Oxford-based group puts on theater and performing arts productions.Melissa Barcomb-Doyle, president"Barcomb-Doyle has been involved with community theater since she was twelve years old; in 2015, after a hiatus of over 20 years, she determined it was time to "tread the boards once again." In 2015, newly transplanted to the Eastern Shore, she discovered Tred Avon Players (TAP) and found herself back on stage as Julia in Lend Me a Tenor. She has appeared in numerous TAP productions since then, most recently as Randa in The Savannah Sipping Society," the Oxford-based group said in an announcement.Barcomb-Doyle joined the TAP board in 2021 and worked with Scott and Jeanne Prisco of Pope's Tavern on a fundraiser to commemorate TAP's 40-year anniversary."In addition to community theater, Barcomb-Doyle is currently involved with Broadway and Off-Broadway shows as co-pro-ducer (with her husband, Ken Doyle) of the Off-Broadway hit show, 'The Other Josh Cohen' and investor in the Broadway musical, 'The Who's TOMMY,'" the TAP release continues.Susan Patterson, vice president Patterson started volunteering at TAP in 2012 as an actor and board member, according to the Talbot County group.In 2017, she was named vice president of the board. In January of2023, she was appointed president when former president, John Norton, retired and relocated from the Eastern Shore.Joe Tyler, theater manager"Tyler has been active with TAP since 1987; starting with being in many shows, directing four musicals, and setting up the new box office system. He joined the board of directors in 2013. Tyler served as assistant secretary until 2022 and is currently the box office manager and newly appointed theater manager for TAP," according to the announcement.Cavin Alexandra Moore, secretaryMoore has been active with TAP since 2011 when she made her TAP debut in "The Big Bang", followed by "The Drowsy Chaperone" in 2012. Since then, Moore has been part of other several shows on stage and behind the scenes including "The Great Gatsby", "39 Steps" and "And Then There Were None" She became a member of the board in 2022 and has now taken on the role of secretary. Moore is the owner of Anahata Yoga in Cambridge.Bill Gross, treasurerGross joined the TAP board of directors in 2013 and was appointed its treasurer in 2014. He is active with several local theater groups.The Tred Avon Players nonprofit theater group was established in 1982.

title: Critically missing man found dead in Caroline County
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Critically missing man found dead in Caroline County

 October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 191
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The search for a missing 61 year-old man ended Tuesday morning when Caroline County first responders located the man dead in a pond less than a mile from the roadway where he was last seen.The Caroline County Department of Emergency Services received a 911 call just before 10:30 a.m. Tuesday reporting a drowning in the 25900 block of Hignutt Road in Denton. The Denton Volunteer Fire Company and Caroline County EMS personnel found the man.The Caroline County Sheriff's Office confirmed the man to be Alvin Jeffrey Ciprich, who was considered a critically missing person when the search began.Initial media releases from police said Ciprich was last seen in the 25500 block of Hignutt Road in Denton at approximately 11 p.m. Monday, Oct. 23. He was wearing grey sweatpants and an orange shirt. Ciprich was believed to be traveling on foot and was said to possibly be nonverbal.Ciprich was transported to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore to determine the cause and manner of death.Anyone with additional information is asked to contact the Caroline County Sheriff's Office at 410-479-5016.

title: USDA awards MARBIDCO funding to assist with expansion of livestock processing
content:

 Page: A5 | Section: News

 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - The United States Department of Agriculture recently announced it is awarding $3.8 million from its Meat and Poultry Intermediary Lending Program to the Maryland Agricultural Resource-Based Industry Development Corporation to finance the start-up and expansion of independent meat and poultry processing facilities in Maryland.MARBIDCO is a quasi-governmental economic development and financial intermediary organization with a mission to serve the commercial farming, forestry and seafood industries of Maryland.The USDA Meat and Poultry Intermediary Lending Program awards funds to financial intermediaries, like MARBIDCO, in the form of a grant to allow them to establish specialized revolving loan programs. The objective of the MPILP is to strengthen the financing capacity for small-and midsized independent meat processors, and to create a more resilient, diverse, and secure U.S. food supply chain.MARBIDCO is supplementing the USDA grant with another $1.3 million of its own funds to establish a special pool of lending capital of approximately $5 million.The Maryland Livestock Processing Loan Fund is designed to assist with the expansion of livestock and blue catfish processing capacity in Maryland. Farmers raising cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs still are facing very long lead times to get their animals processed, while blue catfish is an invasive fish species in the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries that is having a very detrimental impact on other species of fish and shellfish. Increasing commercial harvest and consumption of these catfish is one way to significantly reduce their numbers.Businesses engaged in the processing of livestock, or the invasive blue catfish can apply for a Maryland Livestock Processing Loan, which may also include an equity incentive grant of up to 10% of the project cost. Loan and grant proceeds can be used to purchase livestock processing and cold storage equipment, build or upgrade meat processing facilities, as well as purchase real estate on which the livestock processing activity will occur.MARBIDCO's Livestock Processing Loan Fund can offer standalone financing or work in conjunction with other financing provided by commercial lenders."This should be an incredible win for Maryland. The addition of new or significantly expanded meat processing facilities will positively impact many people within the food supply chain, from farmers and commercial fisherman to consumer's tables with these locally produced protein products," said MARBIDCO Executive Director Steve McHenry. "We are delighted to be a USDA grant recipient, and we want to thank the Maryland Department of Agriculture and our State's entire Congressional Delegation for their support of our application in what was a very competitive nationwide process." Loan amounts can range from a minimum of $250,000 up to a maximum of $2,500,000. MARBIDCO will charge a below-market fixed interest rate of 4% and will work cooperatively with borrowers on establishing other appropriate loan terms and conditions.An equity contribution of at least 7.5% of a project's total cost is required by the borrower (which can be matched dollar-for-dollar with a grant, not to exceed 10% of the project's total cost). The available equity grant match is coming from special funds appropriated to MARBIDCO by the State of Maryland to help enhance livestock processing capacity and cut down on long wait times.Further information and the program application form is available on MARBIDCO's website: www. marbidco.org. 
 
 Caption: PHOTO BY CONNIE CONNOLLY
 
Blue catfish fillets await skinning at the only USDA processing facility on the Eastern Shore.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/July 25
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/July 25

 July 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 533
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On July 25, 1972, the notorious Tuskegee syphilis experiment came to light as The Associated Press reported that for the previous four decades, the U.S. Public Health Service, in conjunction with the Tuskegee Institute in Alabama, had been allowing poor, rural Black male patients with syphilis to go without treatment, even allowing more than 100 of them to die, as a way of studying the disease.Also on this date:
In 1866, Ulysses S. Grant was named General of the Army of the United States, the first officer to hold the rank.
In 1943, Benito Mussolini was dismissed as premier of Italy by King Victor Emmanuel III, and placed under arrest. (He was later rescued by the Nazis and re-asserted his authority.)
In 1946, the United States detonated an atomic bomb near Bikini Atoll in the Pacific in the first underwater test of the device.
In 1956, the Italian liner SS Andrea Doria collided with the Swedish passenger ship Stockholm off the New England coast late at night and began sinking; 51 people — 46 from the Andrea Doria, five from the Stockholm — were killed. (The Andrea Doria capsized and sank the following morning.)
In 1960, a Woolworth's store in Greensboro, North Carolina, that had been the scene of nearly six months of sit-in protests against its whites-only lunch counter dropped its segregation policy.
In 1978, Louise Joy Brown, the first "test tube baby," was born in Oldham, England; she'd been conceived through the technique of in vitro fertilization.
In 1994, Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Jordan's King Hussein signed a declaration at the White House ending their countries' 46-year-old formal state of war.
In 2000, a New York-bound Air France Concorde crashed outside Paris shortly after takeoff, killing all 109 people on board and four people on the ground; it was the first-ever crash of the supersonic jet.
In 2010, the online whistleblower Wikileaks posted some 90,000 leaked U.S. military records that amounted to a blow-by-blow account of the Afghanistan war, including unreported incidents of Afghan civilian killings as well as covert operations against Taliban figures.
In 2019, President Donald Trump had a second phone call with the new Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, during which he solicited Zelenskyy's help in gathering potentially damaging information about former Vice President Joe Biden; that night, a staff member at the White House Office of Management and Budget signed a document that officially put military aid for Ukraine on hold.
In 2022, on a visit to Canada, Pope Francis issued a historic apology for the Catholic Church's cooperation with the country's "catastrophic" policy of Indigenous residential schools, saying the forced assimilation of Native peoples into Christian society destroyed their cultures, severed families and marginalized generations.
Today's Birthdays: Folk-pop singer-musician Bruce Woodley (The Seekers) is 83. Rock musician Jim McCarty (The Yardbirds) is 82. Reggae singer Rita Marley is 79. Musician Verdine White (Earth, Wind & Fire) is 74. Model-actor Iman is 70. Rock musician Thurston Moore (Sonic Youth) is 67. Celebrity chef/TV personality Geoffrey Zakarian is 66. Actor Matt LeBlanc is 58. Actor Wendy Raquel Robinson is 58. Actor David Denman is 52. Actor Jay R. Ferguson is 51. Actor James Lafferty (TV: "One Tree Hill") is 40. Actor Meg Donnelly (TV: "American Housewife") is 25.

title: Listen to the rhythm at the Chestertown Farmers Market
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Listen to the rhythm at the Chestertown Farmers Market

 July 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTEROWN — Each Saturday morning at the Chestertown Farmers Market on High Street, customers can find a refreshing variety of items from produce to baked goodies and handwoven crafts.Last weekend, among quilters, painters and wood carvers, author Marianne Laino Sade was selling her children's books, "TAPUM" and her latest "TA DA".
"TA DA" is especially welcome as baby's first book, recommended for ages 0-4 and their caregivers. "Children need their parents, grandparents, caregivers and guardians to read to them. It is so important for fundamental growth," Sade said.
So the books need to be interesting to the babies and those reading to them. And they certainly are.
Sade's offerings Saturday were each signed by the author. The artwork in her book is created in a collage style, using cut outs and concepts gleaned from her experiences as an English major and librarian across Maryland, New York and Pennsylvania.
Her first book published in 2022, "TAPUM" features a colorful drum on the cover and each element within the drum: the sun, the sea, a lion, are all pages in the book.
Done in that unique collage style, using patterns and dark and light contrasts, there is great attention to detail on each page.
You can hear the song playing along as you read.
"TAPUM!" is the sound of the drum in the world all around. Can you hear its rhythm? "TaPUM, Tapum, TaPUM!"," the back panel reads.
Sade said "TAPUM" came to her while awaiting a bus in New York in the 80's and just hearing that sound repeated. She was again inspired from attending a drum event featuring many world drummers including Babatunde Olatunji, hailed as the father of African drumming in the United States.
"TA DA" came about a little differently. Sade combined animals and music, visualizing frogs, dogs, birds and other colorful critters wanting to be a music band. With a nod to the Chester River Packet, the animal band perform at the end of High Street by the water.
The book talks about the universal appeal of music: "TA DA" celebrates the joy of making music together" and is a companion book to "TAPUM" following a musical theme.
Both books have thick, durable board pages and were appealing to families passing through the market such as Joseph and Amanda Carchi and their baby daughter Marie and son Owen. Little Marie smiled widely pointing at the pictures while Joseph read to her.
"These are very cool," Amanda noted.
So far, "TA DA" is doing well in sales too, selling at least 100 out of the 500 they ordered, Sade's husband Chris pointed out.
And perhaps as many authors tend to do, she is toying with a trilogy.
Sade said she has been reflecting about her childhood but would say nothing further, not wanting to spoil the big surprise.
Check out her books at msadeart.com.

title: Save a blue crab, eat a blue catfish
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Save a blue crab, eat a blue catfish

 June 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 734
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The blue crab population has been struggling. For the last four years, experts say, it has experienced significant declines, negatively affecting the economy and ecology of the Chesapeake Bay.Yet, for some studying blue crab populations, the answer to preserving the species is simple.
Allison Colden, executive director of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation Maryland, said one of the best ways to help preserve and uplift the rise of blue crabs in the Chesapeake Bay is by eating more blue catfish.
Colden explained that blue catfish are an invasive species that has been a primarily threat to the blue crab population on the Eastern Shore.
Harvesting and eating more blue catfish can help reduce their numbers and alleviate some of the predation pressure blue catfish are placing on important species like blue crabs, allowing blue crabs and other native species a better chance at survival and growing their low population numbers, she said.
There is agreement among environmental organizations, political leaders and watermen that creating a more streamlined path from harvesting blue catfish to getting them to market and table is key to getting control of their numbers.
Many watermen suggest establishing a whole new fishery of blue catfish alongside striped bass, blue crabs, oysters and other Bay produce. But for commercial fishermen, who have the capacity to harvest thousands of pounds of blue catfish, jumping through the regulatory hoops currently in place can be daunting and discouraging.
Tilghman Island Seafood in Talbot County is the only USDA-certified blue catfish processor on Maryland's Eastern Shore.
According to the state's website, Maryland is a prominent producer and processor of seafood and is the national leader in supplying blue crabs. The Chesapeake Bay provides about 50% of the total blue crab harvest in the United States, and each year, the Maryland seafood industry contributes nearly $600 million to the state's economy.
Colden said that 2022 had the lowest number of crabs on record according to a dredge survey by the Virginia Marine Resources Commission and Maryland Department of Natural Resources documenting population growth from 1990 to the present. These numbers have left experts concerned about the species.
"What has been concerning over the past couple of years is that we're seeing lower numbers of crabs that are staying low," Colden said. "In particular, the number of juvenile crabs is now at four years in a row below that long-term average, which is a concern because those juvenile crabs, which are sampled in the wintertime, are the ones that grow up to support the blue crab fishery in the fall."
Colden said this would mainly affect people who are fishing for crabs. Low numbers would impact the fishery and impact profits.
According to the 2024 dredge, there was a total crab abundance of 317 million blue crabs, a slight decrease from last year's estimated population of 323 million. However, it is still above the 2022 record low of 227 million crabs.
In 2024, the adult female crab population decreased to 133 million compared with 152 million last year. According to the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, this number falls far below the target of 215 million adult female crabs needed for a healthy population and sustainable harvest in the Chesapeake Bay.
Juvenile crab numbers improved slightly compared to 2022 numbers, but the juvenile population remained below average for the fourth year. Male crab numbers decreased from 55 million in 2023 to 46 million in 2024 despite male harvest limits instituted last year.
Chris Moore, executive director of Chesapeake Bay Foundation, said in a statement, "While juvenile population estimates can vary greatly from year to year, it is encouraging to see a slight increase in this segment of the population. However, given the population estimates from this year's survey, there remains a significant need to continue to protect adult females and critical nursery habitats, like underwater grasses, in order to help ensure better numbers in the future. "
Colden said she understands that they will not be able to eradicate blue catfish, but eating more of this invasive species would help alleviate factors that are negatively impacting blue crabs, which would give the blue crabs the best chance to bounce back from these low numbers.
"The Department of Natural Resources in Maryland is encouraging people to get out and eat catfish; they're delicious to eat, they're fun to fight if you're a recreational or commercial angler, and it will help reduce the impact that they're having on our native species — blue crabs," Colden said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Trey Rider sentenced to 15 months at detention center for house fire
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Trey Rider sentenced to 15 months at detention center for house fire

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 590
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Fred "Trey" Rider III has been ordered to turn himself into the Talbot County Detention Center on Monday morning to serve 15 months for reckless endangerment. His charges stem from a fire he started at his home in November 2022.At a sentencing hearing Friday, Judge Thomas G. Ross also handed Rider a 20-year sentence for first-degree arson with all but the time he's already served suspended. Rider was given five years of probation with conditions that include attending Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous meetings and completing an abuser intervention program.
In August, Rider pleaded guilty to first-degree arson and five counts of reckless endangerment for a fire started at his home in Easton on Nov. 24, 2022. He faced up to 30 years in prison and $50,000 in fines for first-degree arson and up to 25 years in prison and $25,000 in fines for the five counts of reckless endangerment.
Rider had also been charged with second-degree arson, first-degree malicious burning, two counts of arson threat, two counts of malicious destruction of property, obstruction of emergency assistance and two additional counts of reckless endangerment. As part of a plea deal, the state did not prosecute Rider for those nine additional charges.
Forty-five firefighters responded to the fire in Rider's two-story, single-family home at 27930 Peach Orchard Road in Easton. Through investigation, officials classified the fire as incendiary.
According to court documents, Rider's reckless conduct in igniting the house on fire "clearly" put the firefighters who responded in danger.
At Rider's plea hearing, Talbot County Deputy State's Attorney Joyce Jones said Rider blocked his two driveways with vehicles before setting fire to the house.
That night, Rider was located a short distance from his home and transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton for emergency care. Rider's attorney Christine DuFour said at the plea hearing that Rider was under the influence of alcohol during the incident and had slit his wrists.
At the sentencing hearing Friday, Jones asked that Rider's sentencing include incarceration. She said the fire was a planned event, citing threatening texts he sent his wife, Kari Rider, who is currently in the midst of a divorce from Trey Rider.
At the sentencing, Kari Rider said the night of the fire has caused her and their two sons lasting emotional and psychological effects. She said she and Trey Rider had been in a "horribly abusive relationship" and he had been destroying her things for years.
A restitution hearing, which Kari Rider asked for Friday, is set to be scheduled after the divorce proceedings.
DuFour, Trey Rider's attorney, said that over the past seven months, Trey Rider has put in hard work at a recovery center and a sober living home. She said that while he has a ways to go, Rider's goal is to become a sponsor for others struggling with addiction. DuFour said Rider also hopes to participate in reunification therapy with his sons.
A variety of people gave statements on Rider's character during the sentencing, including friends, family and counselors.
Rider said he was ashamed of his conduct, which has "caused immense harm and pain" in the lives of his wife and children. Before apologizing to his family, he said he has "fallen very far" and has reached out to get as much support as possible so he can continue down a road of recovery.
Before handing down the sentence, Ross called Rider's actions the night of the fire "calculated," "planned" and "self-serving." He said Rider has been given opportunities that most people don't get, including getting to begin rehab before being sentenced.

title: Mid-Shore trainers hit the seaside oval
author: TED BLACK tblack@somdnews.com
content:
Mid-Shore trainers hit the seaside oval

 July 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TED BLACK tblack@somdnews.com | Section: Sports 
 
 683
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A handful of owners and trainers with Mid-Shore connections made their way to Ocean Downs, a half-mile oval five miles west of Ocean City, but their ventures there were hardly for entertaining purposes or to savor the sand and sunshine.Last Wednesday, Ocean Downs hosted a quartet of $87,500 Maryland Sire Stakes finals for 3-year-olds of both gaits and genders on its annual "Summer Showdown" card for sophomore pacers and trotters. Several Mid-Shore owners, trainers and breeders performed well in those events as well as others on the card.
In the first parimutuel race on the card, trainer John Wagner of Centreville sent out a solid tandem that would garner second and fourth, respectively. Tony Babe (Jonathan Roberts) lived up to his billing as the 3-5 favorite to score in 1:55.4, while Wagner trainees Petes For Real (Fern Paquet Jr.) and Cloggs For Real (Corey Braden) finished second and fourth, respectively.
Then two races later in the $87,500 MDSS final for 3-year-old colt and gelding trotters, Wagner trainees Geralds A Keeper (Trae Porter) and K J Dash (Victor Kirby) finished one-two as expected. Geralds A Keeper lived up to his role as the 3-5 favorite when he overcame post six to gain command early to carve out all the fractions en route to a 1:58 score, his sixth in seven starts this year.
Then two races later in the $87,500 MDSS final for 3-year-old filly pacers, Yourgracefoundme (Eric Davis) finished second as an overlooked 36-1 shot as prohibitive 1-9 choice Fancy Like That (Johnathan Ahle) led throughout to prevail by seven lengths in 1:56 for owner-trainer Kasey Bendix. A sophomore daughter of Mr. Apples owned and bred by Jeffery Clark of Centreville, Yourgracefoundme sports a lifetime bankroll just shy of $100,000 from 21 starts.
Then just past the midway point of the Wednesday card, Sinatra De Vie (Ahle) lived up to his role as the 4-5 favorite in the $12,000 Open Handicap Trot when he overcame his assigned post eight and rallied from last year and widest of all down the backside and through the far turn en route to a three-length score in 1:55.1.
A 4-year-old son of Southwind Frank owned and trained by Eric Foster of Ridgely, Sinatra De Vie has won all four of his starts at Ocean Downs this summer and now sports eight wins and roughly $67,500 banked from 18 seasonal outings overall.
Several races later, Walden Woods (Hugh O'Neil) easily lived up to his billing as the even-money favorite in the $10,000 Open II class for older pacers when he gained command immediately from the coveted rail and led throughout en route to a three-length score while stopping the timer in 1:54.1. A 6-year-old Betting Line gelding owned and trained by Samuel "Wayne" Young of Church Hill, Walden Woods recorded his third straight score over the seaside oval.
Then one race later on the same card, Full Send (Russell Foster) easily lived up to his role as the even-money choice in a non-winners of $4,501 last four starts class for older pacers when he gained command through the clubhouse turn from the rail and led throughout en route to a three-length score in 1:52.4. A 7-year-old Western Ideal gelding trained by Eli Scott Jr. of Warwick, Full Send recorded his fifth win from 18 seasonal tries.
Last Thursday evening at Harrington Raceway, a half-mile harness racing oval in southern Delaware, Curtsyforpurrseco (Tim Tetrick) easily lived up to her role as the 3-5 favorite in the $110,000 Delaware Standardbred Breeders Fund final for 3-year-old filly pacers when she overcame post eight to gain command before the opener in 28.4, carved out honest fractions then drew clear late to a four-length score while stopping the timer in 1:56.1.
A sophomore daughter of Roddy's Bags Again trained by Jim King Jr. for owner Jo Ann Looney-King and bred by Winbak Farm in Chesapeake City, Curtsyforpurrseco completed a sweep of the DSBF spring series at Harrington and now owns five wins and just over $100,000 banked from 12 seasonal outings. She has also now won exactly one-half of her 22 career outings and boasts lifetime earnings just north of $200,000. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge man sentenced to five years for reckless endangerment
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge man sentenced to five years for reckless endangerment

 November 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 532
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - A Cambridge man was sentenced Monday to five years in prison for reckless endangerment and illegal possession of a firearm in connection to last year's fatal Fourth of July shooting in the town.Emphasizing the tragic nature of the shooting, Circuit Judge Karen Dean handed down a sentence consistent with the prosecutor's recommendation to Dominic Savage, 34: five years of incarceration for illegal possession of a regulated firearm and five years, all suspended, for reckless endangerment."The level of gun violence in this town is astonishing," said Dean, who splits time between courts in Dorchester and Wicomico counties.Officers from the Cambridge Police Department responded to the 1000 block of Cosby Avenue just before 9 p.m. on July 4, 2022, for a reported shooting. There, police found 24-year-old Tyuane Johnson of Cambridge with a gunshot wound to the right side of his head.Over 30 spent shell casings were observed by police in various areas around the scene.Police attempted lifesaving measures while waiting for paramedics.Johnson was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Dorchester, where he was pronounced dead.Autopsy results from the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner ruled Johnson's death a homicide from a gunshot wound.According to Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, police identified Savage in surveillance video of the shooting.L eonard said Savage fired a gun in the area, then fled toward a home on Greenwood Avenue.Savage was already prohibited from owning a firearm due to a previous conviction.During the shooting, Savage also sustained a gunshot wound to his left foot and left a trail of blood from the scene to Greenwood Avenue.In recommending the maximum penalty on the firearm charge, Leonard said Johnson's family was still not satisfied.In the months after the shooting, nearly a dozen men were arrested and charged in connection to Johnson's death and the chaotic scene that unfolded that night, including Savage.Charges against two of the men were eventually dismissed; others received time served sentences after pleading guilty to lesser charges. Three men were handed sentences ranging from 18 months to five years, to be served in state prisons.In September, Deondray Stanford, 23, of Cambridge, was sentenced to 10 years in prison for manslaughter, the most significant punishment in the case.But to the family, no plea would ever fill the hole left by Johnson's death, Leonard said.Defense attorney Andrea Jaskulsky agreed that Johnson's death was a tragedy, but asserted that Savage was the intended target of the fatal shooting. Other men charged in connection to the shooting were upset with Savage for not intimidating a witness in a different court case, she said.It was "impossible" to tell what was going on from the surveillance video, Jaskulsky added.Savage spoke briefly, saying that he was only walking out of his front door and didn't intend to hurt anyone.Both Savage and Jaskulsky asked the judge for consideration for a work-release program, which was opposed by Leonard and denied by Dean, though Dean said she would recommend work programs for him.Savage will receive credit for the 16 months already served in the county jail since his arrest last July.He will also be required to submit to mental health and substance abuse evaluations. 
 
 Caption: FILE PHOTO

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/Jan. 17
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/Jan. 17

 January 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 310
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Jan. 17, 1961, President Dwight D. Eisenhower delivered his farewell address in which he warned against "the acquisition of unwarranted influence, whether sought or unsought, by the military-industrial complex."On this date:
In 1917, Denmark ceded the Virgin Islands to the United States for $25 million.
In 1944, during World War II, Allied forces launched the first of four battles for Monte Cassino in Italy; the Allies were ultimately successful.
In 1950, the Great Brink's Robbery took place as seven masked men held up a Brink's garage in Boston, stealing $1.2 million in cash and $1.5 million in checks and money orders. (Although the entire gang was caught, only part of the loot was recovered.)
In 1955, the submarine USS Nautilus made its first nuclear-powered test run from its berth in Groton, Connecticut.
In 1966, the Simon & Garfunkel album "Sounds of Silence" was released by Columbia Records.
In 1977, convicted murderer Gary Gilmore, 36, was shot by a firing squad at Utah State Prison in the first U.S. execution in a decade.
In 1994, the 6.7 magnitude Northridge earthquake struck Southern California, killing at least 60 people, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
In 1995, more than 6,000 people were killed when an earthquake with a magnitude of 7.2 devastated the city of Kobe (koh-bay), Japan.
In 2016, Iran released three Americans, former U.S. Marine Amir Hekmati, Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian and pastor Saeed Abedini, as part of a prisoner swap that also netted Tehran some $100 billion in sanctions relief.
In 2020, U.S. health officials announced that they would begin screening airline passengers from central China for the new coronavirus; people traveling from Wuhan, China, would have their temperature checked and be asked about symptoms.
In 2022, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov angrily rejected U.S. allegations that Moscow was preparing a pretext to invade Ukraine, as Russian troops who were stationed near Ukraine's border launched more drills. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Suicides are at record levels in the U.S.; Men, specifically white men, are driving the wave
author: Mike Sunnucks; APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Suicides are at record levels in the U.S.; Men, specifically white men, are driving the wave

 August 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; APG National Enterprise Editor | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 941
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A record number of Americans killed themselves last year, according to new suicide numbers from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control.Who is driving the contemporary surge in suicides?"Middle-age white males," said Dr.Caroline Fenkel, chief clinical officer and co-founder of Charlie Health Inc., a Bozeman, Montana-based mental and behavioral health provider specializing in virtual and outpatient care for kids, teens and young adults.Men made up 79.4% of the record 49,449 suicides committed nationally last year, according to the CDC. White men make up 30% of the U.S. population.They accounted for 60% (29,847) of the suicides last year, according to the CDC.Fenkel said men, especially white men, can feel the pressures of societal and throwback gender role expectations - and still not show stigmatized weaknesses of their mental health.Gender roles associated with career expectations in a market-based economy also play a role, Fenkel said, pointing to how society can look down at working class and lower-income men employed in some lower-paying service sector jobs."They are constantly told that they should be successful. That they should be making a lot of money. That they should be providing for or having a family," Fenkel said.Men tend to use guns to kill themselves compared to women who use other means such as attempting overdoses."Women are attempting suicides more often but don't succeed, while men tend to complete suicides at much higher frequency," said Dusti Linnell, an associate professor of practice with Oregon State University's College of Health. She helps lead the university's community mental and behavioral health efforts."The completions are associated with firearms," Linnell said.Guns were used in 54.6% of all U.S. suicides last year, according to the CDC data, outpacing other methods such as poisoning and overdoses (11.6%) and suffocations and self hangings (25.8%).Fenkel said men are more impulsive in their decisions to kill themselves - and are less likely than women to talk about their mental health challenges openly."They are really more likely to self-treat and to self medicate with alcohol," she said. "I think they are less likely to ask for help in general.I think asking for help as a male is seen as a weakness." UPSETTING UPSWINGSuicides have been on the rise in the U.S. since 2000. There were 29,350 suicides reported by U.S. health agencies in 2000. They have increased 68.4% since then and 4.1% since 2019 before all the stressors and shutdowns of the coronavirus pandemic.The 2022 increases include noticeable jumps from 2021 among those ages 45-64 (6.6%) and 65 and older (8.1%) as well as Asians (5.7%) and Hispanics (4.3%).Those all outpace the overall 2.6% jump in suicides from 2021 to 2022.Linnell said she's seen worrisome increases in suicides and suicide attempts by farmers and others working in rural and outdoor vocations as well as continued mental health stigmas and a pronounced counselor shortages making it difficult for those in need to find help.Farmers, farm workers and others working outside have to deal with extreme weather changes including warmer temperatures as well as pesticides and other chemicals.Linnell said lingering stigmas about talking about mental health and suicidal thoughts can be magnified along with social isolations in smaller towns and rural regions."One of the most difficult things to say to another person is that you are thinking of killing yourself or harming yourself," she said.Fenkel said the shortage of mental and behavioral health workers is so pronounced that as many 150 million Americans live in "mental health deserts" where access to services and treatment can be scarce.SOLUTIONS?So what can be done?The growth of telehealth services born out of and magnified after the pandemic has improved access to mental and behavioral resources and sparked the growth of groups such as Montana-based Charlie Health, which was established in 2020.That can allow more therapists and counselors to live and work in smaller towns and rural areas while also seeing patients in bigger cities.It also can offer some privacy for those with mental and behavioral health challenges they might not trust sharing with family or employers. "It can be embarrassing," Linnell said.She said Oregon State is part of efforts in the Pacific Northwest to implement and grow peer-based mental and behavioral health programs.Whether its middle-age or older men or teenagers, it can be easier to talk about sensitive topics such as suicide and self-harm with a friend than family members or employers.High schools and colleges are implementing peer-based mental health programs.Linnell said Oregon State is looking to grow peer-based "Mental Health First Aid" and QPR (Question, Persuade, Refer) programs.The former entails a six-hour training programs to help participants to build skills to help friends and others in need while the other has shorter 90-minute programs aimed suicide prevention.A key goal is for those considering or recovering from self-harm to believe they can get better."It's so important for people to know that recovery is possible," she said. 
 
 Caption: WIKIMEDIA COMMONS/CREATIVE COMMONS/LENART LIPOVŠEK LENART /UNSPLASH.COM
 
Men made up more than 79% of total suicides in the U.S. last year, according to provisional data from the U.S. Centers of Disease Control. White men, who make up 30% of the total population accounted for 60% of the 49,449 suicides nationally, the agency said.
 
AP PHOTO/MARK LENNIHAN, FILE
 
A sculpture called the "Vessel" at the Hudson Yards development in New York City saw a series of suicides after opening in 2019. The U.S. saw a record numbers of suicides last year, according to provisional data from the U.S Centers for Disease Control.
 
Those dealing with suicidal thoughts and mental health crises can call or text 988 for help and resources.

title: County council approves change to alcohol code allowing for possible liquor store in Trappe
author: Natalie Jones
content:
County council approves change to alcohol code allowing for possible liquor store in Trappe

 January 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 239
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council on Tuesday approved a change to the county's alcoholic beverage code, paving the way for a liquor store to be considered and established in Trappe.The bill, first introduced in November, came after a request from several Trappe residents hoping to develop a liquor store within the town.
The existing county code included certain restrictions on the issuance of off-sale licenses, or licenses that allow the sale of alcohol for off-premises consumption.
According to Patrick Thomas, the county attorney, a formula limits the number of off-sale licenses that can be issued.
Thomas said Trappe does have some off-sales licenses, but the town does not have a Class E license, which is required to open a liquor store. It's the only municipality in Talbot County that does not have one.
"This would allow any municipality to have up to one Class E establishment, so that way, residents of Trappe would have the same access to a store that others in the county have," he said.
Town residents currently have to drive to Easton or Cambridge to shop at a liquor store.
Council Vice President Pete Lesher emphasized that the council does not issue liquor licenses — the county liquor board does — but the bill enables that the board to be able to review one for the town.
"Without this legislation, a new business would not be possible," he said. "So this is enabling legislation for sure."
The bill was approved unanimously.

title: Talbot County man charged with sexually assaulting a child
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Talbot County man charged with sexually assaulting a child

 April 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 123
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Kevin Halmiton Manning, 34, was convicted for sexually assaulting a 3-year-old child in Talbot County. Manning pled guilty to 10 counts between two cases in the Circuit Court for Talbot County.In the first case, Manning pled guilty to a felony third-degree sex offense, which involved the 3-year-old. In the second case, Manning pled guilty to two counts of witness intimidation, two counts of electronic communication harassment and five counts of violation of a protective order. The counts were committed against the child's mother.
Manning's plea was followed by an investigation by the Easton Police Department, Talbot County Department of Social Services and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office. The case was prosecuted by Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel.
Sentencing is scheduled for July 24.

title: Events around Caroline
author: Connie Connolly
content:

His work reflects transformation and resilience.

title: Chickens find community support in Ridgely
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Chickens find community support in Ridgely

 September 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — On Monday, Ridgely commissioners and residents discussed potentially allowing chickens within town limits.Listed in Chapter 64-4 of the town's code, the breeding, feeding, pasturing and penning of chickens and multiple other animals is currently prohibited within the town. But after some discussion from town residents, rules regarding chickens could change.
According to town staff, the conversation has been ongoing through the past couple of months, but it gained traction after residents began preparing petitions and presentations on chickens.
Mason Sparks, a resident of the town, gave a presentation to the town on chickens at the commissioners' August meeting. At Monday's meeting, Sparks said that he knocked on 471 doors and received 178 responses from residents, 87.6% of whom were in favor of allowing chickens.
Resident Andrew Meyer also spoke on Monday in favor of chickens being allowed within the town limits.
"I just want to start by saying that I strongly support allowing chickens in town," Meyer said. "There's towns and cities all over the country that currently allow chickens. Today, more and more people want to know where the food's coming from, and raising backyard chickens for eggs is one way that people can ensure that they have healthy raised source of food."
Meyer addressed some concerns he said he has heard about chickens.
"As far as noise, hens are no louder than barking dogs or children playing. As far smells, a small backyard coop that's kept clean would have minimal smell. It's no more disturbing than any other farm smells that town is currently surrounded by. I think the benefits outweigh any small disturbance that would cause to any neighbors around the town."
After hearing from residents, the commissioners voiced their opinions.
"It seems like the residents are definitely in favor," Commissioners Chad Leister said. "I know that I personally reached out to all our neighboring town councils and spoke to them, mainly just to see, some I guess bad feedback they would have for the chickens, and, as you know, there wasn't really a whole lot of it. So, I think I'm willing to be okay with it."
The commissioners made a motion to work on the legal wording of the town code to draft an ordinance to allow chickens within the town. The ordinance is expected to be presented at the next meeting.

title: Talbot County to light up green for veterans
author: Contributed
content:
Talbot County to light up green for veterans

 October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 390
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In advance of the upcoming Veterans Day holiday, the Town of Easton plans to illuminate town and county buildings green from Nov. 6 through 12 - part of Operation Green Light for Veterans.The nationwide initiative, led by the National Association of Counties, raises awareness around the unique challenges faced by many veterans and the resources available at the county, state and federal levels to assist veterans and their families.The Town of Easton will be working together with the Talbot County Government on this project, with plans to light up Town and County buildings along with encouraging local businesses and residents to join in support of veterans.Now in its second year, Operation Green Light is spearheaded by NACo and the National Association of County Veterans Service Officers, building upon successful efforts by the New York State Association of Counties and the NYS County Veteran Service Officers' Association in 2021.In 2022, over 300 towns and counties participated in Operation Green Light."It's a great way to remind our community of all that our veterans have done for our country over the years," said Easton Mayor Megan Cook."In addition to the green lights on our buildings, we also want to shine a light on the employees in our organization who have served, and in some cases continue to serve our country. We are so proud of and inspired by the veterans and service members on our team. This is just a great opportunity to honor them and let them know what they mean, n to us."In addition to lighting buildings and other meaningful landmarks, residents, businesses and other organizations are encouraged to participate by simply changing one light bulb in their home to a green bulb.This can be an exterior light that neighbors and passersby see or an interior light that sparks a conversation with friends."Operation Green Light is a gesture of support and appreciation for the public service of our veterans," said NACo Executive Director Matthew Chase. "With hundreds of towns and counties coming together to light everything from bridges to courthouses, we know veterans across the country will see and feel the gratitude we all feel for their service and sacrifices."Counties and residents across the country are sharing their participation on social media using the hashtag #OperationGreenLight.For more information on Operation Green Light, visit https://veterans.mary-land.go v/op e ration-g reen-light/.
